title: ‘Ahead of the curve’: Maryland realtors not as affected by NAR settlement
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘Ahead of the curve’: Maryland realtors not as affected by NAR settlement

 September 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 632
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A $418 million settlement by the National Association of Realtors has brought forth changes to traditional practices of how broker commissions are paid. Maryland realtors, however, aren't having to adjust as much as their counterparts.The settlement was reached in May after class-action lawsuits by home sellers alleged antitrust violations stemming from requirements placed on listing brokers. The NAR denied any wrongdoing in connection to those claims.
In the wake of the settlement, two key changes from the NAR went into effect in August. First, homebuyers must sign a written agreement with an agent before that agent provides any services to the buyer. Second, offers of compensation from a seller to a buyer's agent may no longer be shared on multiple listing services, which are marketplaces for realtors.
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors' stance on the changes is that there is now an increased sense of transparency for homebuyers and sellers.
"The lawsuit was really about transparency and how (buyer's agents are) getting paid," Shelby Roney, board president, said. "And it kind of makes you reiterate why you should be paid."
Roney, a realtor for Benson & Mangold Real Estate, said Maryland won't be feeling that first change as much as other states. She pointed out that Maryland has had buyer's agency since 1999, noting a law enacted in 2016 that required written buyer agency agreements.
Maryland realtors representing potential buyers are used to signing those written agreements, detailing to the buyer what services the agent will provide and at what cost. The national rule will reinforce that routine and force buyers and agents to sign agreements that are even clearer in outlining how much commission will cost for the agent.
"We've always been very proactive and ahead of the game, ahead of the curve," Roney said of Maryland.
Meanwhile, other states that did not have clear buyer's agency law had to quickly adjust to the new requirements.
"They were already freaking out before March," Roney said of other states. "When I was in California, there were agents from all over the country, and most of them did not have anything resembling buyer's agency. And it was very concerning for them, that they were nowhere prepared. How to explain it, how to even enforce it, how to word it, their state laws were going to have to change."
The increased focus on explicit buyer's agency agreements only furthers the advantages of a buyer paying their own agent rather than relying on a sub-agent during the buying process, Roney said.
Sub-agents are agents unaffiliated from the listing real estate broker but paid by the seller or seller's agent to assist prospective buyers. They do not work for the same company as the seller's agent.
Sub-agency is still alive in the state, according to Roney. However, sub-agents are only able to provide so much help to buyers since their loyalties are only to the seller. For prospective buyers, having a dedicated buyer's agent is beneficial.
"It's the biggest investment that you're going to make in your lifetime," she said of buying a home. Roney did note that many first-time homebuyers have benefitted from the seller paying the commission for an agent.
The option for a seller to offer compensation to a buyer's agent is still available, Roney said, though not through multiple listing service databases. Now, it'll be clear to buyers before any agreement is signed.
The benefits of having a buyer's agent are significant for buyers, especially when housing prices rise, the Mid-Shore Board of Realtors says. It'll also help realtors understand their value and be upfront about what "tier" of services they will offer depending on the compensation rate.
"You have to know your value and you have to explain your value, and you also have to decide what your tiers (of service) are," Roney said. " … Where do you want me to work for you?"

 EASTON — Talbot Interfaith Shelter will be holding its eighth annual Lip Sync Battle Fundraiser on April 27 at the Waterfowl Building in Easton.This year, Talbot Interfaith aims to raise $100,000 to help fulfill its mission of providing shelter, stability and support for local families and individuals in need.
This year, the Lip Sync Battle will see a diverse range of participants. Nineteen teams, including local business owners, school faculty and community leaders, will compete for the top fundraiser title and the coveted Lip Sync Battle trophy. Among them are the Country School Faculty, Father Nash of Saints Peter and Paul Parish, and Vintage Books, each bringing their unique flair to the event.
A panel of judges, including County Council member Keasha Haythe, Easton Mayor Megan Cook and Easton Utilities president and CEO John Horner, will scrutinize each team.
"We're thrilled to bring back the Lip Sync Battle in all its glory," Julie Lowe, executive director of Talbot Interfaith, said. "It's more than just a fundraiser; it's a celebration of community spirit and resilience. Seeing individuals of all backgrounds come together for a common cause is truly inspiring. Last year's event exceeded our expectations, and we're immensely grateful for the ongoing support."
The event will be hosted by Jayme D, Jay Hudson and Ricky Vitanovec. The event is sponsored by Platinum Record Sponsor Sun Management Rising Technologies and a group of other sponsors.
Tickets are available at talbotinterfaithshelter.org/lsb.

title: Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum celebrates 60 years
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum celebrates 60 years

 April 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 737
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST.MICHAELS — A staple of St. Michaels, the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum is celebrating 60 years.Volunteers spearheaded the creation of the museum, which opened in 1965 at Navy Point and was accredited in 1978.
"The museum really started out by a community effort," said Pete Lesher, chief historian and ambassador at large at the museum. "The collections were built with an outpouring from the community over the idea that the place is changing and we need to establish a museum to remember the way it was."
Lesher, came to the museum in 1991 as a curator. He said the museum was created in a "series of themes" to represent the Bay and people around the it.
MUSEUM HISTORY
The museum started in May 1965 with two buildings that had been on the grounds since 1850 the Higgins house and the Dodson house. The eagle house building arrived in 1870. The three buildings now serve as administrative buildings after serving as exhibit buildings for nine years in the early days.
According to Lesher, the land where the museum's lighthouse and other exhibits now sit was reclaimed from the Bay.
"This was just a shallow part of the park," Lesher said. "You would have been standing probably knee deep sinking into mud about 150 years ago.
"This area started with actually a sawmill and grist mill but moved beyond that to seafood packing houses, and by the height here in the 1930s and 1940s, there were four different seafood packing houses out on this point. Every time they wanted to expand, they simply discarded more oyster shells, which they end up on themselves, pushing them into the harbor and built more land."
William Coulbourne and Frederick Jewett were two African American business owners who owned one of the four businesses on the land.
"They were early 20th century Black entrepreneurs from Crisfield, Maryland, who moved up here," Lesher said. "They learned the business and managed to get somebody to sell them land and managed to get somebody to give them a bank loan — a remarkable success story."
The museum plans to honor Coulbourne and Jewitt by renaming its education building after the two entrepreneurs.
The lighthouse, which is featured in the museum's logo, is the first historical structure the museum collected. It was acquired in 1966 when the Coast Guard was demolishing lighthouses "left and right" because of vandalism, according to Lesher.
The museum bought the lighthouse from the demolition company and moved it 50 miles north to the museum site.
"It was so early in our history, it became our logo," Lesher said. "The lighthouse is sort of what identifies the museum."
One of the new changing exhibits at the museum is the Sailing to Freedom exhibit, which highlights the Underground Railroad on the water.
"So we think of the Underground Railroad like the Harriet Tubman story of running up the Delmarva Peninsula to get to Philadelphia and freedom," Lesher said.
"Well, a lot of people made it by boat, whether they got a ticket on a steamboat, got away that way or stowed away on a coast-wise schooner, so many of them on the Chesapeake Bay, while the Chesapeake Bay forms a natural watery highway to the north. This was a route to freedom for many of those freedom seekers," he said. "That's what we try to show with this exhibit."
HELPING THE COMMUNITY
In addition to exhibits for museum-goers, the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum uses some exhibits to help with the curriculum in Talbot County schools.
An exhibit displaying the Maryland Crab Meat Company sits where the museum holds the Chesapeake's Best Crab Cakes program, in which third and fifth graders receive math, reading and social studies credits in the curriculum.
"The Chesapeake's Best Crab Cakes program meets learning goals for for math, for reading and for social studies in the Maryland curriculum," Lesher said. "Every Talbot County third grader and fifth grader has an experience tied to their curriculum, tied to their learning goals right here in the museum."
The museum also conducts an apprenticeship program where museum staff work with an apprentice for two years, ultimately leading to a state credential.
According to Lesher, the museum has hired some of these apprentices as permanent shipyard crew.
The museum has partnered with the St. Michaels Community Center on multiple occasions.
"We're working to do more community collaborations with them because both our missions align, and we want to enrich the lives of people who live in St. Michaels," said Amy Horne, executive director of the community center.

title: Author publishes 10th novel - BOOKS & AUTHORS
content:
Author publishes 10th novel - BOOKS & AUTHORS

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6A | Section: News 
 
 1031
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Louise Gorday published her latest book, "Letter of the Law," in late August through Amazon's Kindle Direct Publishing.Many of Gorday's 10 novels center on life in a small fictional Southern Maryland town based loosely on Chesapeake Beach.The award-winning author has started writing her 11th novel, a historical fiction murder mystery set in 1923.Gorday lives in Dunkirk with her very patient husband, two Shelties, and Emmett, an African Grey who can sing the "SpongeBob SquarePants" theme song."I could blame it on a stapler," she said of writing. "Or maybe it was the Scotch tape, the dog ear, or the occasional white paste. Whatever it was, once I found I could join pieces of paper and write stories, I was forever enthralled by this great adventure called writing." "Letter of the Law" can be found at Amazon.com or for more information about Louise Gorday, go to How long have you been writing, and how did you get started?Creative writing - poetry and short stories - has been a passion of mine since grade school. I attempted my first novel when I was 14, and throughout the years, writing a book was always an ambition.Professionally speaking, I have been writing since 2010.About 13 years ago, I was thinking about how my mother used to refer to me as "Annie off the pickle boat." Suddenly, I realized that I had no idea what that meant, so I started researching the saying.Fishing boats that pickled their catch would slow down as they returned to port. Hence, my mother's phrase referred to someone bringing up the rear.Then the literary muse stepped in and paired pickling boats and the nickname of a historic, unrenovated, old beach house in Chesapeake Beach (Orphan Annie), and voila, my first novel "The Pickle Boat House" was born.From there, I've branched off into nine other novels that include historical fiction and fantasy.What inspires you to write?Everything. I love tying bits and pieces of information together - letting my mind wander and create. In Southern Maryland, we are blessed with stunning landscapes and so many natural wonders (Battle Creek Cypress Swamp, Calvert Cliffs), and fabulous history (the amusement park at Chesapeake Beach, Moll Dyer witch tale) is all around us. I write about these things, spinning them into stories with hopefully likable fictional characters.I also often write with underlying themes: grief, sibling rivalry, jealousy, and selfishness, for example. "Letter of the Law" tackles issues of father-son relationships.And then there is my sense of humor. Humor underlies much of what I write because I'm tickled by a lot of things.Do you consider writing to be a career?Yes, a second career. I've been writing continually for 10 years and I'll continue as long as the muse keeps shoving stories at me.What kind of writing process do you use?Typically, I get up every morning, eat breakfast, and then open up my laptop to my latest work in progress. I read through what I wrote the previous day, usually hate most of it, and start revising. Before I know it, I'm putting down new material. I usually work with a goal of writing a certain number of words each day. When I reach that number, I close up shop and walk away to do other things.My first novel took 2½ years to write. Later ones have taken as little as six to seven months.It all depends on how giving the muse is. I've spent the last 10 years working with the same editor. He's terrific and taught me a lot about writing.I would never publish a book without an editorial review.Who are some of your favorite authors and why?I love Michael Connelly's "Bosch" and "Lincoln Lawyer" series. His writing is so crisp and clear, and his plots are always fresh. Neil Gaiman is another favorite. His imagination is spectacular. They have a substantial impact on how I write, but maybe not in the way one would think. I look at their sentence structures, the way they move characters around, change scenes, end chapters; the technical stuff.That's what I retain and how I improve my writing skills. I try to learn from the masters.What do you want readers to know about you?I'm a quiet, reflective person with a wild imagination and a sly sense of humor, and these traits readily show up in my stories. Also, that I'm an intensely proud Marylander.I grew up in Clinton and I've lived in Calvert County for over 25 years. I love sharing Southern Maryland through my writing.And finally, I want to share that I work hard at what I do with the intent of providing an entertaining immersive experience. Story development, editing, and book cover designs, I want to put out the very best book that I can for readers to enjoy.Please include a brief description of your book: "Letter of the Law" is in the fantasy genre about Hamelin Russell, an immortal who is assigned to run messages between the Weigh Station (a purgatory-like place in the afterlife) and the pearly gates.Hamelin has been stuck in the afterlife for over 700 years; not good enough to enter heaven, and not bad enough to be condemned to hell. He hopes that this latest assignment will finally get him to the promised land.Please include an excerpt from the book: Chapter One: The Door This was the view that greeted those God saved?Hamelin looked right, then left, then straight ahead again.He saw no St. Peter marking names off a list so long and unwieldy that it spilled off his desk and stretched endlessly into the distance. No twinkling stardust or chorus of angels singing anthems of praise just inside gates of glistening pearl, and no white, shining city bathed in ethereal light on the other side of a tall marble wall. There simply was no other side. He stared off into black, limitless space. He had delivered judged souls to paradise for eons, but he had never come this far. He had transferred them into heavenly care at the portal entrance some hundred yards away. How him as Ezekiel, although he probably went by many names.

Author Louise Gorday of Dunkirk, who recently published her 10th novel, "Letter of the Law," said, "Once I found I could join pieces of paper and write stories, I was forever enthralled by this great adventure called writing."

 Historically, those living down long lanes and private roads in Dorchester County have struggled to get broadband access. However, a state funded program is working to expand high speed internet access to these areas."One of the cool things about this is that a majority of the people on this list, except for the people who came forward, don't even know they're getting broadband coming to their homes," said Dorchester County grant writer Marylin Williams.
The Maryland Homestretch — Difficult To Serve Properties Program is administered by the Maryland Office of State Broadband and provides funding for internet installation in areas where it can be particularly expensive. The program is also referred to as the Long Driveway Internet Program.
Williams referred to the program as "ever changing," saying the state modified the grant program as recently as this spring.
This came in handy when the amount initially awarded to the county was not enough to cover projected costs for the project.
Initially, the county was granted $1.1 million, but the project is estimated to cost $2,422,493. The county was recently awarded with a higher grant after Williams advocated for more homes to be covered.
However, The grant still will not cover all of the 299 homes approved to be serviced, so energy companies Bay Country and Choptank Electric are investing in the county to ensure access, Williams said.
Choptank Electric spokesperson Valerie Connelly and Williams requested two action items from the Cambridge County Council at the June 3 County Council meeting.
The first item is accepting the higher grant award of $1,217,852. The second is having the county sign a memorandum of understanding with Choptank Electric and Bay Country. The Commissioners unanimously agreed, with County Commissioner Ricky Travers leading the motion.
According to Connelly, broadband will be installed at no cost to the homeowners and all construction must be completed by Dec. 31, per the grant.

Maple Elementary School celebrates Teacher Appreciation Week

 Words

 CAMBRIDGE — During Teacher Appreciation Week at Maple Elementary School, administrators planned various activities and events to boost staff morale and show the appreciation that administrators and students have for their teachers.Myesha Ford, principal at Maple Elementary, said the goal was to find activities that would get teachers working together and complementing each other, as well as spreading kindness and joy throughout the building.
"I feel like if our teachers are happy, and they can come to work and just kind of be able to love what they do, that kind of transfers over to the students," Ford said. "So we see when our teachers are happy, our students are happy."
Ford said they set up games for the week with the reality show "Survivor" as the theme. Teachers would spin a wheel, and the number that they get would correlate to a challenge. The challenges included writing a paragraph of praise to a fellow teacher and sending it to the principal to give the message anonymously.
Haley Wright, a teacher at Maple Elementary, said she had a lot of fun this week. She enjoyed the appreciation she received from staff and the chance to connect with other teachers at the school.
"It allows teachers who may not always see each other or maybe they're able to establish new friendships among their staff members. The kids really get into it," Wright said. "On their morning announcements, students asked staff to ask us, 'Did we spin the wheel?' 'What challenge are we going to work on today?' So I think it also allows for the students to get excited about it, too."
Natalie Drake, teacher at Maple Elementary, said she enjoyed the work that the administration put into this week, especially while making it a team activity. Drake described how teachers and support staff were split into teams to earn points to be the winning team at the end of the week.
By far, Drake's favorite part was feeling seen by other teachers and staff at the school.
"I did receive one of those anonymous emails today, and that really just put a smile on my face," Drake said. "Other people here at school recognize the hard work that we all put in. They're very appreciative of all that we do here. So not just our administration appreciates us, but also our colleagues are appreciative of us."
For Ford, teachers work hard all year, and with standardized testing, it is easy for everyone to feel a bit burned out this time of the year. These events are meant to refresh everyone and provide a positive outlet for energy for teachers, staff and students.
"Teaching is hard. But it's fun, and it's rewarding," Ford said. "I enjoy seeing my teachers in action, their passion, and you can truly tell that they care about all of their students, and it just makes me feel good. It makes me proud to be the principal here and just proud to be able to work with such amazing educators."

title: Future of DOGE in Supreme Court's hands
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Future of DOGE in Supreme Court's hands

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 691
 Words 

 Read News Document

 To date, more than two dozen lawsuits have been filed challenging the authority, power, goals, plans, initiatives and actions of President Trump's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).No doubt many more lawsuits will follow.
The rulings by lower court judges on the already filed lawsuits are mixed.
Some lower court judges have ruled a president has broad constitutional authority to fire, demote or reassign federal executive branch employees without input from or approval of Congress.
Other lower court judges have ruled a president does not have broad constitutional authority to fire, demote or reassign federal executive branch employees without input from or approval of Congress.
Appeals of lower court judge rulings to the U.S. Supreme Court are not a matter of if, but a matter of when, as well as exactly how they will be addressed.
Ilya Shapiro, a senior fellow and director of constitutional studies at the Manhattan Institute, has already predicted a majority of the justices will support a ruling in approving DOGE's authority, plans and actions.
In a recent commentary, "The Supreme Court is Poised to Restore the President's Executive Power," Shapiro writes, "Article II of the U.S. Constitution begins with a simple declarative sentence: 'The executive power shall be vested in a president of the United States."
He also writes: "A majority on the Court now seems set to return to that view.'"
That majority of the Court referred to by Shapiro is presumably Chief Justice Roberts and Associate Justices Thomas, Alito, Kavanaugh, Gorsuch and Coney Barrett.
These six justices are often referred to collectively as a right-of-center bloc.
Shapiro gives special attention to Chief Justice Roberts.
He refers to a 2005 Supreme Court majority opinion written by Roberts on presidential authority. In it, Roberts explained Article II authority in the U.S. Constitution "generally includes the ability to remove executive officials."
He also says that is "a power that is necessary to ensure the accountable and effective execution of federal policy."
Shapiro also notes that Roberts has stated, without the power to remove executive branch officers, "the president could not be held fully accountable for discharging his own responsibilities; the buck would stop somewhere else."
The key word in Chief Justice Roberts thinking is "generally."
The Merriam-Webster's dictionary defines "generally" as often or regularly.
It does not define "generally" as "always."
That is affirmed by recent actions by Chief Justice Roberts on two lower court rulings on DOGE.
In the first action Chief Justice Roberts, along with Justice Amy Coney Barrett, joined the Supreme Court's left-of-center bloc of justices in blocking President Trump's efforts to freeze $2 billion in foreign aid funding and temporarily blocking budget cuts.
In the second action, Roberts and Coney Barrett agreed with a majority of their left-of-center colleagues on a decision that the court would not overrule a temporary order from a lower court to stop Trump from firing the head of the Office of Special Counsel.
These two actions refute the idea that members of the conservative bloc are unified and consistently unable to reach agreement with members of the left-of-center Justices.
It also demonstrates that Roberts and Coney Barrett are willing to side against Trump in legal challenges on certain DOGE Issues.
Most importantly, it affirms that the issue of presidential authority and power will require extraordinarily intense dialogue and deliberations among all the justices on the short-term and long-term ramifications of their ultimate decisions.
Payvan Ahdout, a law professor at the University of Virginia, suggests the court is "open to a role for judicial review of these [DOGE] decisions, but they just have not yet reached consensus on what that judicial role should be."
Going forward, Chief Justice Roberts and Justice Coney Barrett could be part of majority member rulings that all, most, some or few of DOGE actions are unconstitutional or could be constitutional with revisions.
If both do so, the outcomes will be 6-3 majority rulings for DOGE.
If only one does, it will still be 5-4 rulings for DOGE.
Conversely, if both join again with three of left-of-center justices to sustain lower court challenges against DOGE it will be 5-4 rulings against DOGE.
Ultimately, every Supreme Court review and ruling on every lower court DOGE ruling will determine the future scope of DOGE's constitutional authority, plans, efforts, success or failure to meet projected results.

Summerfest celebrates 35 years

 DENTON — The 35th annual Summerfest drew thousands for a kaleidoscope of family fun Aug. 16 and 17.This year's event was called Storybook Summerfest. There were lots of booths. Some served Ridgely Fire Department's famous pork parfait, and others gave out information on community services like CASA of Caroline.
There were three stages cranking out live music from singer-songwriters, Mike Elzy's students, blue grass artists and funk band G Method. The belly dancing crew of Sammati Dance was even seen dancing with swords balanced on the their heads.
Keith Shaffer, in his best radio announcer voice, called people together for the opening ceremony Friday evening.
"Ladies and gentlemen welcome to Summerfest. In preparation for the opening ceremony in front of the Caroline County Courthouse. Please make way for one of Caroline County's finest marching bands- The North Caroline High School Marching Band of Blue," Shaffer said.
The blue river of high school students with flutes and tubas and snare drums stopped in front of the courthouse. They played the Star Spangled Banner. Then, Mayor Abby McNinch got on the courthouse steps and declared the 2024 Summerfest officially open.
Later after the kids played their song and the color guard raised the flag. Frank Bartz, a Caroline County commissioner, said, "I like seeing all the people from the county in all different towns come together and enjoy themselves and enjoy summer. This is a great collaboration between The Arts Council, County, town and Parks and Recreation."
Jaimie Beechey, director of Caroline Recreation and Parks said, "(Summerfest) was started by the town of Denton and Caroline County in 1989. So this is the 35th year. Logistics-wise, it is such a well-oiled machine between the town, who have a lot of people who have been there a long time, and Recreation and Parks and the county. There are so many people that have been picking this up, that logistically it is just a little tweaking. What is hard is how much money we need to raise to make this happen."
Summerfest leans heavily on its generous local sponsors to fund the many activities offered each year. The event typically draws between 5,000 and 8,000 visitors, Beechey said.
Hallie Readores, a program specialist, had on a mad hatter's black hat with playing cards in the sash around the brim. She took the year's literary theme and ran with it to Alice's Wonderland. She ran a fun, tunnel-like attraction that people had to crawl in to get inside.
"We wanted to bring Alice In Wonderland to life," she said. "Once you go down the rabbit hole, like the classic story, you decorate a mad hatter's hat. Tomorrow we will have a little tea party surprise. Everyone seems to be loving it."

 EASTON — In the wake of the Delmarva Pride Center's third annual Pride festival last Saturday, the Easton Town Council saw a full chamber June 17.For a second consecutive meeting, many attendees spoke out in support of Pride initiatives and the festival, including Tina Jones, a board member of the Delmarva Pride Center.
"Those four days were a time of love and joy, of music and dance," Jones said of the festival. "Everyone could be themselves, love themselves and share their love with others."
The June 3 meeting saw significant pushback on council President Frank Gunsallus for questioning whether the town funds should support downtown Pride banners at a council meeting in May.
"I think it is safe to say that the economic return to the Town of Easton more than offset the cost of a few banners and a handful of street lights," Jones said on June 17.
Some who attended the festival thanked council members they saw Saturday, including Gunsallus, Curry and Davis.
Resident Jen Voshell spoke during public comment to Gunsallus, "wondering if (he) would consider retracting (his) previous opposition" and "support the permitting (of the festival) in 2025." In January, Gunsallus and Ward 3 council member David Montgomery voted against issuing the permit to hold the annual event.
At the end of Monday's meeting, Gunsallus said he "(appreciated) the meaningful conversations with members of the community" and was "glad that everyone had a good time" at the festival.
Others spoke to express displeasure with the council's approval of the festival's permit.
Resident Gary Judy called out the council members who approved the festival's permit in January by a 3-2 vote — Maureen Curry, Don Abbatiello and the Rev. Elmer Davis. "You three will be remembered for opening this door," he said, adding that other groups may now have the ability to obtain festival permits.
Shari Wilcoxon, who wrote to the council in the winter asking for the festival to be held on West Street instead of South Harrison Street, called Monday evening for the council to be "apolitical."
"Would you fully support … a Moms for Liberty parade?" Wilcoxon asked. "Would you pay for banners?"
MONTGOMERY COMMENTS
Meanwhile, other meeting attendees addressed Montgomery's comments from the June 3 meeting, which included a claim of "danger to our community from promotion of (the) transexual ideology."
"By saying that Pride, the Pride flag or any section of our LGBT community is merely an ideology overlooks what the essence of Pride is: a celebration of human rights and the recognition of inherent dignity of all individuals regardless of their (sexual) orientation or gender identity," Mayor Megan Cook said at the outset of Monday's meeting.
Montgomery responded, saying he "did not appreciate being chastised" by Cook. The mayor said they will likely not ever "see eye-to-eye on social issues," but that she hopes everyone can keep an "open mind."
"What I'm trying to do is to be helpful to those who are being misled by what I think is clearly an ideology, and it's demonstrated by the way my comments were received last month," Montgomery said. "Shouting someone down in an effort of de-platforming simply proves we are dealing with an ideology and a political movement."
Jen Wagner, a St. Michaels resident who owns a business in Easton, took to the podium to call for the resignation of Gunsallus and Montgomery, to which the Town Council president said "that's too far."
"I will not prolong this debate tonight on facts or their interpretation," Montgomery said at the meeting's end. "I will object to personal attacks, which exclusively came from the audience directed in this direction."

St. Michaels Police Chief says salaries need to be raised for officer recruitment, retention

 September 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — During the St. Michaels Commissioners meeting on Wednesday, St. Michaels Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald said the police department will lose an 18-year veteran officer to another municipality. The officer, he said, is leaving for better pay."I'm coming up on my 24th year here, three as chief, and during this time, I've seen 43 officers come and go in our agency," Oswald said. "Obviously, there are several factors that contribute to some of the turnover, but the prominent and consistent driver from the exit interviews has been paying upward mobility."
Starting on Thursday, the St. Michaels Police Department will be operating with only four officers, excluding Oswald.
Oswald mentioned one of the reasons that officers leave besides salary is opportunities larger departments can provide.
"They have criminal investigation divisions, they have training divisions dedicated solely to ensure officers meet certifications, qualifications and criminal updates… and remember, each of these on their own is a full-time specially trained position," Oswald said. "... Every St. Michaels Police Department (officer) must be able to perform every one of these rules at any given time, and therefore, after a few years, an officer builds a strong resume and they take it to another agency who's more than happy to pay them some extra money."
Oswald suggested potentially hiring a police recruiting firm and raising wages commensurate to officers' total years of service.
"We're a good place to have an opportunity to do a reset because there's only four of us remaining," Oswald said.
According to Town Manager Don Richardson, the police department has four openings with two each at the corporal and sergeant level.
With potential salary raises, the cost would be north of $200,000 for the town to properly recruit and retain officers, Richardson said.
Commissioner Alexis Roiter mentioned accommodation taxes, which are paid by tourists who stay at hotels or rental properties, as a potential revenue source for police department needs. Commissioner David Wojciechowski mentioned allocating funds from town events.
The commissioners agreed to draft legislation allowing for salary amendments so the St. Michaels Police Department can become competitive in hiring and retention. The measure would have to go through the town's typical legislative process, which would include public hearings, before it can be adopted.
"Thank you for supporting this important need for the town of St. Michaels and our community," Richardson said. "It will ultimately require some level of budgeting amendment that will absolutely go through a public comment period and a legislative ordinance."
The town encourages anyone interested in joining the St. Michaels Police Department to contact the town for further instruction.

 STEVENSVILLE — Ensuring the joy of Christmas is spread throughout the Eastern Shore community, Tides of Grace once again welcomes the return of its signature Christmas Magic Toy Drive.This year's annual drive anticipates serving nearly 1,000 children and is currently collecting gently used toys for infants through teens. The drive serves as a perfect way to make room for new gifts this holiday season and show children the joy of giving, Leann Rhodes, Tides of Grace executive director, said.
Toys will be collected from drop off locations starting at midnight, Dec. 6 and volunteer elves will come out for an extravagant Christmas pajama party at The Edge Arena to sort and lay all the goodies across the 25,000 square-foot edge arena.
From 7 a.m. to 9:30 a.m. Dec. 7, Christmas magic will welcome registered parents to shop for free toys for children ages infant to 17.
This jolly big event is designed for parents only, with children left at home to maintain the element of surprise.
No income verification is required, but parents must register ahead of time.
This event takes a total of 200 volunteers from the community starting from midnight on Friday, Dec. 6 through the morning hours of Saturday, Dec. 7 to make it possible.
"It's really awesome to see the community come together in such a big way," Rhodes said.
The annual event began in 2020 with a group of moms wanting to spread holiday cheer, and it has grown tremendously over the years, from helping 100 children in 2020 to over 600 children in 2023, she said.
Donators are asked to ensure toys are in working condition and keep all parts together with a bag to prevent them from getting lost during sorting.
The drive is not accepting stuffed animals, used clothes, or books this year.
Drop off locations are located throughout the Eastern Shore with volunteers available to arrange pickups if donations can't be dropped off in person.
"Together, we can spread joy and ensure that every child in our community feels the love this holiday season," Rhodes said.
More information including child registration and drop off locations can be found at tidesofgraceinc.org/christmas-magic.

title: ShoreRivers to improve three community green spaces
content:
ShoreRivers to improve three community green spaces

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A8 | Section: News 
 
 411
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - Shore-Rivers-thanks to funding from the Chesapeake Bay Trust's Green Streets, Green Jobs and Green Towns (G3) Grant Program-is in the process of improving three community green spaces on the Eastern Shore.These spaces will be enhanced through the conversion of mowed lawn areas, or turf grass, into beautiful perennial wildflower meadows located at James T Wright Park in Preston, Oxford Cemetery, and the Presbyterian Church of Chestertown. At each community space, the established meadows will be highly visible and a welcome improvement to existing landscapes. They will also serve to educate the community on the benefits of river-friendly practices that function as native bird and pollinator habitat.The towns of Preston, Oxford, and Chestertown can expect to witness the various stages of turf to meadow conversion. Early in the process, residents and visitors should notice less green as the current vegetation is removed to make way for seed planting in late winter. During the first two years of establishment, periodic mowing will occur to help reduce intrusion from invasive species. Around year three, the meadow will be humming with insects pollinating the colorful, seasonal flowers. Each of these projects will take time to complete, but will provide countless benefits both aesthetically and to native plant and pollinator habitat, and for climate change resiliency.In 2017, ShoreRivers developed its River-Friendly Yards program to inspire and empower residents to become environmental stewards of their own properties through direct action such as reducing turf grass, eliminating lawn fertilizer, planting natives, installing rain gardens, and increasing buffers along rivers, creeks, and ditches. A River-Friendly Yard mimics the natural environment to benefit water quality, native birds and pollinators, and our local ecosystem. The program now encompasses River-Friendly campuses, congregations, communities, and roadsides.The G3 Program is funded by the United States Environmental Protection Agency Region III, West Virginia Department of Environmental Protection, and the Chesapeake Bay Trust, and supports the design and implementation of green streets, community greening, and urban tree canopy projects that enhance livability in cities and communities.In addition to funding the conversion of these meadows, the program is also providing funding for ShoreRivers to design multiple green infrastructure projects at St. Mary's Refuge ofSinners Church in Cambridge.

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council last week approved a bill allowing it to accept money from a statewide cannabis reinvestment fund, which currently has around $730,000 allocated for the county.Maryland's Cannabis Reform Act in 2023 created a Community Reinvestment and Repair Fund, designed to allocate 35% of the collected taxes from cannabis sales back into communities most affected by the disproportionate enforcement of previous cannabis laws.
County Attorney Patrick Thomas said at the council's meeting on Oct. 14 that the county can't use the money until it passed the bill, which effectively establishes Talbot's own reinvestment fund and a commission to administer the funds. Talbot Family Network, the board responsible for the county's youth and family services, will serve as the commission.
After the public hearing yielded no comments, the council moved the bill to third reading and approved it 4-0. Council member Lynn Mielke abstained.
The county must use the money for community-based initiatives, as defined by state law, such as after-school, behavioral health, housing or homeless prevention programs.

title: U.S. faces alarming 'problems without passports'
content:
U.S. faces alarming 'problems without passports'

 September 28, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 750
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - The man with the most interesting job in government receives a daily diet of information so potentially abundant, and often alarming, that it must challenge his phlegmatic disposition. William J. Burns, 67, the first career diplomat to serve as CIA director, is calm in the eye of the unending storm of international crises, which involves what he called, at a July conference in England, "problems without passports," including pandemics.Hostile potential uses of biotechnology, including engineered viruses, are, Burns thinks, "among the scariest things." Malign actors surely noticed the enormous self-inflicted costs - monetary and cultural - that U.S. policies imposed during the coronavirus pandemic. Cyber vulnerabilities suggest that destruction on a scale that used to be assigned to fleets of bombers can now be done with computer clicks: In 1995, a rogue trader for Barings Bank inadvertently destroyed the 233-year old institution.Imagine what can be done intentionally to physical (electric grids, communications systems, hospitals, etc.) as well as financial infrastructure.Oxford-educated and seasoned by foreign-policy immersion that began in the Reagan administration, Burns served as the ambassador to Moscow (2005-2008), where he got to know Vladimir Putin. In November 2021, when the U.S. intelligence community clearly saw Russia's preparations for invading Ukraine, Burns went to Moscow and spoke with Putin.The CIA director was alarmed when he went, and more so when he left Moscow convinced of Putin's "tragic and brutish fixation" on Ukraine, a fixation unaltered by "the clarity of our understanding of what he was planning." Putin's invasion has been, Burns says, a strategic blunder with Russia's "military weaknesses laid bare; its economy badly damaged for years to come; its future as a junior partner and economic colony of China being shaped by Putin's mistakes; its revanchist ambitions blunted by a NATO which has only grown bigger and stronger." Putin thought his window of opportunity regarding Ukraine was closing. Chinese President Xi Jinping, contemplating what he might think is an opening regarding the seizure of Taiwan, is surely watching what Burns calls Ukraine's "breathtaking determination and resolve" - and the possible weakening of U.S. support for Ukraine.On the CIA's leafy Northern Virginia campus, the agency has a large cadre of analysts debating whether, for example, the world has passed "peak China" - the apogee of China's might. Or whether there is any historical precedent for a rapid military buildup comparable to China's that has not been followed by war. A perennial intelligence problem is to decide how a nation's intentions can be inferred from the capabilities it develops.Today, the agency's remit extends to helping the Commerce Department understand the security implications of globalization's thick web of supply chains. We are, Burns says, in a "plastic moment," when much is in flux.Intelligence successes often are secret because they concern crises prevented, and/or because publicity would reveal espionage sources and methods. Known successes - e.g., Navy codebreakers turned the tide of the Pacific war in the battle of Midway during World War II - are fewer than the known failures (Pearl Harbor, Bay of Pigs, Iraq's nonexistent weapons of mass destruction). About the CIA's limited ability to explain itself, Burns is laconic: "It comes with the territory." Cambridge University historian Calder Walton, in his new book "Spies: The Epic Intelligence War Between East and West," says there was a time when "the CIA was so bereft of intelligence on China that it resorted to buying fish and chips in Hong Kong, to read the newspapers from the mainland they were wrapped in." In many ways, technology - "smart cities," facial recognition, people using smartphones - can make societies more transparent and more porous to outside influences.We are, Burns says, in a "profound transformation of espionage tradecraft": "We recently used social media - our first video post to Telegram, in fact - to let brave Russians know how to contact us safely on the dark web. We had 2.5 million views in the first week." There are and always will be, however, "secrets we need a human to collect, and clandestine operations that only a human can execute": "That requires intensive training, an intensive team effort to support operations, and immense creativity and appetite for risk. It still, however, remains central to our mission." This is good to know. It would be a loss to literature were the intelligence-gathering wonders wrought by technology to totally supplant the derring-do that made Eric Ambler and John le Carré possible.Reach George Will at georgewill@washpost.com.

title: Protection or pain? Disparate views of Trump's immigration crackdowns, deportations
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Protection or pain? Disparate views of Trump's immigration crackdowns, deportations

 April 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: National 
 
 1206
 Words 

 Read News Document

 President Donald Trump's immigration raids and promises of mass deportations of undocumented migrants are very much in the eye of the beholder.For Trump and his populist supporters the immigration crackdowns are about arresting and deporting dangerous gang members and migrants with criminal records.
"I have no problem rounding up hardened gang members and the illegal aliens that associate with them and deporting them immediately. Those in our country to do harm don't deserve to be here," said U.S. Rep. Ryan Zinke, R-Montana, in a recent social media statement.
U.S. Rep. Andy Harris, a Republican representing Maryland's Eastern Shore, also backs Trump's hardline approach. "It's time to deport all criminal illegal aliens to keep our communities safe," Harris said in a social media statement.
He points to the recent murder, rape and sexual assault conviction of Victor Martinez-Hernandez, a fugitive from El Salvador, in the 2023 killing of Rachel Morin, 37, in Hartford County.
"Rachel Morin would be here today had it not been for the dangerous wide-open border policies of the Biden administration," Harris said in a statement.
Trump's hardline immigration policies, which his backers hope include crackdowns on human trafficking, are among his most popular policies.
A recent CBS News Poll found 58% of U.S. voters back Trump's deportation efforts, while the same percentage opposes his tariffs push.
In the other corner, progressive groups, including some Christian organizations, worry about expulsions of refugees and asylum seekers and arrests of undocumented immigrants who are working in the U.S.
"Our faith calls us to stand with children and families fleeing violence and persecution, not to turn them away. These orders place vulnerable lives in danger and foster a culture of exclusion and fear," said Sandy Ovalle, senior director of campaigns and mobilizing for Sojourners, a Christian social justice group.
"We must act in solidarity with those who are suffering and continue to advocate for policies rooted in justice, mercy, and love," she said.
The Washington D.C.-based group also worries about potential Immigration & Customs Enforcement (ICE) actions impacting churches and schools.
"Serving migrant people is a religious liberty issue for many communities of faith. Relaxing the rules around immigration raids at sensitive locations like churches and schools makes it much more difficult for our houses of worship to serve as safe spaces for spiritual nourishment for all people, setting the stage for less safety and more trauma for everyone," Ovalle said.
The Sojourners group and Pope Francis have criticized Trump and other immigration hardliners for what they see as violations the biblical calls to welcome the stranger and to love thy neighbor.
A recent report by the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, the National Association of Evangelicals, World Relief and other groups said more than 10 million of the undocumented immigrants in the U.S. who could be deported are Christians.
"Eighty percent of immigrants vulnerable to deportation identify as Christians, with 61% being Catholic and 13% identifying as evangelical Christians," according to the report.
The same study found 77% of asylum seekers are Christians and close to 7 million U.S. citizens "live in households with someone at risk of deportation."
'BAD THIN
GS TO COME'
Karen Hunter sees Trump's immigration raids and deportations through her church's lens.
Hunter is a priest at Grace Episcopal Church in Nampa, Idaho. Her congregation and the church's community ministries have included undocumented persons.
She's seen deportations during past U.S. administrations and worried about the downstream ramifications during the post-pandemic migrations under the Biden administration.
"When the Biden administration opened the border, I knew it was the beginning of bad things to come," Hunter said, pointing to stagnant working class wages, affordable housing shortages and strained schools and social services.
The post-pandemic surges in migrations during the Biden administration included more than 8.6 million border patrol encounters with migrants at the Mexico border and more than 5.8 million asylum applications, according to the Migration Policy Institute.
Some of the migration surges came from conflict zones in Africa, the Middle East and South Asia. Other migrants, including from Haiti and Latin America, were escaping gangs, crime, religious persecution, poverty and extreme weather events such as natural disasters and droughts.
"I knew it would eventually result in deportations and that people who were living here peacefully and productively would end up getting caught up in deportations and an unwillingness of the general population to make ways for those who should have a way to stay," Hunter said.
She's worried about what's next under Trump, who has designated Latin American gangs and drug cartels as terrorists and has deported some alleged gang members to a prison in El Salvador.
"It is a painful thing to contemplate that some of our friends and members may face deportation," she said. "I know from experience that there will not be relief for undocumented folks once they are picked up."
Trump recently picked up a victory when the U.S. Supreme Court okayed his use of the 1798 wartime law the Alien Enemies Act to deport Venezuelan gang members to a prison in El Salvador.
The Trump camp has also criticized federal judges blocking the administration's immigration crackdowns.
"President Trump has made it his number-one priority to secure the border, defeat the cartels, and remove criminal aliens from American communities," said Chad Wolf, homeland security chair for the pro-Trump America First Policy Institute.
"The Trump administration has rightly indicated that they will use any legal authority available to protect Americans. Unfortunately, in recent weeks, partisan judges have repeatedly attempted to usurp the lawful power of the presidency to identify and remove terrorist organizations from our streets," said Wolf, who served in the first Trump administration.
The U.S. administration has also curtailed refugee and asylum programs and is also embroiled in fights over its attempts to revoke student visas and deport foreign students it has deemed supportive of Islamic militant groups in pro-Palestinian protests against U.S. military support for Israel and the post-Oct. 7 war in Gaza.
U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen, D-Maryland, traveled to El Salvador to visit Kilmar Abrego Garcia. The Salvadoran migrant, who lives in Maryland, was deported by the Trump administration, is being held in an El Salvador prison and there is a legal fight over bringing Garcia back to the U.S.
"The Trump (administration) can lie all they want, but the court said they failed to show he was part of MS-13. This is about bringing home a man they admit should've never been abducted. I won't rest until then," said Van Hollen, referring to the notorious Salvadoran gang and court rulings calling for Garcia to be returned to the U.S.
Trump called Van Hollen "a fool" and "grandstander" over the visit. Harris and other Trump backers argue Democrats and progressives seem to care more gang members illegally in the U.S. than the victims of their crime, including human trafficking.
In Idaho, Hunter is frustrated with the situation undocumented migrants face and how they are viewed and treated by both sides.
"They become a kind of slaves. They have to put up with low wages and bad housing," she said.
"Even those in the media who seem to be advocating for undocumented people refer to them as the people who clean the houses and cut the grass or work in the fields. They do the work Americans won't do, they say. It's a short step from that thinking to 'they are here to serve us, to do our dirty work'," she said.

 FEDERALSBURG — The Federalsburg Judy Center Hub celebrated 25 years of operation this month.According to Caroline County Public Schools, The Judy Center Early Learning Hub at Federalsburg Elementary School's goal is to "promote school readiness through collaboration with community-based agencies and organizations. Through these partnerships, the Judy Centers are able to provide a full range of early intervention and comprehensive services within the school and center."
The center offers multiple avenues of help and learning for Federalsburg residents ages 5 and younger.
"When we talk about working with those families and children, we offer play groups and our services always have a parent and a child component," said Heather Harding, Federalsburg Judy Center Early Learning Hub coordinator. "It's always a family caregiver and the child together. So we offer play groups throughout the week, we offer family engagements, we offer parent training and that may take on different forms… We service the whole family so it's whatever the family determines their needs are, and it is a strength-based program."
The celebration of 25 years featured an event with activities for children and families. The Judy Center created a timeline walkthrough for the last 25 years and invited all previous employees from the 25 years to participate.
"It was really important for us that when we plan the celebration that we took it back to the focus of the Judy Center work, which is family," Elizabeth Saylor, supervisor of instruction, said.
"So, we did a big family event, so the kids had something fun to do, and the families had something fun to do, and then we did all those the traditional ceremonial things too…We invited all previous employees to come back as well. So, it truly was as current families, family families, but then definitely our work family as well."
Staff said the impact was the best reward for all the hard work.
"I absolutely love my job with the Judy Center, and I was here previously, when we also worked as an Early Head Start under the direction of Ms. Tearesa French," Harding said. "She was the supervisor for 22 years of it. The impact that the work has made on everyone, it was never just one person. It's always been a collective. title: Global warming seen in Dorchester County forests
author: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service
content:
Global warming seen in Dorchester County forests

 July 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service | Section: Local News 
 
 1074
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The oak trees on Mike Tidwell's street in Montgomery County are dying, so he wrote a book about it."In the last few years, I just have become very conscious of the fact that our biggest trees in Takoma Park were dying," said Tidwell, founder and director of the Chesapeake Climate Action Network. "I read in the city newsletter and heard from arborists that this mass tree mortality was linked to extreme weather, triggered by climate change. I thought that was sad and amazing."
Tidwell's new book, "The Lost Trees of Willow Avenue," looks beyond Takoma Park. It examines extreme weather events and climate change happening across the state. And other experts agree that the impact is vast, including on the Eastern Shore, where more dead trees can be found in the "ghost forests" of Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge.
These things are happening because temperatures in Maryland have never been warmer.
Since the 20th century, temperatures in the state have risen around 2.5 degrees Fahrenheit, according to the National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration. But it's more than just heat. Federal data shows the state is experiencing increasing precipitation, a higher probability of summer droughts, more extreme weather events and flooding accompanied with rising sea levels.
The impact of climate change on the state is as varied as its landscape. From vast forests and rolling farms that line the Eastern Shore to the 80.9 square miles of Baltimore City scattered with heat islands, different areas of the state will be affected by climate change in vastly different ways.
To hear Tidwell and other environmental experts tell it, the state's poorest communities will face the greatest climate challenges. Communities on the Eastern Shore — where farmlands are becoming wetlands — and Baltimore's city neighborhoods are at particular risk.
"There are certain communities, especially marginalized communities that won't have the resources to adapt," Tidwell said. "We just have to stabilize the climate before we face those truly nightmarish impacts."
The changes Maryland is likely to face are detailed in the federal government's fifth National Climate Assessment — but the Trump administration deleted all that data from the internet on June 30. However, the Local News Network at the University of Maryland's Philip Merrill College of Journalism downloaded all that data months ago and used it as the basis of this story and the accompanying county summaries.
Here's a closer look at what's happening to the climate, and what's expected to happen, across the state:
EASTERN SHOREThe remnants of Harriett Tubman's birth home sit in a dying forest in Dorchester County.
"They found the original foundations of her home and you now can't even get there because it's in the middle of a ghost forest," said Kate Tully, a researcher and associate professor at the University of Maryland College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.
Ghost forests — which are either partially or completely dead — can be found throughout the lower Eastern Shore in Dorchester, Somerset, Worcester and Wicomico counties. These ghost forests result from saltwater intrusion, or what Tully refers to as "invisible floods," where seawater creeps inland as temperatures and waters rise.
"That's essentially when the salt burns the tree from the inside out," Tully said.
High tides, droughts and groundwater pumping all contribute to this increasingly common phenomenon. Eventually, land plagued by saltwater intrusion turns into either marshland or open water.
As a result, Tubman's home — only discovered just a few years ago in the Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge — is now inaccessible.
In the lower Eastern Shore, there are over 70,000 acres of forest classified by the state as ghost forests, with 90% of those acres classified as severely or very severely impacted. For a forest to fall under these classifications, at least half of its trees would be dead.
But saltwater intrusion isn't just killing forests.
"There are farmers that are being highly impacted by the saltwater intrusion and the loss of productivity of their land," said Elliott Campbell, director of the science and research division of the Watershed and Climate Services at Maryland's Department of Natural Resources.. "There's not really a way to, like, get the salt out."
Farms along the Eastern Shore, including northern counties such as Cecil, Kent, Talbot and Caroline, are known for growing corn and soybeans, used primarily to feed livestock, Campbell said. But these crops don't grow well in salty soil, and Campbell said there is no perfect alternative.
While there are vulnerable farms throughout the entire shore, Tully said Black communities in the lower Eastern Shore are being disproportionately impacted by saltwater intrusion.
"We've already lost so many Black farms in Black communities on the Eastern Shore," Tully said. "There's actually a whole history that's already gone underwater that we will never get back."
In the Antebellum period, the lower Eastern Shore became home to many free Black people escaping slavery from Virginia and other Southern states. The tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay helped provide a living for many formerly enslaved people. But Tully said these communities — and their deep-rooted history — will disappear soon if they're not already underwater.
The Chesapeake Bay region is the United States' third-most vulnerable area to sea level rise behind Louisiana and South Florida, according to NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information.
Because the low-lying, largely flat area is so vulnerable, the effects of an increasing climate are much more intense than in other parts of the state. The Chesapeake Bay has already risen from 1.3 to 1.5 inches each decade over the past 100 years, and increasing temperatures would drastically increase precipitation.
The land isn't the only thing vulnerable to climate change. Throughout the entire Eastern Shore, the fishing industry is changing.
"One very clear example is that we never had a shrimp industry in the state until the last couple years," Campbell said.
Campbell also said blue crabs populations, which do well in warmer waters, will thrive. But the effects on the bay aren't all positive.
Warmer waters will kill fish at an increasing rate, Campbell said. Similarly, an increase in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere increases the acidity in the ocean water, which can deplete oyster populations.
As for the Eastern Shore's farmland and ghost forests, Campbell said the best case for this land experiencing saltwater intrusion is for it to transition into wetlands. The state has a pilot program to help farmers with that transition.
"In some cases, you see marshes forming under those forests," Campbell said. "But in some cases, they eventually will transition to just open water and you lose that ecosystem."
Capital News Service reporter Rachel McCrea contributed to this report.

title: Ethics standards are good decision for Court
content:
Ethics standards are good decision for Court

 August 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Those who suspect that Justice Samuel Alito views the Supreme Court as some imperial Star Chamber that is unaccountable to Congress, the public or anyone else have recently gained a powerful new ally in that theory: Alito himself.In a recent interview with The Wall Street Journal's opinion section, Alito lashes out at the growing consensus that Congress should impose mandatory ethics standards on the justices, considering they refuse to do it themselves."No provision in the Constitution gives them the authority to regulate the Supreme Court," he says. "Period." Legal scholars and others have pounced on the assertion as just plain wrong, constitutionally. It's also a distressing confirmation of the anti-democratic instincts of a man who, with his fellow court conservatives, has lately wielded his unelected power in precedent-breaking, culture-transforming ways - regarding abortion rights in particular - that would never pass muster at the polling place.That comes against a backdrop of ethics concerns that have undermined the court's credibility lately, involving justices from both sides of its deep ideological divide.The details vary: Justices Clarence Thomas has accepted luxury trips and other perks from a prominent Republican donor; Justice Neil Gorsuch made a big real estate sale to a lawyer whose firm has business before the court; Justice Sonia Sotomayor's staff has prodded public institutions to buy her memoir.The justices for the most part have responded to the mini-scandals, if at all, by denying wrongdoing and/or saying they will be more careful going forward.Alito had a different approach when ProPublica was preparing to report in June that he had accepted private jet travel to a luxury fishing trip from a politically active billionaire: He preempted the story with a defiant Wall Street Journal op-ed making the tonedeaf argument that he had saved the taxpayers travel-security expenses by accepting the private ride.He insisted he technically had no legal obligation to disclose the trip, nor to recuse himself from cases before the court in which the billionaire was involved.The latter assertions are true, and that's the problem. Unlike every other judge in America, the court's nine justices aren't bound by a mandatory set of ethics standards regarding conflicts of interest and recusal.They have long asserted that they adhere to such standards voluntarily, so there is no need to officially impose them. For an answer to that assertion, re-read the preceding paragraphs.The issue has prompted movement in Congress to impose mandatory new ethics standards on the justices. Which in turn prompted Alito's claim, in the extensive Wall Street Journal interview, that the court is effectively untouchable by anybody. (One of the two writers of the coddling opinion piece, it discloses, is an attorney with a case pending before the court. You can't make this stuff up.)At first half-blush, it might make sense - surely the high court must be utterly independent from Congress to function, right? - but that ignores the entire concept of constitutional checks and balances between the three branches of government. The whole point of that concept is that no single branch holds unfettered power of the kind Alito appears to claim.As numerous legal scholars and other critics have pointed out in response to Alito's comments, Congress already requires financial disclosure of gifts and stock transactions from the justices.Congress also determines the size of the court, its budget (including the justices' pay), the dates of its sessions and other basic structural issues.Congress similarly imposes ethics standards, budgetary control and other power over the executive branch; the president, meanwhile, can veto actions of Congress. Alito hasn't questioned these and other checks and balances between the other two branches of government. It's only his own branch, apparently, that is untouchable.It's not. Congress should be cautious about overstepping its authority regarding the court, but mandatory ethics standards of the kind that govern other judges would be constitutionally defensible and could help restore public confidence in the court.If Alito is concerned that it would threaten a creeping loss of judicial independence, he should champion a move for the court to self-impose those standards.REPRINTED FROM THE ST. title: Oyster restoration in Chesapeake Bay meeting expectations
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Oyster restoration in Chesapeake Bay meeting expectations

 June 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Environment 
 
 343
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Oyster restoration and protection in the Chesapeake Bay is on the right track thanks to a decade-long effort by the Chesapeake Bay Program and surrounding nonprofits.The EPA program announced Thursday that eight of 10 tributaries have completed restoration expectations. It also said all 10 are on track to complete the restoration goals by 2025, which was the original target year.
The effort to restore the oyster populations stems from a 2014 Chesapeake Bay Watershed Agreement, which aimed to restore the bay and its surrounding waters.
All 10 of the tributaries were given a target number of healthy reef acres to reach. A 2023 restoration update showed that eight tributaries had hit the target of healthy acreage, which includes pre-existing reefs and recently restored ones.
The Manokin River in Maryland is less than halfway complete, with 222 acres of reef restoration remaining of the target 441. Virginia's Lynnhaven River is 38 more acres away from reaching its target of 152 healthy acres.
Allison Colden, the Maryland executive director of the nonprofit Chesapeake Bay Foundation, applauded the progress and vouched for continued oyster restoration in the bay.
"It's critically important to build on the success of these oyster restoration projects and maintain momentum by expanding these initiatives to more tributaries in Maryland and Virginia," Colden said in a press release. "Restored oyster reefs support a healthy Chesapeake Bay, numerous economic opportunities, and strengthen our resilience to climate change for communities across the Bay watershed."
Oyster protection has been a long-running debate at the state and local levels.
In March, State Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) introduced SB922, a bill repealing previous requirements that prevented the Maryland Department of Natural Resources "from taking any action to reduce or alter the boundaries of certain oyster sanctuaries."
According to previous Star Democrat reporting, watermen supported the bill at the time, which would allow harvesting in those oyster sanctuaries. Many conservation leaders and DNR officials, though, did not.
As the bill made its way through the House and Senate and was amended, there was little pushback. In May, it was signed by Gov. Wes Moore.

title: Competitive eaters throw down at Cult Classic
author: ERIC SYLVIA Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Competitive eaters throw down at Cult Classic

 February 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ERIC SYLVIA Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 769
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — "There's not much else to do on a cold February Saturday — football's over, NASCAR hasn't started and March Madness is still a couple of weeks away," quipped Rohry Flood, owner of Cult Classic Brewing on Kent Island."That's why this event is a perfect way to spend the day," Keith Graffius, organizer of the 14th annual Crawfish Boil and Muskrat Leg Eating Contest held Feb. 17, said.
Graffius has run the event since the beginning, and he says it has grown year over year to its current size. The 2024 event saw more than 1,000 spectators, all eager to witness the competition.
The eating contest didn't kick off until 5:30 p.m., but by noon the taproom floor was already crowded, karaoke was being sung in the listening room, local merchants were selling their wares at one end of the taproom and the food tent was pumping out crawfish and muskrat themed dishes.
The food was provided by Palm Beach Willies, a local favorite in Taylors Island. Willies chef John Butz and his team cranked out quesadillas, spring rolls, muskrat barbecue and steamed crawdads. The line for food was steady, with many of those in line looking to try the signature dish, muskrat, for the first time.
Graffius explained, "We started this event as an add on to the Dorchester County Outdoor Show, but over the years we have outgrown the various venues we've used for past events. Bringing this event to Cult Classic was a perfect way to continue the tradition and provide a premiere event."
Flood added, "Some of the proceeds will go to the Waterman's Association, while others will be used to support a new scholarship fund." The new scholarship fund was set up in the name of Ralph "Peg Leg" Bramble, a two time champion and hall-of-famer who was always a fixture at this event as well as the Outdoor Show. "He did so much to keep these traditions alive — traditions that are at the heart and history of Dorchester County," Graffius said.
Bramble passed the baton and his crown to the 2023 and 2022 world champion, Daniel "Chunky" Hesson. Hesson, a 17-year-old Dorchester native, will be attending Salisbury State next fall.
He has been participating in the event since he was twelve and says Bramble was a mentor. Wearing a t-shirt with a picture of the two of them from a past competition on the front, Hesson said, "Ralph always watched over me during these events, since I am usually one of the youngest competitors."
When asked about the tie-in with crawdads, Graffius explained it is linked to Cameron Parrish, Louisiana that plays host to a similar annual event, the Louisiana Fur and Wildlife Festival. Guests from Cameron Parish made the trek to Dorchester County this weekend for the National Outdoor Show in Church Creek to help crown Miss Outdoors and observe the muskrat skinning semi-finals.
The afternoon saw a steady increase in spectators. The listening room of Cult Classic transitioned into the un-official Blues Emporium of Kent Island as DC Blues legend Jimmy Cole and his Delmarva All-stars took the stage.
The band features a who's-who of blues music, including Ron Holloway on tenor sax, Sam Paladino on the Hammond organ, George Sheppard on drums, Bryan Smith on bass and Jimmy Stepanson on lead guitar.
By 5 p.m. the room was filled to capacity, and the anticipation was palpable as the nine contestants took the stage, one by one. The contestants included Hesson, as well as past competitor Mike Detmer, also of Dorchester County, and several first timers, some of whom had never had muskrat before.
Detmer is known from past contests as "Dirty Legs" Detmer, due to the amount of meat he has been known to leave on the bones during the contest.
As he took the stage for the finale, he stripped off his camo jacket to reveal a gold sequin shirt, which turned out to be somewhat prophetic, as Detmer would go on to win the event by a tenth of a pound over Hesson.
Detmer paid tribute to his fellow competitors, "The rest of the competition is great — they are truly champions and I am surprised I won," he said.
As the event concluded, Detmer accepted the trophy from Flood and Graffius, amid calls for a re-test from Hesson's supporters. First-time entrant Cody Fenzel from Millersville rounded out the top three.
Graffius is hoping to bring the event back to Cult Classic for the 2025 edition. Flood said they were "psyched" to be hosting this year's event.
"It's a perfect partnership between the weird and wonderful things we love about where we live and the crazy creativity of our neighbors," he said.

 An art exhibit at the Academy Art Museum in Easton featuring the work of Hoesy Corona wraps up Sunday, Sept. 10."Corona's work highlights the complex relationship between humans and the environment by focusing on our changing climate and its impact on habitation and migration patterns. Using the archetype of the traveler, who is seen holding suitcases and voyaging through a wide array of landscapes towards a better place, Corona tackles the reality of the human aspect of climate change while celebrating the lushness and vibrancy of flora, bodies of water, and geographic forms, and bringing attention to the multitudinous powers of nature," according to AAM's summary of the exhibit."The artist transformed the Museum's Saul Atrium Gallery with site-specific vignettes that each picture a character journeying from a land made uninhabitable by global warming.
