title: 'Teamwork makes the dreamwork' for Kent kayakers
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Teamwork makes the dreamwork' for Kent kayakers

 August 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 463
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Due to the dock collapse at the Washington College boathouse during Tea Party weekend (May 23–25), the Maryland Special Olympics Kayaking Championship could not be held in Kent County as in previous years.While the event moved to Crisfield, the Kent County team hosted its own local competition Saturday, giving athletes a chance to paddle 150- or 500-meter races and celebrate their achievements.
Traveling to Crisfield was not feasible for all athletes.
"Traveling two-and-a-half hours was not convenient for some of the athletes," Coach Jenny Lee Freebery said.
Despite fewer competitors, the day was full of enthusiasm and achievement. Awards were handed out, and the event concluded with a special lunch honoring the athletes. Head coaches Freebery and 1972 Olympian Jack Brosius, assistant coaches Danielle Cudone and Anne Scott, as well as Ricky Freebery and parents, helped run the event.
Opening ceremonies began at the Washington College boathouse with Kent paddlers. Scott Kuster played "The Star-Spangled Banner" on his baritone horn, followed by the Pledge of Allegiance from newcomer Thos Stevenson. Brian Tate recited the athletes' oath before the competitions began.
Athletes adjusted to conditions after being unable to use the docks. Freebery, the only coach allowed on the dock, provided a recap of the racing. Competitors included McKenzie Weaver (150 meters, first season kayaking in a tandem with Cudone), Nick Gaorfal (150), Thos Stevenson (150, tandem with support staff Courtney Phelps), Woody Glenn Jr. (500, tandem with his father Woody Glenn Sr.), Chris Dooley (500), Tom Rickloff (500), Brian Tate (500), Robin Baker (500), and Scott Kuster (500).
Team members who did not compete this year due to schedule conflicts included Allison Bedell, Andrew Jackson, and Palmer Hopwood.
Freebery praised the athletes' dedication despite a challenging season.
"I'm so proud of our team. This year had a lot of challenges; the dock broke right before our season started, so we weren't able to use the beach for many practices. Then we had so many days with heat indexes over 100 degrees or thunderstorms on the horizon that kept us off the water," she said.
On Saturday, the paddlers persevered, showing determination and teamwork.
"Everyone put in such great effort and was very adaptable. It was rewarding watching our new paddlers go from never having been in a kayak before to racing down the Chester," Freebery said.
She also highlighted the camaraderie among athletes.
"Practices are always fun, with the athletes cheering each other on, helping carry boats, and pushing one another to do their best," she said.
The team hopes to host the Maryland championships again next year and is seeking more volunteers and Special Olympics paddlers for next summer. They also launched a campaign to acquire new boats and paddles. To support their cause, visit support.somd.org/team/755145.
Brian Tate, reflecting on the team's spirit, offered a possible motto:
"Teamwork makes the dream work," he said.

title: Sabres finish strong on way to crown
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Sabres finish strong on way to crown

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 767
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Keely Morgan's goal just 2 seconds before halftime put the home team in front.But it was Eden Zimmerman's goal off Avery McCall's beautiful corner kick that put Saints Peter and Paul High's girls soccer team finally in control.
That score gave the top-seeded Sabres an infusion of confidence Friday en route to a 4-1 victory over Gunston in the Eastern Shore Independent Athletic Conference championship.
"It feels amazing," said McCall, a junior midfielder, who has now been a part of conference title teams in soccer, basketball and lacrosse. "This is a very special team."
A team that had been bounced in the first round of the ESIAC postseason the past two years. A team that went undefeated in conference play this season and came in as the No. 1 seed. And a team that won its first ESIAC championship since 2019.
But the Sabres (10-3) were consistently beaten to the ball by the Herons (6-5-1) in the first half, and halfway through the second half.
"We were definitely dominant in the first half and the first 20 minutes of the second half," Gunston head coach Tony D'Antonio said. "And then it was pretty even after that. They found the net and we didn't."
Sts. Peter & Paul found the net in the 8th minute, when Emery Zimmerman parked a direct kick into the right side of the net for a 1-0 lead.
Gunston got a pair of corner kicks in the 18th minute, the first skidding through the crease but finding no one on the other end. Sabres keeper Kaylin Palmer made a save on a direct kick with 13:30 left in the first half.
The Herons then put together a flurry off a corner with 5 minutes remaining before the break. A corner kick sailed over the Palmer's outstretched fingers and through the crease. Gunston kept possession, striking a ball that hit one of its own players before sending a shot over the crossbar.
Then with 2:04 left before halftime, Ellie Roberts sent a drive from about 25 yards out that nestled into the far right corner for a 1-1 tie.
"It's hard to beat a team three times," McCall said of the Sabres' two regular-season wins over Gunston. "But I think we were mostly in panic mode. They (Gunston) always come out really fast and we're normally a second-half team. So we were very defensive and I think that's what saved us. And then eventually we got the offense together and it all came together."
Sts. Peter & Paul got a huge boost just 2 seconds before halftime when Morgan got a ball and tucked it inside the left post for a 2-1 halftime lead.
"It was absolutely huge," Sabres head coach Nicole Edsall said of Morgan's goal.
Sophomore Emery Zimmerman agreed.
"I think that was essential because it really just got us going," Emery Zimmerman said. "It (made us) realize, 'OK, we need to win this. We want to win this. This is ours. We came all this way undefeated (in conference play). This is the time that we need to come out and score.
"When they caught up to us and we got back up one more like right off the bat, it really got us going," Emery Zimmerman continued. "Gave us a lot of enthusiasm and momentum."
But not right away.
"They definitely had jitters in the first half," Edsall said of her team. "And when we talked at halftime I said, 'I know this isn't the team that we are. So just kind of brush it off. Let it go. Start the half over and let's play our game.'"
Play evened out midway through the second half. Then with 8:42 left, McCall bent a corner that plopped right in front of Eden Zimmerman, who tapped it in for a 3-1 lead.
"I've been struggling on my corners all season," McCall said. "I usually just boot it and hope. Eden is always everywhere and she just found it. It got the curve that it needed and she was just there for it. We've always been a team that struggles to like get it in (on corners). It's always gone right through. But she was just right there where she needed to be."
Less than 2 minutes later, the Sabres spilled into the box before Kendall Kroniser gained possession, spun away from a defender and drilled in a fourth goal.
"I'm sure it's great for the seniors," Emery Zimmerman said. "I'm happy for them. I feel over the last year nobody leaving (through graduation) and through this year, we really built up on our skills and built great team chemistry. And this is what happens when you work hard at practice."

title: Bridge - Deception by deduction
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Deception by deduction

 December 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A7 | Section: News

 Read News Document

 John Ruskin, who was an English art critic, discussed painters when he wrote, "The essence of lying is in deception, not in words." In bridge, sometimes you lie in words when you make, for example, a psychic bid.During the play, sometimes you lie by false carding. In today's deal, a defender fooled declarer by dropping an unnecessarily high card. However, it helped that he had calculated his "generosity" couldn't cost a trick.
In four hearts, declarer won the first trick with his club ace and cashed the heart ace, "dropping" West's queen.
Worried that East had four trumps, South immediately ran the diamond 10. East kept up the good defense, ducking his king. Suddenly fooled, South repeated the diamond finesse, but East won with the king and gave his partner a diamond ruff.
West cashed the club queen, and the heart jack was the fourth defensive trick.
Cool - but how did West know he could afford to play the heart queen? Well, if South had started with A-Jx-x of hearts, he would have played a heart to dummy's king and taken the trump finesse. So, when South started with the heart ace, East was marked with the jack. Dropping the queen was safe. Also, it couldn't mislead East, because South was marked with four hearts from the auction. (If South had opened one no-trump with five hearts, he would have drawn two rounds of trumps before taking the diamond finesse.)
However, remember, when trying a deceptive defense, be careful not to deceive your partner more than declarer.

title: 'Proven leader': Easton will soon welcome Kitzrow as new town manager
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Proven leader': Easton will soon welcome Kitzrow as new town manager

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 740
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After nearly a year without a permanent town manager, Easton will welcome Andy Kitzrow next month.Kitzrow, the current Salisbury city administrator, was tapped by Mayor Megan Cook to assume the post from Police Chief Alan Lowrey, the interim town manager since August. Kitzrow begins July 7.
During an interview in Salisbury last week, Kitzrow said he instantly noticed opportunity in Easton.
"The more I looked at Easton, the more I started to fall in love with where they're going," Kitzrow said.
The new town manager is Cook's most major appointment in her two years as mayor. Kitzrow will oversee town operations, lead department heads and town staff, and be a point of contact with the mayor and Town Council members.
After whittling down a list of around 12 semifinalists, the town conducted full-day interviews with four finalists. It was an intensive but worthwhile process, Cook said.
She felt Kitzrow rose above the others, as he was up to speed on what's happening in Easton and meshed well with her and with town employees.
"(Staff) really thought of the candidates, he could get up and running the fastest because he had the background of Maryland politics," Cook said.
Kitzrow, 42, served as Wicomico County recreation superintendent before becoming Salisbury's deputy city administrator in 2017 and city administrator in 2023.
In Salisbury, Kitzrow worked under three different mayors, including Jake Day, now the Department of Housing and Community Development secretary. Day noted Kitzrow's oversight of city permit and procurement operations as especially impactful.
"It's not easy work, but he's a proven leader," Day said of Kitzrow. "Somebody who can do it."
Cook says while the Day connection didn't factor into her decision, it will benefit Easton as the town tackles its own housing challenges and initiatives.
"Having that relationship, I think, is great. It's key," Kitzrow said. "A lot of this is about relationships, whether they are elected officials or state officials."
A BETTER FIT
Working under three different mayors, Kitzrow says he's experienced three very different visions.
In early 2023, Day left Salisbury with then-city administrator Julia Glanz to head up the state's housing and community development efforts. Jack Heath served as mayor until current Mayor Randy Taylor won an election later that year.
During Day's tenure, Salisbury undertook a number of efforts to redevelop its downtown through programs providing tax incentives to developers, such as "Here is Home" and HORIZON — the latter aimed at bringing multifamily residential and hotel units, an initiative which Kitzrow championed.
"(He was) the mastermind behind the HORIZON legislation that we passed locally," Glanz said.
Taylor and developers have clashed in recent months over the stalling of downtown projects, some of which were approved by former mayors and councils. In April, DelmarvaNow.com reported that developers of a downtown project filed a $40 million lawsuit against Salisbury and Taylor.
While Kitzrow believes the change in vision is OK and can be solved through compromise, he acknowledges it factored into his choice to accept the Easton post. Neither Taylor nor Heath could be reached for an interview.
"Professionally and personally, the town that Megan wants to run and her goals align more with what I value and what I want to be part of," Kitzrow said.
GOALS IN EASTON
Salisbury's population is nearly double Easton's, but Kitzrow sees similar challenges and opportunities in the two areas.
He said he wants to "move projects forward in a smart way." In Salisbury, he's dealt with a housing pipeline of around 5,000 units and led a focus on building "from the inside out." Easton's pipeline has recently hovered around 1,000 units.
Kitzrow is hoping to bring a focus to Easton's Rails to Trails network, given his parks and recreation background, as well as get "under the hood" in the human resources department.
Cook said she's excited to bring on a consistent leader during what she says has been a year full of change in town. "I'm looking forward to a steady ship ... and some calm seas ahead," Cook said.
Working for the mayor, Kitzrow emphasized that strong relationships with the Town Council will be crucial in completing the work that will make Easton a better place.
"We are working together, not against each other, and I think that's important," Kitzrow said.
Kitzrow will remain living in Salisbury with his wife and kids. He owns Escape Salisbury, a downtown escape room business.
But he's looking to learn as much about Easton as possible. He said he's especially excited to meet business owners, nonprofit leaders and community members in his first 60 days on the job.

author: Maggie Trovato

Plea hearing is scheduled for Rider case

 June 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime

 EASTON — Fred "Trey" Rider III is planning to enter a plea deal in August rather than standing trial for charges related to a fire at his home on Peach Orchard Road in Easton.At a virtual status hearing Tuesday, Judge Thomas G. Ross scheduled a plea hearing for Aug. 19, the first day of when Rider's trial was supposed to begin, and a sentencing hearing for October.
Rider is accused of setting his house on fire in November 2022.
Through investigation, officials identified the fire as an act of human intervention with an open flame, classifying the cause of fire as incendiary. According to court documents, Rider's reckless conduct in igniting the house on fire "clearly" put more than 45 firefighters who responded in danger as they suppressed the fire.
At the status hearing Tuesday, Talbot County Assistant State's Attorney Jennifer Wilson said Rider plans to plead guilty to first-degree arson and five counts of reckless endangerment. She said the state plans to enter nolle prosequi for Rider's remaining nine charges, meaning the state will not prosecute for those charges.
Rider's attorney Christine DuFour, who took over from attorney Stephanie Shipley in April, said Rider's divorce proceedings with Kari Rider are happening parallel to this case. She said it would be helpful to know the outcome of the divorce before Rider is handed a sentence because the divorce will have an affect on the sentencing.
The sentencing was scheduled for Oct. 4, a little over a week after the final hearing in Rider's divorce process.
Wilson said the state is not opposed to Rider being handed suspended consecutive sentences for the reckless endangerment counts. DuFour said the state could seek restitution in the plea agreement, but that has not been determined.
Rider was supposed to stand trial March 4, but at a status hearing that morning, Ross said Rider had been voluntarily admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital and issued a bench warrant for Rider's failure to appear in court that morning. After getting discharged, Rider was granted a request to be transferred to an alcohol and drug rehab facility for 60 days, with the condition that he return to the Talbot County Detention Center upon completing the program.
On May 14, the detention center was ordered to release Rider on a previously posted $20,000 unsecured bond. Rider was released on conditions including that he surrender his passport, he reside in a sober living home in Pasadena, he attend Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings and he enroll in mental health services.
This report has been updated from an earlier version to clarify the state's opinion on Rider potentially receiving suspended consecutive sentences.

title: Easton planners: amid affordable housing shortage, inclusionary zoning may be useful
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton planners: amid affordable housing shortage, inclusionary zoning may be useful

 January 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 1134
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Through her work at the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, Daisy Aguilar interacts with many prospective first-time homebuyers. Of the many challenges they face, housing prices in Easton and Talbot County are at the top of the list."The houses, they're not affordable right now," Aguilar, the center's housing coordinator, said. "And most people that are buying, they're buying in Dorchester County because it's more affordable than it is in Talbot County."
An inclusionary zoning ordinance in the works could pave the way for more affordable homeownership and rental opportunities in Easton. It would require residential developers to allocate 15% of their units as affordable, defined separately for ownership and rental.
Inclusionary units in ownership developments would need to meet an affordable price for households making up to 100% of area median income, while rental developments would need to meet prices affordable for households making up to 60% of area median income.
According to Jim Bent, chair of the Affordable Housing Board, Easton's area median income was around $98,000 last year.
While similar legislation has faced hurdles in the past, town leaders and affordable housing proponents are hopeful the time is now for inclusionary zoning to be implemented.
EASTON'S WORKFORCEEaston Mayor Megan Cook is well aware of the fact many can't afford to live in town, including essential workers, town employees and police officers.
"When you're sworn to protect and serve a community, yet you can't even live in the community that you're dedicating your life to, that says something," Cook said. "That's not quite the message we should be sending people."
According to the draft ordinance, Census data shows that 42% of around 17,000 Talbot County workers commute into the county. Cook and others are hoping the ordinance can lower that percentage.
"A lot of the people who work in those fields earn wages where they have been priced out of the Easton market, and so their only option is to find housing in adjacent counties," said Miguel Salinas, Easton's director of planning and zoning.
For homebuyers, the local market is a significant challenge. According to the Mid-Shore Board of Realtors, the average home price in Talbot County in 2024 was $856,000.
Town staff's calculation of the maximum affordable home price for a family of four making the area median income is $292,000.
"There was a time, a couple years, not too long ago, that houses were affordable," Aguilar said. "I mean, they were selling fast, but they were affordable. And at least you had the possibility of actually getting a house."
THE ORDINANCESalinas, who has led the town's efforts to create the ordinance, recognizes it is just one piece of the puzzle. But it's a critical step, he said.
"This is one tool in the toolbox. And it's been discussed for 20-plus years," Salinas said.
Since it was initially presented in February 2023, Salinas said the ordinance has endured many revisions, along with being viewed by the town's Affordable Housing Board, Attainable Housing Task Force and an outside contractor.
Town planners looked at similar provisions in jurisdictions such as Queen Anne's County, Annapolis and Frederick when drafting the ordinance.
A draft version of the inclusionary housing ordinance was passed 4-1 by the town's Planning Commission last November.
Planning Commission member Michael Ports, speaking for himself and not the commission, said the inclusionary zoning ordinance would do two things particularly well. It would push the "cost burden predominantly away from existing residents" and incentivize developers to build inclusionary units.
In addition to the requirement that 15% of units fit the inclusionary definitions, the ordinance would grant developers that provide inclusionary units on the same site as market-rate units with a 20% density bonus.
Such aspects of the ordinance encourage mixed-income projects, which town leaders believe can help to reduce housing inequities.
"Housing segregation opens the door to other types of segregation, and you can certainly see that in many, many communities," Salinas said. "But not just racial and ethnic, but also age."
Tom Klein, the Planning Commission's sole vote against the ordinance, says he is a proponent of more affordable and workforce housing. He believes inclusionary zoning is not "necessary nor a cost-effective way" to achieve that goal.
"For the past two years that I have been on the Planning Commission, just about every new development proposal has come with a component of affordable/workforce housing," Klein wrote in an email.
Recent developments that provide the town with affordable housing include projects from The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, such as Port Street Commons, a multi-use property with nine affordable apartment units that opened in December, and Silo Square, a mixed-income housing project greenlit in October.
Revitalization of the Doverbrook Apartments complex in Easton is underway and will feature an additional 14 affordable units on top of 50 existing ones. On Elliott Road, more than 100 apartments are under construction, a portion of those affordable.
Last July, the town approved the annexation of 17 acres of land for a housing project on the east side of Route 50. In the annexation agreement, developers agreed at least 50% of the project's apartment units will be affordable.
Given the number of ongoing projects, Klein says he feels inclusionary zoning would not "provide a significant number" of additional affordable units.
But Ports believes the ordinance will ensure that the limited supply of undeveloped land in the town is being used properly.
"It's really the biggest asset any community has," Ports said. "If we want to allow someone to potentially change it forever, we need to make sure that they're investing in the community in some way."
REGULATIONAt the November Planning Commission meeting, Klein and other commission members expressed concerns of overregulation prior to voting on the ordinance.
"I think that the market's taking care of it," Klein said. "I think that we're putting a lot of regulation here. Like I said, I think there could be a lot of unintended consequences that come out of that and a lot of cost for what we get out of it."
Salinas and Bent both said the market hasn't been able to address ballooning home and rental costs in recent years.
Bent said he's heard from planning commissioners in the past that a "tool" is needed to point developers toward what the town wants in terms of affordability.
While proponents of inclusionary zoning are confident it can be this tool, they recognize the housing problem in Easton is complex.
"If we got into this hole of housing deficiency over the course of decades, it's impossible to fix that in one year, let alone even 10 years," Ports said. "It will be a game of playing catch-up."
Cook hopes Easton residents, along with the Town Council, see affordable housing as a top challenge to tackle.
"I do hope that they see the importance of this issue, and I also hope that the community itself sees the importance of the issue," Cook said. "For the longevity and the vibrancy of the Town of Easton, it's an important issue."

title: Opioid deaths spur push for kids to carry naloxone
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
Opioid deaths spur push for kids to carry naloxone

 March 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1188
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Jackson Taylor remembers when a peer passed out from an overdose across from his high school. He knows friends who have struggled with addiction. One has been in and out of rehab.Those experiences help explain why the Rockville High School senior now trains his peers on how to administer naloxone, a lifesaving medication that reverses opioid overdoses. They're why he carries naloxone at school and why he wants all districts to let their students do the same.
"It's just like a student having a heart attack," said Taylor, who runs a student task force on drug and opioid issues in Montgomery County. "It might be rare, but on the off chance it happens, you want to be able to save them and help them."
Currently, a disparate and ambiguous set of district-level policies has created confusion on the role students may play in preventing opioid deaths among their peers. But a bill before the Maryland General Assembly aims to provide a clear and uniform set of standards.
The measure, HB 1268, would explicitly authorize students across the state to possess and administer naloxone — also known by its brand name, Narcan — as adolescent opioid deaths surge and teens lobby for urgent solutions.
While the practice is already permitted for students in Montgomery County, others have gotten punished for carrying naloxone in school, according to the bill's sponsor, Del. Joe Vogel (D-Montgomery).
"We know that our student populations are uniquely vulnerable when it comes to (the opioid) issue," Vogel said. "And this (bill) is, to me, a common-sense step to say, 'Hey, you should not be punished for carrying naloxone with you in a school hallway, and you should not be punished for saving a classmate's life if they're overdosing.'"
At a hearing before the House Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday, Taylor, 18, was among those who testified in support of the measure. So, too, did Maryland's Special Secretary of Opioid Response, Emily Keller, an indication that the bill has the backing of Gov. Wes Moore's administration.
"Empowering people and giving them the tools necessary to help is a vital strategy, especially with young people," Keller said in her testimony. "Making naloxone accessible with every Marylander is one of our priorities because we know it's the number one life-saving tool."
The bill responds to an alarming national trend: Between 2018 and 2022, adolescent deaths from opioids quadrupled, according to an analysis by KFF.
The rise in overdoses has coincided with two factors, said Patricia Kapunan, the medical director for Montgomery County Public Schools. One is the use of social media to market pills without a prescription. The other is the rise of fentanyl, a potent synthetic opioid that is being mixed with illegal drugs, often unbeknownst to the user and with deadly effects.
In 2021, fentanyl was involved in nearly four times as many fatal overdoses among young people in Maryland as the next deadliest drug, cocaine, according to the state's Vital Statistics Administration.
"Suddenly, (fentanyl) is showing up everywhere, and suddenly one pill can kill," Kapunan said.
Implementation questionsIn response to the opioid crisis, lawmakers have mandated that school districts take preventive actions. The Start Talking Maryland Act of 2017 required public schools to teach kids about the dangers of opioids and have naloxone available on campuses. It also authorized nurses and other health and school personnel to administer the medication in overdose emergencies.
Most districts have not extended the same permission to students. In Cecil County, students are not necessarily punished for possessing naloxone, according to director of student and school safety John Roush. But "they would be talked to by their school administration about it and informed that we don't have a policy for (them) to carry that in schools," he said.
Roush thinks the bill is a good idea and may help save lives, though he anticipates challenges with implementation and logistics.
"We have over 15,000 kids in our system here," he said. "How do you get Narcan out? How do you get information out? How do you make them educated on the use? How do you make them aware? It seems like there would be a lot of time and details to be worked out in that regard."
While the bill requires schools to educate students about the benefits of naloxone, it does not specifically address one major logistical consideration: training kids on how to dispense the medication.
Available over the counter as a nasal spray, Narcan must be administered by tilting the person's head back and firmly pressing the plunger. Because the medication's effects are temporary and overdose symptoms may return, it is critical that the individual providing Narcan also call 911 and seek medical aid.
To the American Medical Association, the benefits of expanding naloxone access in schools still outweigh the risks. Following a debate on the issue, the group approved a resolution last year encouraging "states, communities and educational settings to remove barriers to students carrying safe and effective overdose reversal medications."
"Narcan saves people quickly, and lack of Narcan kills people quickly," said Kenneth Certa, an AMA delegate from the American Psychiatric Association, which co-sponsored the policy. "When somebody is turning blue and cold, you don't have much time. And to wait until a dose gets from another part of the building can be too late."
'Hugely empowering'In Montgomery County, which saw a 78% spike in youth overdoses from 2021 to 2022, a policy permitting students to carry naloxone took effect on May 1, 2023.
Kapunan, who crafted the measure, said students were never punished for possessing overdose-reversing medications and were already protected under good samaritan laws if they acted in an emergency. But teen advocates nonetheless pressed for a policy change that eliminated ambiguity and codified their right to intervene.
"Those levels of permission were really important to students," Kapunan said. "For me, it was a very small part of the regulation. For them, it was hugely empowering."
Kapunan says the policy does not mean schools are depending on kids to save lives. During the 2022-23 school year, naloxone was dispensed on school grounds in Montgomery County 18 times, almost always by nurses. Since the policy change, there have been no known instances of a student administering naloxone to a peer at school.
But to supporters, the measure remains an important preventive step, permitting those in closest proximity to an overdose to act without fear of repercussion.
"Students know before the teachers do, is the truth," Taylor said. "I'm a lot more likely to know, 'Hey, my friend has a pill in his bag that he's thinking about taking, and it could have a repercussion' than a teacher would know."
Vogel, who is running for the open U.S. congressional seat in Maryland's 6th District, said expanding policies like the one in Montgomery County has become a necessity. Six months ago, he met with student leaders who spoke to the urgency of the opioid crisis and their desire to help address it.
"A lot of them have taken matters into their own hands," Vogel said. "A number of them have stepped up and said, 'We want to get trained on how to administer naloxone, and we want to be able to carry naloxone.' … That's what this bill is in response to."

title: State, local officials announce return of Fair Hill Races
author: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com
content:
State, local officials announce return of Fair Hill Races

 July 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FAIR HILL — State and county officials have announced the long-awaited return of the Fair Hill Races to Fair Hill on Aug. 30, along with promises of future racing events to be held at the track."The Fair Hill Races are back in Cecil County," Cecil County Executive Adam Streight said. "We're bringing back a tradition that has bonded us together. And we intend to keep it here."
Last occurring in 2019, the Fair Hill Races are a longstanding Cecil County tradition stretching back nearly 90 years, and their absence has been a subject of public inquiry throughout the six-year gap. With the Maryland 5 Star becoming an annual event at Fair Hill's race track, officials said that the return of the races will usher in a new era for Cecil County's equine community.
"A renaissance of racing starts today," said Del. Kevin Hornberger, who has been heavily involved in legislating the Fair Hill Special Event Zone and its use.
The official announcement of the races' return comes in the wake of a $2.85 million dollar partnership between Cecil County and the Sport and Entertainment Corporation of Maryland that was approved by the county council last October.
State officials thanked local and state partners and acknowledged the feedback from Cecil Countians as a major impetus for the return of racing to the track.
"This is clearly a place Cecil County loves," Maryland Department of Natural Resources Secretary Josh Kurtz said. "Our responsibility as the steward is to reflect what Cecil County wants and what Cecil County needs."
Other officials agreed with Kurtz, saying that Cecil Countians' calls for the return of the races have been heard.
"We couldn't let another year go by without racing at Fair Hill," said Sport & Entertainment Corporation of Maryland President Terry Hasseltine, noting that the races' return has been "a long time coming."
This year's race will be free to the public and is planned to be a one-day event held on Aug. 30. According to Hasseltine, the number of races in this year's event is still being determined.
While the reborn Fair Hill Races are the only event on the docket for the remainder of 2025, Hasseltine also said that there are already plans to hold another racing event next Memorial Day, as well as discussions about races on other dates.
"[Fair Hill] is globally significant when it comes to the equine community," said Kurtz.
Officials noted that the horse racing industry and economy has a multi-billion dollar impact on Maryland, directly employing approximately 22,000 workers throughout the state.
Local organizations expressed their pleasure that the races will finally be making their return to Cecil County.
"The Board of Directors is delighted by this morning's news from Maryland Department of Natural Resources Secretary Josh Kurtz that racing will return to Fair Hill on August 30," Fair Hill Foundation President Charles C. Fenwick Jr. said. "It has been gratifying to work with his dedicated team, the Sport and Entertainment Corporation of Maryland, the Cecil County Breeders Fair, and Delegate Kevin Hornberger to make this long-anticipated outcome a reality, and we are immensely grateful for all the hard work on the part of so many people. We look forward to our continued work together to realize Mr. du Pont's vision for Fair Hill as one of the world's leading venues for equestrian sport."
With events like the Maryland 5 Star and the Cecil County Fair already making use of the site, Streight noted that his administration expects that the addition of the races and future events will show returns not only economically — with an emphasis on the benefits to small businesses — but culturally.
"We expect an economic boom," Streight said. "[And also] a return to pride in what Cecil County has to offer."
Streight also pointed to the history of the races and their value to Cecil County's identity.
"This is a tradition that goes back decades," said Streight. "That bonded us together."

title: Maryland Department of Agriculture working to address ongoing DAF issues
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Maryland Department of Agriculture working to address ongoing DAF issues

 February 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Environment 
 
 735
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — The Maryland Department of Agriculture is doing "everything within its powers" to address recent concerns with the storage of dissolved air flotation residuals, according to Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks.Speaking to the Eastern Shore Delegation Friday morning, Atticks touched on the agency's efforts to handle the growing worries with responsible handling and storage of the sludge — an issue that has garnered extensive attention in Caroline County over the last few months.
Dissolved air flotation, or DAF, is a method used to process wastewater from food processing plants. The method leaves behind a sludge-like byproduct, or DAF residuals.
On the Shore, much of the material generated from DAF comes from poultry processing plants, though some comes from industrial and wastewater treatment sludge.
When used, managed, stored and transported correctly, there are no issues with DAF, Atticks said. But when it's used against MDA's regulations, issues arise with the smell, making neighboring residents concerned.
"What we're learning, what we're all collectively learning, is that for better or worse, one or two bad actors can ruin the entire setup," he said.
Atticks said the agency is working on legislation to answer the concerns, but it's also doubling down on enforcement within its powers. The department is working with the Maryland Department of the Environment as well.
On Feb. 5, several state lawmakers introduced legislation aiming to establish an industrial sludge utilization permit. The legislation would authorize MDE to issue the permits, develop a fee schedule and inspect and enter any site where industrial sludge is utilized.
According to the bill, industrial sludge includes material separated from liquid waste through a DAF process.
"We've been cooperating with Caroline County and in other parts of the state … to make sure that we're leaving avenues open for this product to be used responsibly and appropriately —where appropriate, when appropriate — but then putting the guardrails on it so that it's not going to cause the problems that it's causing in these minor incidents," Atticks said.
Del. Steve Arentz (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil and Caroline) asked if the Department of Agriculture would look at processes that could turn DAF residuals into energy.
Atticks said the department is actively exploring the idea.
"The poultry producers and other manufacturers who have food residual waste need a place to go, and it's not the landfill, and it's not the rivers," he said. "If it's through this DAF process, that's an option, if it's through a bioenergy generator, even better."
Arentz said he'd prefer internal work to solve the problems as opposed to more regulations — a statement the secretary agreed with in part.
"The last thing we want is more regulation. We certainly don't mind better regulation," Atticks said, adding, "We have limitations to what we can do and what we can't do, and this is an instance where we have industry come to us to say, 'We need more regulation to ensure that we can do what we're doing responsibly better,' and we can make sure that those who are bad actors are out of the business."
Del. Jefferson Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil and Caroline) emphasized that the application of DAF isn't an issue due to the department's nutrient management plans. The unregulated storage is the problem, he said.
A former Caroline County Commissioner, Ghrist introduced a bill Friday that would give local governments that own or operate a water or sewer system the authority to enact local legislation relating to DAF storage that is equal to or greater than the state permit requirements for sewage sludge utilization.
To Atticks, the goal is to get something "on the ground" as fast as possible, whether it's to the counties or state agencies.
"...More is not better here, but clearer would help — figuring out a process so that we've actually got the controls that the community feels we should have, and that our industry feels that we should have," he said. "We're doing everything we can to work with the industry on this."
A separate bill involving fines and fees with MDA's programs did have support from the industry, Atticks said, because those who aren't doing anything wrong don't face fines.
"This is one of those instances where what we need is clarity, what we need is to run the groove to make sure that we've got the authorities that we need, that MDE has the authority that they need and (that) the counties have the authority they need."
Star Democrat reporter Connie Connolly contributed to this report.

 EASTON — During Tuesday's meeting, the Easton Town Council approved four-way stops at two different intersections on Brookletts Avenue.Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh recommended the stop signs be added at the intersection of Brookletts Avenue and South Harrison Street, as well as the intersection of Brookletts Avenue and Hanson Street.
Van Emburgh wrote that the all-way stops will improve safety for pedestrians, bicyclists and drivers. By a unanimous vote, town councilmembers approved a resolution for the stop signs.
Currently, at the intersection of Brookletts Avenue and South Harrison Street, vehicles driving on Harrison Street do not stop, while vehicles traveling on Brookletts do.

"I know that we've had multiple conversations and emails and stuff about some of the complaints of traffic and stuff on Brookletts," Interim Town Manager Alan Lowrey said Tuesday. "And this is an opportunity to try to address that to see if implementing these four-way stops will improve some of that accident data and speed concerns."

 EASTON - This year will mark three decades of First Night Talbot.And for the event's 30th year, First Night Talbot is sparing nothing to make Dec. 31 a special night for everyone.
Deena Kilmon, director of strategic initiatives at Easton Economic Development, said the event, which starts at 6 p.m., is "amazingly fun," inclusive and free.
"All the venues are handicap accessible," she said. "It's alcohol-free, drug-free. So if you wanted to go to a family-friendly happy, fun celebration out in your community, that's what this is." This year, even the buttons for participants are free. Kilmon said that while the collectable buttons have been something for purchase in the past, they are free of charge this year.
"A lot of people collect them, and this is the 30th-year button," Kilmon said.
The buttons are available at the Easton Visitor Center on Harrison Street. They can be picked up the day of the event or anytime before that. The center is open from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Monday through Friday and 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. on Saturdays.
This year will be Improv Easton's first time performing at First Night Talbot.
Kilmon said that aside from the crab drop, Improv Easton is a can't miss experience.
"They have been practicing and practicing and practicing for months," Kilmon said. "I think that's going to be a great show." Kilmon said there will also be more arts and crafts activities for children at the Waterfowl Building this year.
And although this is not Mike Elzey's first rodeo at First Night Talbot, this will be his first year at the Town Hall venue.
"It's kind of like a private concert venue versus being out in the open," Kilmon said of the change.
From 6 p.m. to 8:45 p.m. at Town Hall, there will be a student showcase from Mike Elzey's Guitar Studio students. From 9:15 p.m. to 10:30 p.m., Elzey will host an air guitar competition with prizes.
Along with the Waterfowl Building and Town Hall, there will also be performances at the Avalon Theater throughout the night.
But the main event of the night is the crab drop - an 8-foot-wide Maryland blue crab sculpture created by Rich and Suzanne Hood 19 years ago - that will drop at 9 p.m. and at midnight.
First Night Talbot Program Chair Carolyn Jaffe said that when the crab reaches the bottom of the rig, it lights up the numbers for the new year.
"It's just the greatest," Jaffe said. "Everybody loves it - to take pictures of each other in front of the crab drop when it's lit up like that." This year, USA Today ranked First Night Talbot's crab drop the 6th best New Year's Eve drop in the nation.
"They actually had the New York City drop included in that," Jaffe said. "But they weren't in the top 10." At an Easton Town Council meeting Monday, Jaffe was honored for her many years of contributions to First Night Talbot.
Kilmon said making the entire First Night Talbot event free gives everyone the opportunity to enjoy the event.
"All the stuff that's happening is going to be no charge to the families," she said. "We certainly just want them to come out and enjoy their community." More information on First Night Talbot can be found on Facebook@FirstNightTalbot Inc. on on Discover Easton's website.
Questions can also be directed to the Easton EDC at 410-690-7348 or welcome@discovereaston.com.

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 308
 Words

 CENTREVILLE — Queen Anne's County High School has recently been awarded $70,000 to pursue the hiring of the district's first School Security Employee (SSE), according to Joe Saboury, coordinator of school safety and security.As of August, the district received funding from the Maryland Center for School Safety School Resource Officer (SRO) Adequate Coverage Grant under the 2018 Maryland Safe to Learn Act, Saboury said.
This funding allows school districts to hire an employee to serve as a supplement to the SRO already in place, he said. Resource officers already serving the school district fall under the direction and budget of the county sheriff's office.
The statewide grant funding assists in supplementing law enforcement coverage for public schools with $10 to 15 million in FY26 and $20 million in FY27 and each year thereafter, he said.
As school security is considered a top state priority, a minimum three years of funding following this year is secured, according to Saboury.
"So really that's putting additional eyes and ears in our schools, which is a wonderful thing," he said.
As a member of the district, the SSE works more closely with school leaders on safety measures, often outside law enforcement scopes, and are more closely involved with student behavior, support and providing intervention to mitigate and prevent harm, he said.
As district employees, QACPS has the flexibility to utilize SSEs for after school sporting events or field trips Saboury said.
"It's a great resource that the school district has never had before," he said.
SSEs are held to the same standards and certification programs through the Maryland for School Safety Model training as SROs.
Training, uniforms, equipment and overtime are all budgeted into the grant with no cost the district, he said.
With the potential for increased funding down the road, Saboury was hopeful to be able to build the program and continually create a safe learning environment for students.

 TRAPPE - Volunteers at Trappe's Rural Life Museum are puzzled and looking for answers after an antique device was recently left on museum grounds.The mystery is twofold, said museum board of directors President Elizabeth Ferguson, and includes questions about the device's original purpose and who brought it to the facility.The item in question is a wooden implement that appears to have been used as some kind of press, as it includes an arm that raises and lowers a wooden punch into a metal reinforced hole.The implement does have some metal hardware, and it includes a large block of wood used as the base.The round house is between one to two inches, and there are non-structural boards nailed to upright supports under the punch area, possibly forming an area that was easier to clear of punched material.Ferguson said the antique was left in the museum's Carriage House building a few days ago. The building, damaged in a 2020 storm, saw the renovation begin in 2021.The building was a notion shop at one point, and it was moved to its current location on Backtown Road from Trappe's Main Street around 1900.It also served as housing for migrant workers, who slept in the loft, and was also used as an office and possibly a garage for the canning facility previously located on what is now the museum grounds.Anyone with information on what the device is or where it came from is asked to email rurallifemuseum@gmail.com or call 410-476-4857.More information about the Rural Life Museum is available online at trapperurallifemuseum.org.

 OXFORD - Following direction from a Commissioners of Oxford meeting on Tuesday, a resident has moved forward with creating an informal committee to beautify the area surrounding the water treatment facility on Jl Thompson Drive.The committee will formulate a plan to be brought to the Commissioners of Oxford for consideration.Nick Papson, the resident tasked with creating the informal committee, submitted a petition, signed by more than 180 residents, to the town to "accelerate a beautification campaign along the fence surrounding the water treatment facility" on Jl Thompson Drive."For years, this has been an eyesore, which those of us who live nearby and pass daily have been asked to tolerate as higher priority facility and beautification projects have taken place," the petition said, which Commission President Tom Costigan read at the meeting.Since the meeting, Papson said he has assembled a committee of six residents.He said the committee will meet next week to begin the process of putting together a plan and getting quotes for potential projects. title: Long-awaited Easton dog park officially opens
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Long-awaited Easton dog park officially opens

 January 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 467
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Not even sub-freezing temperatures and bits of ice laying on the turf grass Thursday morning could stop over a dozen dogs — and their owners — from celebrating the grand opening of Easton's long-awaited dog park.Dogs of all ages, sizes and breeds were pulling at their leashes with energetic anticipation, waiting for the ceremonial red ribbon to be cut by Easton Mayor Megan Cook.
Thursday's ribbon cutting was a welcome sight for local dog owners and dog lovers, many of whom had waited years for the project to come to fruition.
A voiced interest in a dog park first came seven or eight years ago, said Rick Van Emburgh, the town engineer.
But in 2019, Easton residents David Ferraris and Noah Matten restarted the efforts, working with Rauch Inc., a local engineering firm, to prepare concept plans for a dog park near the downtown area.
And in fall 2020, the town received $7 million in bond funding, a majority of which was required to be allocated to parks.
Almost three years later, in March 2023, the Easton Town Council voted to fully fund the dog park on Brewers Lane and to add a restroom there, Van Emburgh said.
With the legislative work completed, construction of the dog park required a true group effort from the town's public works, parks and recreation, IT, buildings and finance departments.
Willow Construction, Easton Utilities and Chester River Landscaping also lent a hand with a number of other efforts to make the park a reality.
"I believe this is a wonderful example of teamwork," Van Emburgh said. "I believe it's a wonderful example of our community working together to build something beautiful for our town residents and our dogs."
Cook kept her comments brief, acknowledging a number of excitedly yapping dogs waiting to enter the park and play.
"I really want to give an extra shoutout to all the departments," the mayor said. "Pretty much every department in the Town of Easton played a role in getting this park up and running."
Once the ribbon was cut, the dogs were unleashed and off to play.
The new park, open dawn to dusk, includes two separate play areas for the pups based on weight, with a larger area allocated to dogs over 35 pounds.
A turf grass layer on top makes for a comfortable surface for dogs to run, jump and roll around, and underneath, there's an anti-microbial infill material and an irrigation system for cooling the turf.
It was clear that the dogs were excited as they raced in circles and made new friends, and the smiles on owners' faces told a similar story.
Easton resident Scott Cohen, who stopped by the park with his two Australian Shepherd-poodle mixes Scruffy, 4, and Casey, 3, said the dogs had a great time playing Thursday morning.
"I think it's a terrific add to the community," he said.

Vikings rush past Knights

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports

 CAMBRIDGE — Rob Burnham is among the football coaching crowd who stresses the importance of the second half's first possession.The last possession of the first half proved pretty important as well for Burnham's Cambridge-South Dorchester High team Friday night.
Sterling Perkins hauled in a 14-yard touchdown pass just before the end of the first half, then scored on a 3-yard run to open the second half, to help give the Vikings separation on the way to a 49-21 victory over Century.
"I tell our kids all the time when we get in the locker room that the first possession of the second half is the biggest possession of the game," said Cambridge-SD's first-year head coach after his team improved to 2-0. "And I believe that. You open the game and score, that's OK because there's a lot of ballgame left. But when you open the second half (and score). ... And I thought it was big that we scored right before halftime and then we got the possession again. So that gives us the two-score lead. That's huge. Huge."
After a scoreless first quarter, Cambridge-SD senior quarterback Anthony Hughes scored on runs of 20 and 55 yards to help stake the Vikings to a 14-0 lead with 9 minutes, 18 seconds left in the second quarter. Collin Bair drilled both point-after kicks.
The Knights (0-2) rallied though. Jonathan Ferguson scored on a 1-yard run up the middle, but the point-after boot sailed wide left, leaving Century trailing 14-6.
Cambridge-SD drove from its 40 to the Knights' 20, where Dylan Vroom intercepted Vikings backup quarterback Nathan Twilley and raced 80 yards up the sideline for a touchdown. Ferguson's two-point conversion run tied the game at 14-all with 3:02 left before halftime.
The Vikings came right back, as Hughes lofted a pass toward the end zone that Perkins made a nice over-the-shoulder grab on for a 14-yard touchdown and a 20-14 lead with 7.6 remaining in the first half. Cambridge-SD bobbled the snap from center on the extra-point attempt, and settled for a six-point lead entering the break.
The Vikings needed just three plays to expand that lead on the first possession of the second half. Perkins ran for gains of 17 and 27 yards before he took a handoff and made a quick juke into the end zone for a 3-yard touchdown. Hughes hit Antonio Blueford with a two-point conversion pass for a 28-14 lead just 42 seconds into the third.
On its next possession, Century tried to convert a fourth-and-four from its own 31. But quarterback Jacob Dexter fired incomplete, turning the ball over to the Vikings. On the next play, William Jackson swept right and blazed into the end zone for a 31-yard touchdown. Bair added the PAT for a 35-14 lead with 9:08 to go in the third.
Century pulled within 35-21 with 4:50 left in the third, as Ferguson bulled his way into the end zone from 2 yards out, then booted the point-after.
The Knights though could not stop Cambridge-SD's big plays.
On its ensuing possession, Hughes broke free for his third touchdown run, this one covering 42 yards for a 41-21 cushion with 3:34 left in the third.
Cambridge-SD again stopped the Knights on fourth down, but penalties from the Vikings back to their own 6-yard line. It didn't matter, as Perkins took a handoff, found a seam up the middle, and bolted 94 yards for a touchdown. Blueford made a diving grab on Hughes' two-point pass for a 49-21 lead.
"We're going to get better," Burnham said. "The things we struggled with today we'll make improvements on. We have to be better than we were tonight that's for sure."

 An investigation that led to the arrest of an 81-year-old Perryville man accused of stealing more than $160,000 from an 85-year-old California woman through a protracted telephone scam has continued for the past two and a half months, resulting in the lead detective identifying six more victims and six other states, according to Perryville Police Chief Robert Nitz."The total amount of money stolen is up to about one million dollars now," Nitz told the Cecil Whig on Wednesday. "We've reached out the the U.S. Secret Service and now there is a possibility that it will take over the case and handle the investigation from here."
Nitz applauded Perryville Police Department Det. Anthony Lenzi, lead detective, for conducting the initial three-month-long investigation that led to the arrest of the suspect — Harold Joseph Lahr, of the 1400 block of Perryville Road — and for the continuing probe during the past two and a half months, which resulted in the identification of the six additional victims and six other states. Lenzi reportedly was assisted by fellow officers while serving as the lead investigator.
"These types of investigations are especially complex due to the involvement of multiple financial institutions and jurisdictions," Nitz commented. "This case highlights that crime knows no boundaries. I'm extremely proud of the dedication and persistence shown by our officers in bringing justice to the victim. The Perryville Police Department remains committed to protecting our community and (to) working with partners across the country to hold criminals accountable."
The local investigation leading to Lahr's arrest and the criminal charges against him started in May, when detectives with the Orange County (Cal.) Sheriff's Office contacted the Perryville Police Department regarding an elderly resident in their jurisdiction who had been defrauded by someone in Cecil County, police reported.
That spurred a three-month-long investigation, culminating in the arrest of Lahr on July 30 and the charges against him, according to Nitz, who declined to specify the ruse that Lahr allegedly had used to steal the woman's money, citing the pending trial.
Nitz reported that the woman used cashier checks to pay Lahr and, on one occasion, overnighted $8,000 in cash to Lahr through the U.S. Postal Service.
"The investigation revealed that the victim had been defrauded of approximately $163,000 through a series of financial transactions. Through search and seizure warrants, subpoenas, and multiple interviews, Harold Lahr was identified as the suspect," Nitz explained.
The police chief further outlined, "Investigators gathered transaction logs, video surveillance footage, and other supporting evidence before submitting the case to the Cecil County State's Attorney's Office for review."
Investigators arrested Lahr after the Cecil County State's Attorney's Office filed 11 charges against him on July 16 by way of a criminal information document, Nitz outlined.
The criminal charges against Lahr include four counts each of exploitation of a vulnerable adult to steal more than $25,000 and less than $100,000 and theft of more than $25,000 and less than $100,000, according to Cecil County Circuit Court records. Theft scheme to steal more than $100,000 also is among the charges against Lahr, court records show.
Lahr remained in custody on no bond Wednesday, according to court records, which further show that, on Sept. 5, Lahr was found to be incompetent to stand trial.

Music as medicine: holiday concert provides cheer to residents living with memory loss

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Holiday

 EASTON — On Monday afternoon, the HeartFields Assisted Living in Easton was filled with hums and songs.The annual holiday concert led by TiShawna Jordan, a local musician, was an effort to provide holiday cheer and acted as an intervention to benefit those living with loss of memory.
Heartfields Assisted Living at Easton partnered with the Chesapeake Center in order to provide support for elderly individuals through volunteer-led events such as the holiday concert.
Erin Lewis, director of career services at Chesapeake Center, said TiShawna Jordan's concerts have provided holiday cheer and positive memory recollection to those in the Bridge to Rediscovery program.
"Watching her perform throughout the year with the people in the memory clinic. She brings them back to life," Lewis said. "They start singing, they start dancing, they remember all the words to each one of the songs. It's wonderful to see how she can interact. It's almost like a different way of communicating."
According to Northwestern University, musical intervention has therapeutic benefits for people with dementia or Alzheimer's disease and has been proven to decrease a patient's agitation and improve communication.
Megan Pinder, director of sales and marketing for HeartFields Assisting Living, said HeartFields had begun partnering with the Chesapeake Center about two years ago. The volunteer-led programs began with a bird club where volunteers come to the Heartfields and fill up the 41 bird feeders every week for the residents to enjoy.
Then TiShawna, an active volunteer at the Chesapeake Center, began to come and play music for residents at HeartFields.
According to Pinder, the first holiday concert was a resounding success, and TiShawna Jordan was presented with roses by the HeartFields Resident Ambassador because her playing had moved many attendees to tears.
Elsie Jordan, mother of TiShawna Jordan, said her daughter was always musically inclined. As a child she would play the keyboard, and Elsie Jordan said she would help her daughter learn new music through humming songs.
During the concert, Elsie Jordan sat next to her daughter humming and singing along to classic Christmas songs such as "White Christmas" and "Jingle Bell Rock." At some points they would both sing, encouraging the crowd of attendees to raise their voices and fully enjoy the memory of the holidays.
"God gave her that gift, and I want her to share her gift with other people," Elsie Jordan said. "Because if it wasn't for God, she wouldn't have the gift she has. I feel like it's a gift and you shouldn't have to be paid for something you love doing. And she loves playing."

title: Sabres can't break Royals' rule
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Sabres can't break Royals' rule

 February 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 756
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GEORGETOWN, DEL. — They were separated by two points during their two regular-season games.And they were separated by two halfway through their third meeting.
That separation became wider though in the second half Monday, as Delmarva Christian School hit big shots in the paint and beyond the arc on the way to a 53-42 victory over Saints Peter and Paul High, giving the Royals their sixth Eastern Shore Independent Athletic Conference girls basketball title over the past seven seasons.
"Delmarva Christian played fabulous today," Sabres head coach Katie Murphy said. "I mean Bella (Marinelli), I think she hit just about every shot. I'd love to see her shot percentage from today. She was amazing. They all were. They played really hard. They executed correctly. They deserved to win."
And yet for the third time this season, this rivalry was shaping up to be a duel to the end. Sts. Peter & Paul (12-9), which came in on an eight-game winning streak, broke a 9-9 first-quarter tie when Kaylin Palmer (nine points) hit a bucket and Avery McCall converted one of two from the foul line for a three-point lead after one complete.
But the Royals (16-4) began connecting from beyond the arc in the second quarter. Marinelli, who drained four 3-pointers as part of a game-high 20-point performance, freshman Avery McCoy (nine points) and Layni Dukes (11 points) each hit 3-pointers, with Dukes' tying the game at 19-all with 1:31 left in the half.
Lucy Rankin kept the Sabres close, scoring six of her 12 points in the second quarter. A pair of Marinelli free throws and a Dukes layup moved Delmarva Christian to a 23-19 lead before Sts. Peter & Paul's Annie Albright scored to make it a two-point margin at the half.
The Royals began to widen their lead early in the third, as Marinelli buried a 3-pointer and Eve Bohinski (10 points) made a three-point play for a 29-21 lead. Emma Hainey's two free throws halted Delmarva Christian's mini-burst.
And though Sts. Peter & Paul remained within striking distance, the Royals began patiently working the ball around the perimeter before driving through the lane for layups that steadily extended their lead. Bohinski and Dukes each found an open lane for layups before McCoy's three-point play pushed Delmarva's Christian's lead to 36-26 late in the third.
"We made a couple shots that kind of got us going," Royals head coach Frank Roach said. "The first two games, jump shots weren't really falling much. I think that helped. And then we changed up our defense a little bit in that third quarter and that gave us a little bit of breathing room. I think the defensive switch is what kind of broke the game open."
The switch from man-to-man to a box-and-one helped Delmarva Christian outscore the Sabres, 13-7, in the third. Still, Sts. Peter & Paul stuck around, Palmer scoring the last basket of the third and the first of the fourth, drawing the Sabres within 36-30.
But Marinelli scored on a drive through the paint, hit a 3-pointer, watched Dukes score a layup, then drove through the middle again to give the Royals a 45-32 lead with under 4 minutes remaining.
"I told them to space it out," Roach said of his team's offense. "I know they (SSPP) were in a hurry to try to get some turnovers, get some steals. I said, 'Hey. Space the floor, use your handle. Let's attack the basket.' They did a good job attacking the basket."
Delmarva Christian's lead floated between 13 and 15 points before McCall, who notched her sixth double-double of the season with 15 points and 10 rebounds — both team highs — scored the Sabres' final seven points.
"I think nerves had a lot to do with it," Murphy said of her team. "I think in some cases we may have wanted to win too much instead of playing our game. Not settling into offense was a real huge thing. We were able to do that in the previous two games. And here they couldn't get their offensive rhythm no matter how many times we said, 'Run this offense. Do this. Slow it down.'
"Again, it's a young team," added Murphy, who has no seniors on the team. "They have grown a lot and continue to learn. They're a great group of kids who fought until the very end. There's no reason why they can't do this again next year."
Notes: McCall was named the ESIAC player of the year, and was joined on the all-conference first team by Rankin and Albright. … Hainey was honorable mention.

title: Gunsallus to run for reelection as Easton Town Council president
author: Konner Metz
content:
Gunsallus to run for reelection as Easton Town Council president

 January 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 315
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus is running for reelection in the town's election this spring.Gunsallus, who has served as council president since September 2023, announced his candidacy last month. He is a member of the Easton Rotary Club and works with Disaster Aid USA, a nonprofit that delivers disaster relief worldwide.
"Over the past term, I have had the privilege of working alongside dedicated council members, community leaders, and residents who are passionate about shaping Easton's future," Gunsallus wrote in an email to The Star Democrat. "The trust placed in me to lead our town council is both humbling and inspiring, and I believe there is more work to be done to ensure Easton remains a vibrant, welcoming, and prosperous community."
The current president will have at least one opponent, as Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello announced his candidacy for the head council seat earlier this week. Abbatiello has been the Ward 2 representative since 2019.
Gunsallus says his main priorities if reelected are public safety and infrastructure, affordable housing, community engagement and economic development. On the topic of housing, he said it's an "ongoing challenge" and the town's making "significant strides."
In 2023, Gunsallus won a special election for the presidential seat after previous president Megan Cook assumed the town's mayoral seat. At 35, he began his term as the youngest council president in Easton's history.
With more than a year under his belt, Gunsallus said he's learned "the immense value of collaboration and listening."
"I have learned that effective leadership requires balancing the immediate needs of the community with a long-term vision for sustainable growth," Gunsallus wrote. "This role has also reinforced the importance of adaptability and resilience, especially when navigating the challenges that come with governing a dynamic town like Easton."
In addition to council president, there will be Ward 2 and Ward 4 elections this spring. The filing deadline for candidates is April 7.

title: Dorchester MCAP data shows some progress, some areas of concern
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester MCAP data shows some progress, some areas of concern

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 483
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Public Schools' Spring 2024 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program successes — along with district concerns — were shared during a Board of Education meeting on Thursday.Although the district ranks in the state's bottom four for MCAP English and math proficiency rates, it did see year-to-year increases.
In English, the district rose 1.4% to 33.7% proficiency, ranking 22nd in the state out of 24 districts. In math, the district rose 1% to 12.3% proficiency, ranking 21st in the state.
During the meetingThursday, Jodi Colman, the district's assistant superintendent of academics and student services, showed proficiency rates and rankings in the state broken down by grade level.
Colman said there were eight grade levels where the district's state ranking in math increased and six grade levels where the district's state ranking in English increased.
In fifth grade science, where 14.4% of students were considered proficient on the 2024 MCAP assessment, the ranking went up to 20th in the state for 2024 compared to 22nd the previous year.
Colman said that at a statewide assistant superintendent meeting recently, Dorchester County was mentioned for its growth in third grade math, sixth grade math and middle school algebra.
"I thought that was nice to be highlighted across the state as seeing a district that is actually moving some of their scores," she said after mentioning that math scores across the state were pretty stagnant in the 2024 MCAP compared to the previous year.
Colman also brought up concerns regarding district MCAP scores.
According to the data Colman shared, 30.6% of 10th graders scored proficient on the English assessment last school year, ranking last in the state.
Colman said the district is looking at its support pathway classes, which it hopes will affect the 10th grade data "more significantly."
Colman also brought up elementary English scores. She said that as students go up in grade, English proficiency levels decrease.
Colman said there have been discussions about whether the district should resume using its instructional program for elementary English or adopt a new one. The district's language arts supervisor is researching this.
Moving forward, the district is getting feedback from the state on a new comprehensive literacy plan, Colman said.
"We are also looking at, across the board, our tier one instruction for any content level," she said. "Making sure that we're really using that instructional planning model, that we're thinking through strategically with our students and that do we have good, formative assessment data to use in order to change teaching within our classrooms. And I think we have a lot of work to do in that area."
Colman said that although the MCAP scores aren't "exactly where we want them," there is hope in the county about increasing the scores going forward.
"So I'm excited about that," she said.
After Colman's presentation, Superintendent Jymil Thompson said although the score increases might not be "monumental," they show progress.
"If we continue that progress over the years, it will add up," he said.
