title: All The Leaves Are Red, Yellow, and Orange - Top U.S. Destinations For Leaf Peeping And Other Fall Adventure
author: Michael Pollick; Wealth Of Geeks
content:
All The Leaves Are Red, Yellow, and Orange - Top U.S. Destinations For Leaf Peeping And Other Fall Adventure

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Pollick; Wealth Of Geeks | Page: 4A | Section: News 
 
 950
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The pumpkin spice lattes are flowing, and post-Halloween pumpkins are getting chunked.But there's still interest in family road trips, especially to destinations where the annual changing of the leaves is at its peak.A study by lawn care specialist LawnStarter reveals the top states for leaf peeping and other fall-related activities. Beyond Oktoberfest and Halloween, many cities offer harvest festivals as local crops come into season. Others organize arts and crafts shows or music festivals, while local wineries debut their latest releases.The allure of fall foliage may put cars on the road, but the states on LawnStarter's shortlist have found creative ways to reward visitors for their interest.TOP FIVE STATES FOR VIEWING FALL FOLIAGECaliforniaCalifornia ranks at or near the top in virtually every metric used in the LawnStarter study. It has the most national parks, the most scenic drives, and the most Fall-related attractions. Outside of Sacramento, Apple Hill features over 50 local farms and a fall festival with apple cider donuts and u-pick pumpkin and apple venues. The Napa Valley is famous for its fall foliage, along with wine tastings and grape stomping adventures.New YorkOne measurement used in the LawnStarter study was the number of peak days for the leaf-watching season. New York ranked highest, with a total of 31 days of ideal leaf peeping available. New York is also home to the Finger Lakes, renowned for their cideries. Other points of interest include the Adirondacks and the Catskills for hiking and historical towns such as Sleepy Hollow for ghost chasing.WashingtonWashington State's mountainous and forested terrain offers adventurous foliage seekers over 12 weeks of peak viewing time. Besides a generous number of hiking trails and national parks, visitors to Washington State can also visit the alpinethemed village of Leavenworth for its Autumn Leaf Festival and enjoy adult beverages at local wineries.MichiganMichigan's extended foliage viewing season of 12 weeks makes it very appealing for Midwesterners who seek a more local destination than coastal states. Michigan also has a high number of cideries, ranking second overall in the Lawn-Starter study. A scenic drive north of Harbor Springs is known as the Tunnel of Trees and offers travelers breathtaking views of hardwood trees and their colorful leaves. The Pumpkin Train is another popular Fall-related attraction located in western Michigan.PennsylvaniaPennsylvania's abundance of undeveloped forests helps land it in the fifth position on the Lawn-Starter survey. The view of tree-covered hills and rolling pastures has enticed visitors for literally hundreds of years. The Pocono Mountains host the annual Jim Thorpe Fall Foliage Festival, a ghost tour, and a scenic train ride.THE BEST TIME TO GO LEAF PEEPINGWhile the first leaves may start to change as early as mid-September, the peak Fall foliage season doesn't generally arrive until the middle to late part of October, when air temperatures also begin to drop in many regions. The most colorful part of the transition is often over by Thanksgiving, as leaves fade to brown and trees become bare.Min Park, Ph.D., Academic Program Coordinator School of Sport, Recreation, and Tourism Management at George Mason University, says, "In general, fall foliage peaks in most parts of the nation in mid-October through mid-November.Some mountains in the northwest are often at their most colorful in mid-September to early October."As I live in Virginia, Virginia's Shenandoah National Park is one of the best for fall colors. The best time to experience gorgeous fall colors in Shenandoah National Park is in October. Visitors can make the scenic cruise along the 105-mile-long Skyline Drive, which offers 70 overlooks where travelers can hop out of the car for a better view of foliage with red, yellow, and orange leaves.".FALL FESTIVALS AND OTHER ATTRACTIONSEven if fall foliage is not at its peak or travel options are limited, there are still many Autumnal activities individuals and families can enjoy. In many areas of the country, the temperatures and climate are still favorable for camping, hiking, and attending outdoor festivals.Rosa Abreu, Assistant Professor, Hospitality Management, New York City College of Technology, offers her suggestions for a satisfying fall-related excursion. "Stay in a place that has a fire pit and roast marshmallows. Have a few drinks by the fire. Go glamping. Pumpkin and apple picking is always fun." Other fall-related festivals and destinations you might want to check out include: Morton Pumpkin Festival, Morton, Illinois The village of Morton, Illinois, produces almost all of the canned pumpkin products in the international market. The village considers itself to be the pumpkin capital of the world and celebrates annually with the Morton Pumpkin Festival in September.Salem, Massachusetts, Haunted ToursThe small coastal city of Salem, Massachusetts, has become a popular fall destination because of its association with the Salem witch trials. The city hosts several festivals throughout the fall season and guided tours of local landmarks.Vermont's Sugarhouses and Maple SyrupThe state of Vermont supplies over half of the country's maple syrup, and the fall months are the best time to watch the process unfold. Numerous sugarhouses in Vermont provide guided tours of their facilities, and guests also enjoy a taste of small-town New England life.World's Largest Corn Maze, Spring Grove, Illinois Corn mazes, hayrides, and harvest festivals are always popular destinations for families, and Richardson Farm in Spring Grove, Illinois, offers over 9 miles of hayride trails and mazes on its 28-acre cornfield.This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks.

title: A 'smart buoy' is coming to St. Michaels harbor
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
A 'smart buoy' is coming to St. Michaels harbor

 November 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Environment 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — On Wednesday evening, Andrew David Thaler carried a large wooden device with yellow cords piled in its interior and a yellow and black top into the St. Michaels commissioners meeting.Thaler, a member of the St. Michaels Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission, smiled as he eagerly presented the "smart buoy."
With the permission of the commissioners, the Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission will put the buoy in the harbor to monitor water levels and flooding.
"What this buoy will do is it measures sea state, so we get sea surface temperature, we get wave action on the surface," Thaler said. "And then we'll also have a pressure gage at the bottom of the mooring, which we'll be able to use to assess tidal head. So that'll give us both the actual tidal cycle coming into the harbor, as well as any storm surges coming up from the bay."
According to Thaler, one of the long-term goals of the commission is to look into the viability of having the town's own tide gage.
The reasoning behind this goal is to gather specific data of St. Michaels tide pH. Currently, the data gathered for nuisance flooding, tidal surges and storm surges come from three sites. The sites are gages from Cambridge, Annapolis and Clayburn. Which are too far from St. Michaels to accurately gather information for the town.
Thaler said last year the commission applied for an equipment grant from So Far Ocean, a company that makes smart buoys. The presented device will gather data in real time and is solar powered.
Thaler said the location of the smart buoy will not interfere with boat traffic and will be located in the lagoon between Honeymoon Bridge and Mill Street. It comes at no cost to the town.
After the presentation, the St. Michaels commissioners thanked Thaler and the Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission for all their efforts. Commissioners will vote on the use of a smart buoy during a future meeting.

title: Historic Sotterley screens, holds panel discussion on 'Grandma's Hands'
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Historic Sotterley screens, holds panel discussion on 'Grandma's Hands'

 November 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 665
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Family recipes are passed down through the generations and the film "Grandma's Hands" focuses on six Southern Maryland individuals who cherish those recipes.Historic Sotterley held a screening and panel discussion with the stars of the film along with writer, executive producer, director and narrator Craig Sewell on Nov. 13 at the museum in Hollywood.
"This was a passion project for me," said Sewell. "Kitchens are magic places, whether they're commercial kitchens or home kitchens, because it's about where everything happens. It's where smiles happen and tears happen and stories happen and the aromas happen. Kitchens are places where people come together."
The 58-minute film was funded through a Maryland Heritage Areas Authority grant and filmed by the Southern Maryland National Heritage Area.
"Ask someone about their grandmother and chances are the story will quickly end up in the kitchen. And once there, the real story begins," Sewell said to open the film. "Lives change, but the food will always be with us. Food is powerful. It nourishes our bodies, it excites our tastes, it is infused and marinated in emotion and it provides us with a solid connection to our past. For generations our grandma's hands have made memories, continued traditions and blessed us with the knowledge of who we are."
The film stars six individuals who recreate their grandmother's recipes: Lexington Park's Teandre Thompson (bread pudding), Waldorf's Mary Louise Booth Webb (crackling bread), Newburg's Tiffany Barber (tomato sauce with meatballs), Benedict's Franklin A. Robinson (chili sauce), Greenbelt's LaWann Stribling (macaroni and cheese) and Lothian's Kayla Griffith (sweet potato pancakes).
Thompson said her grandmother Theresa Young would create "a masterpiece dessert using a few ingredients and her hands. She didn't use measuring cups and spoons; she did it just by sight. I'm not that daring yet."
The 98-year-old Webb, who cooked the dish in her grandmother's farm kitchen located near Zekiah Swamp, said it was made as a way to use everything of the pig.
Robinson, who lives at Serenity Farm, said his grandmother would make the sauce at the end of the tobacco harvest.
"For me these recipes are a way of keeping all of these people I've known alive," Robinson said. "Every time I open the cookbook, I remember my grandmother at her wood stove and my other grandmother who lived on another farm. It's remembering them and honoring them."
Barber, who lives on Grace Haven Farm, said her grandmother would take Wonder bread, slather it with the sauce and layer it with Parmesan cheese.
"My grandmother's recipes were the center of my childhood," Barber, who still uses her grandmother's cast iron skillet, said in the film, "and it's something I carry forward with my kids."
Barber said dinner at her two-table dining room — which is essential for eight children and five grandchildren — "became that place where you learned to express yourself, having conversations about what matters to you and those connections. Dinner matters, meals matter. It's the connection you build around that meal."
Griffith, who lives on the family farm, said her grandmother Lillian would make pancakes with chocolate chips, whipped cream, sprinkles, "the whole nine yards"
"She could not sit down for more than a minute or two," she added. "She would get up, make sure everyone had something on their plate. To most of us she would say, 'You don't have enough,' but [to my grandfather it would be] 'Earl, you're eating too much.'"
The film viewing earlier this month was the season finale of Historic Sotterley's Common Ground series.
"Throughout the peninsula that is Southern Maryland, people have gathered, cooked for centuries," Sewell says in the opening minutes of the film. "The recipes are messengers from whence we came. Food and recipes can divide a family, a region, even a culture."
Maryland Public Television will air a 27-minute version of the film — focusing on three of the cooks — at 7 p.m. Saturday, Nov. 23.
The hour-long version of the film will premiere on mpt.org, pbs.org and the PBS app starting on Sunday, Nov. 24.
Find out more about the film at destinationsouthernmaryland.com/discover/grandmas-hands.

Maryland kids celebrated in Times Square national Down syndrome video

 September 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: News

 Five kids from Southern Maryland appeared in the annual National Down Syndrome Society Times Square video in New York City on Saturday.The one-hour video will show over 500 photographs including children, teens and adults with Down syndrome from all 50 states and 11 countries, a release from the National Down Syndrome Society said. The photos of Ellie Griffin, Norah Smith, Harrison Bonovitch, Arthur Schaefer and Josiah Gross were selected from more than 2,600 entries in the society's call for photos.
Ellie, Norah and Arthur are from St. Mary's County and Harrison and Josiah are from Calvert County. Their photos will be displayed on two screens in Times Square above Dos Caminos restaurant in Father Duffy Square.
Ellie is 5 and was diagnosed with Down syndrome when she was born, Jessica Griffin, Ellie's mom, said. Ellie was also selected to be in the video in 2022, but this is the first time the family is going to New York to see it.
"I can't wait to see her reaction," Griffin said before the event. "Hopefully she realizes what's happening."
While Ellie might not understand everything that's happening, her 8-year-old brother is excited and "thinks she's famous," the mother said.
Outside of the national society, the family participates with other Down syndrome organizations, Griffin said. They do fundraisers with the Down Syndrome Diagnosis Network and have raised over $20,000 to connect families who are new to the condition, in which a person is born with an extra chromosome causing mild to moderate cognitive disability, developmental delays and physical challenges.
"It's amazing the support that we get through our community," Griffin said.
Griffin is also a parent volunteer with Jack's Baskets, which hand delivers baskets with gifts and resources for families to celebrate babies with Down syndrome.
The Times Square video presentation kicks off the New York City Buddy Walk. The walk has taken place in New York City since 1995 as part of the National Buddy Walk Program.
The National Down Syndrome Society video allows Ellie and the other Southern Maryland residents to advocate the message of inclusion, Griffin said. The photos were taken by 21FIVE Photography by Teresa Tucker, a resident in Southern Maryland who did free photoshoots for the kids to submit to the society.
"Everyone's goal is to support their kids and help them be the best versions of themselves," Griffin said.
Ellie does not have a lot of words, but she is a huge Taylor Swift fan, Griffin said. When Swift plays Ellie screams "Tay Tay" and starts dancing and singing.
"She's been hitting a lot of the words to the songs," Griffen said. "We think it's actually helped improve her language and speech skills."
The presentation was slated to be live-streamed on the National Down Syndrome Society Facebook page from 9:30 to 10:30 a.m. on Sept. 6.

 EASTON — Shawna Payne issued a reminder to more than 100 people gathered in the Avalon Theatre April 9 — "You have been chosen."The phrase was a call to action. Despite any self-doubt, Payne said, those gathered in the theater that evening were there to celebrate their own accomplishments and honor their potential to initiate positive change.
In the crowd were some of more than 200 nominees for this year's Women to Watch magazine, an annual publication by APG Chesapeake recognizing the contributions of women to Mid-Shore workplaces and communities.
The women, who were nominated via an online portal by coworkers, friends, spouses and loved ones, represented a wide swath of Mid-Shore change-makers.
"It was a wonderful evening to celebrate the power, success and perseverance of women to watch in the Mid-Shore," said Orestes Baez, regional president of APG Chesapeake. "Everyone had a great story to tell and a great energy to share. APG Chesapeake did a wonderful job putting all the pieces together. We are thankful for the opportunity to share it with the public."
The event marked the launch of the fifth Women to Watch magazine, a preliminary printed version of which was unveiled at the Avalon that evening. The magazine will be inserted into the Star Democrat and available online April 23.
Payne, who works through her nonprofit The BE Academy to empower women entrepreneurs, is one of 14 women featured in this year's edition. She was the first of three speakers to offer advice to those gathered April 9.
Yixin Qiu, co-founder of Apollo's Dream Foundation and a technical project manager for Qlarant, shared how she has worked to generate positive change in the Eastern Shore community that welcomed her as an immigrant a decade ago. Qiu helped found a nonprofit aiding senior citizens with digital literacy.
Jackie Wilson, senior vice president at Burke and Herbert Bank, shared advice for women experiencing change or uncertainty in their careers. She encouraged women to embrace change and rely on their expertise and the expertise of their teams to navigate challenges.
"What an uplifting evening," said Betsy Griffin, APG Chesapeake general manager for sales and marketing. "It was great to see Mid-Shore women connecting and networking with other leaders. We are honored to provide a refreshing evening celebrating these women who serve in the community and excel in their workplaces. Maryland author takes bestseller lists by storm with self-love book

 NORTH EAST — If there was ever a day to launch a book about love, Valentine's Day would be it, as North East author Trista Polo discovered when her first book, "Self-Love Shenanigans", shot to the top of bestseller charts overnight.Polo, 52, described the book — which launched Valentine's Day on Amazon's Kindle store — as a "resource manual for self-worth," which she hopes will help readers to achieve and embrace the power of self-love. Each chapter provides readers with new ways to level up their self-worth, conveyed through a tone that Polo said is fun and inviting.
"The book is called 'Self-Love Shenanigans' because I didn't want it to be too serious," Polo said, "It is a serious topic but it is also fun and I wrote it the same way I would say it."
Polo's inspiration for the book follows her self-love journey and her experiences. Through her journey, Polo said she began to realize that she was developing knowledge and mindsets that other people tend to struggle with.
She explained that she has struggled with self-love and self-worth her whole life and that her book is home to all of the work she has done and what has worked for her throughout her journey.
"Everything that is in the books is all things that I went through in my life and writing the book," Polo said. "I wasn't trying to reinvent the wheel, I just wanted to put it all in one place with my own spin on things by looking at things a bit differently to help people."
Complementing Polo's messages on self-love in the book are numerous activities involving journaling and other growth activities to help readers build a deeper connection with the content.
Polo said that her inspiration to include activities in her book stems from her value of putting action behind learning.
"You can read everything about self-love but without action, I assert, it will not make much difference which is why the activities are important- so people can bring and apply the content to themselves," Polo said.
The 147-page book was mostly written before Polo and her husband moved from New York to a home on North East's Main Street last year. While simultaneously writing her book, Polo started the Self-Love Shenanigans and Stories Collective Facebook group.
The group has over 175 members and serves as a hub for members to share their experiences, self-love tips and new ways to achieve self-love. Since moving to North East, Polo said her value of the community she is creating has grown.
"Walking Main Street every morning really gives me a sense of being part of a community," Polo said. "Being in an area that is this community centered, I started to see the bigger picture and realize that it is not just about myself and my readers, it is about the community that we are creating around self-love and its value."
Polo noted that she hosted a virtual launch party for her book Tuesday night. Readers and supporters from all over the country attended — buying her book the second sales went live on Amazon.
The book is currently on sale for $0.99 cents.
As of press time Thursday, "Self-Love Shenanigans" is ranked number one in several of Amazon's bestseller categories, including Journal Writing, Women's Inspirational Spirituality and the New Age Self-Help category.
Since launch, Polo said she has received overwhelmingly positive feedback from her readers.
"My heart is so full because of the feedback I have received so far," Polo said. "You write something and you hope it is good and makes a difference so to have the book make a positive impact bigger than I could have imagined, it brings me to tears when I think about it."
Currently, "Self-Love Shenanigans" is only available virtually through Kindle. Polo is preparing to deploy the book in paperback within the coming weeks, and plans to collaborate with Cecil County retailers to sell her product.
Polo also plans to work with Cecil County libraries to host events and workshops involving self-love exercises outlined in her book along with other activities.
"My book is not about convincing yourself into something positive you do not believe," Polo said. "It is all about being open to the idea that 'maybe it is true' and starting to believe it and it has been wonderful to be able to help people and share what I know."

title: Caroline County officials share why substance use awareness is bigger than just a month
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County officials share why substance use awareness is bigger than just a month

 September 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 793

 Read News Document

 DENTON — While all Caroline County substance use awareness programs acknowledge the importance of "Caroline Goes Purple" in September, they know the work is done all year-round.The Caroline County Health Department credits this work for a dramatic reduction in overdoses.
According to Health Department officials, in 2023, Caroline County experienced 19 overdoses. In 2024, the number was less than 11 overdoses, and that trend seems to be continuing this year.
When number is under 11, the county is not allowed to share the exact number due to state regulations, officials said.
The efforts to reduce overdoses are celebrated during the month of September, when the county holds multiple substance use awareness events to connect residents to services the county provides. Jessica Tuel, director of Caroline County Behavioral Health and director for Caroline Goes Purple, said all these events are designed to show residents they're not alone.
"I think that people need to understand that a lot of these events are obviously to bring education and prevention services, but it's also to provide connection to those who are experiencing substance use," Tuel said. "We have a motto here. It is 'the opposite of addiction is not sobriety, it is human connection.' So, by bringing these things to the community, number one, it gives a level of education and prevention services, but it also helps those who have been through it or going through it know that they're not alone."
This is a goal stakeholders in Caroline County try to meet outside of September.
Monthly, the county and several municipalities hold joint meeting, called the Drug Free Caroline Group, to close gaps in service so the county can be strong year-round.
"We have a local drug and alcohol council meeting once a month to discuss trends that's happening," said Sloane Franklin, Caroline County state's attorney. "It has the law enforcement, courts, mental health, and substance abuse counselors, clergy, county behavioral health or substance abuse programs… We talk about grants that might be available to our partners to go out, and I seek those grants so they can continue to provide services to these people."
These services include a "safe station" located at the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.
The safe station allows an individual to come into the Sheriff's Office and say, "I need help." An off-duty officer will then search the person and confiscate any paraphernalia without charging the person.
The Sheriff's Office also has an on-site peer, Kristie Thompson, five days a week in partnership with the Sante Group. Thompson goes into the community and makes residents aware of options available.
Thompson said the goal is to get the individual experiencing substance-related difficulties into inpatient treatment.
"Our partnership and relationship with Sante Group is is definitely a high point for the county as far as being able to provide this service to citizens of Caroline County," Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker said. "As far as working out of this building, having one of their employees here being able to people who are in distress needing support services or wanting to get off controlled dangerous substances, I think that is definitely a high point when you can take somebody and give them the services they need."
The Health Department is another community partner that helps residents be aware of the dangers of substance use and their options. Tuel highlighted some of the services the Behavioral Health extension offers.
"We have a level one outpatient mental health and substance use program," Tuel said. "We serve a lot of different people throughout various stages of substance use. We provide medication-assisted treatment, as well and we have clinicians in the schools. We do mobile treatment for adults and for kids at the both high schools, and we're expanding into the middle schools. We try to offer as many services as we are able to as a public health system."
Tuel said the key to reducing overdoes in the county has been including peers who have lived the experience to help others still struggling.
"I think that in the last couple of years, we've done a really great job of including peers," Tuel said. "Peers are those who have lived experience and are on the other side of it. They've really given us a great perspective and hope that we're doing the right thing and that there is success in this.
"I think that sometimes as first responders, and sometimes people in our field, what happens is we get very discouraged because we don't see the hope at the end. Having peers embedded in a lot of these services, like at the sheriff's department and in our services at the Health Department and throughout the community, it really even gives us hope that we're doing the right thing and that we're on the right path and that people can heal and they can get better."

title: Bikes, scooters need to show caution
author: Staff Writer
content:
Bikes, scooters need to show caution

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 398
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last week, I met and spoke with Easton Police Department Officer Hugo Galan while walking on the Rails to Trails. We talked after he spoke to a man riding a motorized bicycle about keeping safety in mind as he traveled the trails.I told him my concerns about more and more riders of electric bikes, scooters and skateboards whizzing along on the trails with seemingly little regard for pedestrians. If these riders were on the street, the speed probably wouldn't be as noticeable, but when you're walking, it feels really fast as they zip by, startling because you often don't hear them until they're next to you.
And, it happens without warning, like signaling with the ringing of a bicycle bell behind you, or, as some kindly people do, call out to let you know what side they're passing on. Careless riders will zig-zag at top speed between older adults walking dogs, little kids on bikes and scooters, or moms pushing strollers with small children in tow. It's frightening to watch because one misstep could result in something terrible.
The Rails to Trails through Easton is a pedestrian highway for hundreds of people. Some without transportation use it to get to jobs. Schoolchildren use it to get to and from school. And for others, it's a daily exercise routine or a way to simply enjoy the outdoors. But with more motorized bikes, scooters and even skateboards, the safety and peacefulness of walking on the trails has changed. Walkers have to factor in the possibility of being hit, adding a lot more caution to each stroll.
Easton residents have been speaking up about the uptick of speeding on the trails, expressing concerns to the police department and to town officials. Officer Galan said the Easton Police Department has expanded its outreach and patrols to increase safety awareness among riders, urging them to slow down as they approach walkers and runners. I applaud these conversations, the extra patrols and other actions the police take each day, particularly at night when no one should be on the trails or in the parks, to keep all of us safe.
It is reassuring to see officers on the trails engaging with the public in positive ways to increase everyone's awareness. But most importantly, riders need to show more courtesy to walkers and slow down. We all use the trail and we want to enjoy it safely.
BARBARA SAUERS
Easton

title: Tony Shalhoub returns as "Monk" in new Peacock movie
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Tony Shalhoub returns as "Monk" in new Peacock movie

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: D12 | Section: News 
 
 502
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With the way that popular series of the past have been recycled - even in the streaming era that has added so much content - the second coming of "Monk" may not be that huge a surprise.As it happens, streaming is the avenue by which Tony Shalhoub is reprising his multiple-Primetime Emmy-winning portrayal of obsessive-compulsive detective Adrian Monk. Peacock premieres "Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie" on Friday, Dec. 8, with the hugely phobic title character on a very personal mission to help his journalist step-daughter Molly ("Home Economics" alum Caitlin McGee) when tragedy strikes as her wedding nears. The film might claim that this is Monk's final investigation, but of course, a ratings triumph for the picture can change that notion easily. (Consider that there have been three movie sequels to another former USA Network series, "Psych," and a fourth has been under discussion.) Also an executive producer of the new film, Shalhoub isn't the only "Monk' veteran returning for it. Series creator Andy Breckman ("The Good Cop") wrote the script and returns as an executive producer as well (with "Hit & Run's" David Hobernan also reprising the latter job), and Randy Zisk ("Midnight Caller") - who directed many of the original show's episodes, including the finale - calls the shots again on the movie.Other familiar faces from the "Monk" cast also are back. Traylor Howard ("Two Guys, a Girl and a Pizza Place") again plays Natalie Teeger, who was Monk's second assistant on the show; Ted Levine ("The Silence of the Lambs," 1991) and Jason Gray-Stanford ("A Beautiful Mind," 2001) return as the police-connected Leland Stottlemeyer and Randy Disher; Hector Elizondo ("Last Man Standing") resurfaces as psychiatrist Neven Bell; and Melora Hardin ("The Office") resurfaces as Monk's late wife Trudy."Monk" premiered on USA Network in 2002 and enjoyed an eight-season run, with Shalhoub earning three Primetime Emmy Awards for it along the way. John Turturro ("Barton Fink," 1991) and Stanley Tucci ("Big Night," 1996) each picked up an Emmy for guest stints on the show, and Randy Newman ("Toy Story," 1995) won two of the honors for his musical contributions to it. Shalhoub also won a Golden Globe and two Screen Actors Guild Awards for the program.The series brought stardom to Shalhoub after his tenure as a respected supporting actor on stage and screen. When "Monk" began, he was known to viewers largely as Antonio on the sitcom "Wings," and he also had gained notice for roles in such movies as "Big Night" (1996, with the aforementioned Tucci) and "The Siege" (1998). He also had earned the first of what would be his four Tony Award nominations to date, for "Conversations With My Father" (1992); his others have been for "Golden Boy" (2013), "Act One" (2014) and "The Band's Visit" (2017), and he won the honor for the latter play.For now, though, it's back to "Monk" territory for Shalhoub's - and though "Last" is in the movie's name, don't necessarily bank on that being the fact.

 A projected $640,000 lunch debt is straining the Charles public school system's budget.Additionally, a sinkhole, broken fire alarms and faulty HVAC systems are among the pressures forcing the school board to shuffle $5.7 million across its internal 2025 fiscal budget — not to spend more, but to stay within the current year's total budget.
Last week during a school board meeting, Chief Financial Officer Karen Acton and Budget Manager Sherri Fisher-Davis detailed a large budget transfer to cover a range of categories from emergency repairs to unpaid student meal balances, which skyrocketed since pandemic federal meal funding ended.
"We cannot, by law, we cannot be over budget by category," Acton said at the June 10 meeting. "So, we have to move things back and forth."
The unplanned emergencies discussed at a previous board meeting, including a sinkhole, faulty HVAC systems and a series of fire alarm malfunctions, led to this reallocation of funds, Acton said.
She asked to move several funds in differing categories, including $1 million from contracted administration services, $3.5 million from instruction, salary and wages (to cover teacher wages during summer months), and $200,000 from special education (without disrupting programs, according to school officials).
Lunch debt is now projected to be $640,000 for the school year that just ended, a dramatic increase from pre-pandemic levels of roughly $18,000 to $20,000 per year. Board members said the debt likely stems from families choosing not to pay or failing to submit annual free/reduced lunch forms.
The school system did not respond for more information by deadline.
"These are families who make above whatever the threshold is to qualify and they are able to pay for lunch. They are able to pack their student's lunch. … There are options," board member Jamila Smith said. "It's a choice just not to pay."
The board provided school principals lists of students with outstanding balances to contact families, encouraging repayment plans and assisting with lunch forms.
"And we do recognize that families are in different situations now, given that there are work closures, reductions in force, a variety of things that are happening," Smith said. "But this has been going on well before that even began."
Board member Samichie Thomas emphasized the importance of filling out the lunch forms every year, or the school does not know if a family qualifies for the program that reimburses the school system for low-income students' lunches.
"I was a parent of four. You get all these forms and all these things at the beginning of the school year," Thomas said. "Make sure you take the time to fill out the form because that's how the school can help you. … You can do it online."
The board is now considering stronger actions, including possibly sending unpaid debts to collections. The board will revisit the issue in July once the end-of-year payment window closes and final figures are available, giving families until end of June to pay their outstanding balance.
For now, board members are stressing outreach at every level to make families aware.
Board member Dottery Butler-Washington said, "You have to say something three or four times for somebody to actually get it."
The full transfer plan vote is set for July when actual figures replace projections.
New substitute bus wages OK'dThe school board unanimously approved a raise for substitute bus drivers, boosting hourly wages.
New wages will be between $20 and 22.50, up $2.50 per hour. The increase, tied to 2026 budget, keeps pay competitive with full-time drivers and will cost an estimated $20,000 extra.

title: Museum opens art-making studio

 Hirshhorn Art School, a first-of-its-kind art education experience, opened inside the Smithsonian's Hirshhorn Museum on Oct. 30. Combining elements of a professional artist's studio, museum galleries and clubhouse, the new and flexible 1,700-square-foot hub will offer structured programming and open-studio sessions guided by museum educators and teaching artists four days a week for visitors of all ages."Hirshhorn Art School asks visitors to 'think like an artist,'" said Melissa Chiu, museum director. "When the Hirshhorn opened in 1974, museum education was in its infancy and largely grounded in observation. We've since found that experiential art learning is both highly effective and in demand."
Designed for varying ages, abilities and interests, Hirshhorn Art School programs will be organized into thematic, artist-focused semesters and will build on the work of Hirshhorn Kids and ARTLAB as well as public programs for adult audiences.
The first semester, "Boundary Breakers," will introduce the biographies, materials, techniques and philosophies of originals such as Anni Albers, Mark Bradford and Barbara Hepworth, whose artworks are on view. In its first year, Hirshhorn Art School expects to host more than 25,000 in-person visitors and 75,000 more virtually with livestreamed lessons and anytime resources.
Hirshhorn Art School offers programs Wednesdays–Saturdays:
Storytime Studio, Wednesdays, 10 a.m.–1 p.m.Children ages up to 8 years will connect an artwork on view with a children's book and engage in hands-on activities that develop self-expression and visual storytelling. Drop-ins welcome.
School Studio, FridaysGuided by museum educators and teaching artists, students in grades three through eight will explore the hows and whys of art-making, inspired by Hirshhorn collections and exhibitions. These weekly morning and afternoon sessions, lasting 60–120 minutes, must be reserved.
Open Studio, Saturdays, 10 a.m.–3 p.m.Guided by museum educators and teaching artists, visitors of all ages will be invited to respond to modern and contemporary art history, with a focus on Hirshhorn exhibitions. Drop-ins welcome.
Emerging Artists, Saturdays, 3–5:30 p.m.Teens ages 14–19 will collaboratively focus on the works of living artists. The debut season invites consideration of Bradford and his monumental work "Pickett's Charge" (2017). This program builds upon ARTLAB, the Hirshhorn platform for teens, which served an average of 4,000 student artists. Pre-registration is required.
As part of Hirshhorn Art School's outreach, art educators will continue to build upon the museum's library of almost 50 online projects and three free in-gallery activity guides. The Art School classroom has a built-in loop system to support visitors who use hearing aids, as well as a quiet area and tactiles.
Hirshhorn Art School is the public expression of Hirshhorn Education, a central pillar of the national museum of modern and contemporary art, whose mission amplifies the importance of the voices of artists on behalf of the Smithsonian Institution.
The Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden is the national museum of modern and contemporary art. Part of the Smithsonian, the Hirshhorn is located on the National Mall in Washington, D.C. For more information, visit hirshhorn.si.edu.

title: 'Barge-r' than life: Wye River Oyster Program ensures 21 million oysters in Wye River
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
'Barge-r' than life: Wye River Oyster Program ensures 21 million oysters in Wye River

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE RIVER — A small but mighty group of citizens, friends and neighbors dedicated to the preservation of the Chesapeake Bay, Wye River Oyster Program volunteers raised donations to plant 21 million spat-on-shell oysters to cover three acres of the Wye River bottom June 29.Focusing hyper local efforts, the Wye River Oyster Program is a non-profit, community initiative to restore oyster populations in the local Wye River.
The Chesapeake Bay is "the only water system like it in the world," and residents who live on the water are a unique community, regularly sharing information about the water and its resources, organizer Steve Burleson said.
Dedicated to the preservation of the watershed, the ball began rolling about a year ago, according to Burleson, when citizens gathered to see what additional initiatives could be done to further restoration efforts.
While conservancy groups are invaluable in education and advocacy, Wye River Oyster Program volunteers sought to have more direct and local impacts and discovered the Wye River as an oyster sanctuary right in their own backyard.
With little more than an idea and a talking point, the Wye River Oyster program hatched, with all-volunteer efforts ensuring 100% of donations go toward purchase of spat on shells, he said.
"This way we know exactly where the money is going," he said.
Every little bit helps, especially with the growing uncertainty of federal funding, he noted.
Primarily through word of mouth with other water enthusiasts, Wye River Oyster Program quickly raised money to partner with Ricky Fitzhugh of Seed to Shuck Ventures, and cover three acres of the Wye River bottom.
Based in Cambridge, Seed to Shuck's hatchery spawns new oyster larvae for spat on shell production and restoration projects on the Bay.
Seed to Shuck is an active partner with federal and state agencies, conservation organizations and watermen to plant new growth in oyster sanctuaries, public fisheries and private leases in Maryland and Virginia.
Each canister is home to approximately 675 bushels of oysters and the initiative planted three canisters, which makes up one barge, Burleson said.
According to Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR) estimates, about 15% of spat on shell grow to market size, and the DNR has been incredibly supportive of the initiative, he said.
An essential aspect of an entire ecology, oysters naturally filter pollutants and excess nutrients in the water and their reefs help restore submerged habitat, providing shelter and breeding grounds for a variety of marine life, according to Burleson.
By restoring oyster beds to historic areas, the Wye River Oyster Program aims to achieve significant improvements to the water quality of the Wye River for the benefit of the community and the ecosystem of the Chesapeake watershed.
Community interest throughout the entire initiative has been highly engaging, and supportive, Burleson said.
Several boats with numerous volunteers and river enthusiasts took to the water to watch the planting Sunday, June 29. The shell is washed off the boat onto the waiting river floor below the surface.
The Wye River Oyster Program seeks to make plantings an annual tradition and encourage more neighboring rivers to join in initiatives to locally support their waterways, according to Burleson.
The Wye River Oyster Program Fund is a non-profit of the Mid Shore Community Foundation.
More information about Seed to Shuck Ventures can be found at seedtoshuck.com.

title: Local author asks, does a kitten belong in school?
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Local author asks, does a kitten belong in school?

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 477
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Growing up in Massachusetts, in the mid-80's, second-grader Nancy Mugele, now Head of Kent School, a private day school in Chestertown, had an adorable and stubborn gray kitten that followed her to class.The affectionate feline was called Jingles. Her unique personality left a big impression because years later, the kitten would be the subject of Mugele's first children's book, "Jingles Goes to School."
Late October, Bumble Bee Books, the children's publishing department of Olympia Publishers, put out the book and can now be purchased at Bumblebee Books website, on Amazon, and locally here at the Book Plate, in downtown Chestertown.
Mugele based her book off her childhood, even mentioning her home, the house with the red shutters at 19 Bonney Lane. That was where Jingles escaped from back then, braving the New England winters to follow Mugele to school. Mugele's mother had to place her infant son in a stroller to come pick up Jingles.
"That's not normal behavior for a cat," Mugele said laughing.
This amusing anecdote is the plot of the book.
In between the colorful illustrated pages, Jingles displays to Nancy's teacher, Miss Bevivino, her class, and the principal, Mr. Willett, her love of learning. At one point, Jingles even plays the piano, "learning to trill in all the right places," at the school concert.
Will Jingles earn the affection of some of her harshest critics, like the principal?
One thing is for sure, Jingles loves school, and so does her creator, the Head of Kent School of nine years with a career in education over 20 years.
"It's really remarkable, the transformative power of books," Mugele expressed.
She witnesses this on a weekly basis, reading Jingles' adventures to her pre-k, kindergarten, and first graders, seeing their reactions.
"They absolutely love it. They ask a lot of questions. It's such a thrill when I show them actual pictures of Jingles, and see how their imaginations expand."
From her enjoyment of reading aloud to her students, she pitched her story to eight publishers, and heard back from three of them — no small feat for a new author.
Olympia Publishers appreciated that Mugele drew from her own experiences. They took care of the artwork and distribution, leaving Mugele to dream up future stories for Jingles.
In the meantime, "Jingles Goes to School," will be coming out in hardback Jan. 30, and in the near future the author plans to do local book tours. She will also be doing one for a friend at Farley's Bookshop in Pennsylvania.
Her passion however is to visit schools, reading to the kids.
"It is one of my most important meetings throughout the week," Mugele said.
She hones her writing skills on her blog site nancymugele.com, while envisioning new adventures to pen.
And as she looks for more inspiration from her life, nobody is safe, especially her lovable black lab, "River."
"He won't mind one bit if I make him the star," Mugele said with a smile.

title: Salisbury fine metal artisans prepare products for inauguration
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Salisbury fine metal artisans prepare products for inauguration

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business

 EASTON — On the workshop floor of Salisbury Inc., skilled men and women work attentively and proficiently under dozens of American flags. In their hands are sleek trays, cups and other products receiving careful changes under heavy machinery.Each person, in protective gear, carefully works to create countless commemorative products engraved with Americana symbols for the upcoming inauguration of President-elect Donald Trump.
More than 600 products were sent to Washington earlier this week, where they were received by members of Trump's team as part of a longstanding tradition at Salisbury.
The company has a rich history of providing engraved commemorative gifts for presidents and other government officials.
For over 30 years, Salisbury has crafted engraved pewter trays, picture frames, jewelry boxes and 700 other products showing appreciation for the country.
In preparation for the 2025 inauguration, the Salisbury team has been crafting items featuring Trump's signature and other symbols of the presidency.
Joseph Bernstein, sales manager for Salisbury, said they are proud to continue the tradition of pewter work.
"Pewter in itself has a rich history," Bernstein said. "Paul Revere was a pewter smith. Pewter was brought over from England to America, and we made it our own. So we have a rich tradition of making pewter smithing in this country.
"It is, in itself, Americana. They're valuable keepsakes and commemoratives that can be passed down for generations."
Bernstein said the company started crafting items for politicians during the Ronald Reagan presidency. During his time in office, Reagan had his presidential seal with his and first lady Nancy Reagan's signatures turned into Americana products.
Since then, the company has made similar products for U.S. senators and representatives, other presidents and for commemorative events.
The products being prepared with engraved signatures will have several uses, Bernstein shared. Some of the products are in preparation for the president-elect, who, according to Bernstein, purchases the products from Salisbury with donations and uses them as gifts and for personal use.
During Trump's last term in office, his team would order between 50 to 100 pieces from time to time, sometimes putting in orders for additional products when he was traveling to visit other leaders nationally and internationally.
Additionally, different organizations will purchase the products to use for events.
According to Bernstein, Salisbury's products are in no way a political statement, and the company has gone out of its way to stay out of politics due to polarization. The company is proud to serve Republicans, Democrats and other parties "all with the same respect."
For Bernstein, appreciation for Americana goes beyond political lines. He shared that julep cups, a drinking vessel traditionally used to serve mint julep, is his favorite type of product. Bernstein describes it as "if you were drinking from a fine leaded crystal, just one of those things that enhances the experience."
Overall, Bernstein said as they prepare for the inauguration of President Donald Trump, the company is working hard to provide its best products and is excited to continue to serve every political representative in the future.
"Salisbury has been around since 1979, and we are proud to be, to serve, we are proud to be on the Eastern Shore and commemorated, and proud to be a small part of commemorating our American heritage," he said.

title: Striped bass need summer vacation to thrive
author: ALISON COLDEN Bay Journal News Service
content:

 Author/Byline: ALISON COLDEN Bay Journal News Service | Section: Columns 
 
 815

 Read News Document

 There's a shift happening in Chesapeake Bay angling."People are pivoting, and they should be," said David Sikorski, executive director of the Coastal Conservation Association in Maryland. "It used to be all stripers all the time. I find now more people view angling as an experience on the water, versus needing to target an exact species."
Sikorski is worried about the dire state of the striped bass population. Recent years have seen troubling trends — below average numbers for five years straight in Maryland's juvenile striped bass survey, fewer citation-sized stripers being registered in Virginia, and a steep decline in the Bay's commercial striped bass catch.
There are many reasons for these trends, ranging from overfishing and climate change to pollution and loss of habitat. But changing fishing habits is the only immediate way to make a difference.
Chesapeake Bay states and the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission have taken action with new regulations. The tough new reality also is being met by a new generation of anglers.
While stripers remain a staple, other species — especially invasives like blue catfish and snakeheads — are increasing in popularity.
"Blue catfish are available in every tributary of the Bay and provide endless recreational angling options, with no limits," Sikorski said. "They're attracting new anglers across the watershed all year round."
The regional publication FishTalk hosts monthly invasive species fishing reports. On social media, hundreds of thousands of people are following catfish anglers like TikTok personality Haz Life Fishing and Ernest Robinson, whose half a million Instagram followers know him as Ernie the Hog Snatcher.
While fishing for schoolie stripers is tempting these warm summer days, it's also when striped bass are most vulnerable. With the right steps now, we can rebuild a healthy striped bass fishery for the future. Anglers can start by giving stripers a well-deserved summer vacation.
About 90% of striped bass caught recreationally are released, according to ASMFC stock assessment data. But a significant number of these fish die, especially on hot summer days.
Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission data assumes that about 9% of stripers that are caught and released will die from the stress. But that's the year-round number; the percentage is likely much higher in the summer, when heat causes low-oxygen levels in the water, increasing striped bass heart rates and hindering their ability to swim, find food and fight disease.
To address this, this year the commission established a catch-and-release mortality workgroup to explore options to reduce the loss of released fish.
Maryland also has implemented regulations prohibiting striped bass fishing from July 16 to July 31, when striped bass are particularly stressed by high temperatures. The Maryland Department of Natural Resources posts heat warnings when air temperatures are above 90 degrees.
The season will reopen Aug. 1 and run through Dec. 10. Anglers may keep one striped bass from 19 to 24 inches per person, per day.
Summer is prime time for catching many other species, including northern snakehead (also known as Chesapeake channa), white perch and yellow perch in the upper Bay and its rivers. In the southern Bay, where salinity is higher, expect to find cobia, red drum, speckled trout and Spanish mackerel.
Blue catfish can be caught in every Bay tributary, year-round. Introduced into the Bay watershed in the 1970s, these catfish have since become voracious predators of beloved native species like striped bass, oysters and blue crabs.
The Maryland Office of Tourism's Fish & Hunt Maryland recently added a Catfish Trail resource to help anglers target these aggressive and fun-to-catch predators. Many prime catfishing spots are easily accessible from the shore, where you can use basic tackle and cheap bait (try dipping raw chicken in Kool-Aid).
Blue cats also make for a great meal. Unlike other catfish species that are mainly bottom feeders, blue catfish have a more varied diet and are known for their tasty white, flaky fillets. Summer is an ideal time to catch the smaller, younger blue catfish that taste best.
If you do target stripers this summer, there are steps you can take to responsibly fish them. The maximum catch size for striped bass in the Bay is 24 inches, because bigger fish most effectively reproduce and rebuild the population. Older, larger females produce far more eggs and are key to repopulation efforts.
The last time we saw a strong number of juvenile striped bass in the Bay was in 2015. These have grown into the big fish being caught today.
Anglers can help ensure fish survival by practicing safe catch and release tactics, such as using barbless circle hooks, keeping fish in the water and supporting them with two hands if handling.
Sustainable fisheries require long-term forethought and, sometimes, short-term sacrifice. If we want a striped bass fishery in the future, we need to pivot. Let's give striped bass a summer break.
Allison Colden is the Chesapeake Bay Foundation's Maryland Executive Director. This commentary first appeared June 18, 2024, on Bayjournal.com and was distributed by the Bay Journal News Service.

title: Mid-Shore legislators express concern over tax hikes in governor’s budget proposal
author: Konner Metz
content:
Mid-Shore legislators express concern over tax hikes in governor’s budget proposal

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 793
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With the state facing a significant deficit, some Mid-Shore legislators are raising concerns that the governor's proposed budget may negatively impact local constituents and businesses.In his fiscal year 2026 budget proposal presented Wednesday, Gov. Wes Moore (D) suggested both tax cuts and increases, as well as spending cuts, to tackle the state's looming $3 billion budget gap.
Moore's proposal lays out two new tax brackets for high-income households: a 6.25% rate for those who make more than $500,000 and a 6.5% rate for those who make more than $1 million.
Meanwhile, it consolidates the state's bottom four tax brackets and doubles the standard deduction on tax returns, two measures expected to provide tax breaks to Marylanders, Moore says. The governor plans to reduce corporate taxes "to entice more businesses and drive growth."
But local legislators aren't fully on board with Moore's plans to offset the deficit. Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) shared his reaction after watching Moore's live press conference on Wednesday.
"My initial reaction was a little jaw-dropping," Hutchinson said. "I felt like it was a little bit of smoke and mirrors on the way that he was presenting the budget."
Hutchinson says while lower corporate taxes look "nice on the surface," he's most concerned for local small businesses with the new tax brackets.
"That's where it's really going to hurt the small business owners because they pass through a lot of their small businesses through their personal income taxes," Hutchinson said. "So it's going to be detrimental, actually, to small businesses in my opinion."
Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico) noted Moore's proposal to eliminate the inheritance tax as a positive. However, she's worried some of the spending reductions will burden counties, such as the expectation that counties will supplement proposed state reductions in teacher retirement funding.
Hutchinson and Del. Jeff Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) both likened Moore's tax hikes for the wealthy to tax increases seen under former Gov. Martin O'Malley (D).
Sample-Hughes and Ghrist are worried the tax increases will drive Marylanders elsewhere, specifically the "half-millionaires" and above.
"One of my fears is is that if we continually tax the upper bracket, they're going to … move to Delaware or move to other neighboring states," Sample-Hughes said.
"The folks who have the money, they reinvest in the economy with their wealth," Ghrist said. " … We're just shooting ourselves in the foot is what we're doing. It's terrible economic policy."
Hutchinson is optimistic the tax cuts in the lower brackets may help local residents, but he shares the other legislators' worries about the increases for wealthy residents.
"I think a lot of the local residents on the Shore will have a positive effect on the change to the lower tax bracket," Hutchinson said. "But my fear is sometimes we rob Peter to pay Paul. While we'll all stay because we love it and we want to be here, again, those high-income earners have the opportunity to go multiple places when there's a tax increase on their personal income tax."
MOVING FORWARDSince the Democrats have a firm majority in the legislature, some Republicans understand that there's limited ability to push forward their spending and tax policies.
"There's really not much we can do. We're outnumbered two to one," Ghrist said. "The only thing we can do is inform the public about what's going on, inform the public about what these impacts are going to be."
Ghrist believes it will "be an ugly session for taxpayers."
He and Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) say a better way to address the budget gap would be to find savings in government efficiency efforts.
"I look for things that are consensus ideas," Mautz said. He believes this year's budget will undergo more scrutiny than recent ones and potentially see "significant changes" during the legislative session.
Hutchinson says Republicans will be "very vocal," adding that some of his Democratic colleagues have their own concerns about the budget proposal.
"What was laid out on Wednesday — I am sure — is not going to be the final version that we see when we move forward in early April," Hutchinson said. "And we will be having a lot of debates over this issue. It is the number one issue."
Sample-Hughes said it's important for legislators to comb through ways in which government agency cuts can help reduce the budget gap. She wants to see that diligent work done before counties assume any more of the burden.
As for tax increases on Marylanders, Sample-Hughes is hoping that can be avoided given the current economic landscape.
"That's not something I'm supportive of because I know that the constituency is already grappling with a lot of financial burdens," Sample-Hughes said.
A final version of the state's 2026 budget must be passed by both chambers of the Maryland legislature before the end of this year's General Assembly in April.

title: Colonel tops Easton, evens slate
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Colonel tops Easton, evens slate

 December 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports

 Words

 AMERICAN CORNER — Easton High's wrestling team is rebuilding this season.Colonel Richardson?
Colonels head coach Bryan Hall winces at the idea of a rebuild, preferring to say, "We're filling in."
Colonel filled in quite nicely Wednesday night, scoring the first takedown in eight of the 10 matches wrestled en route to a 58-24 victory over Easton.
"It hurts 'cause we thought last year we had eight sophomore starters, three freshmen starters, and only one senior," Hall said. "But we've lost four of our starters from last year. One transferred to North Caroline. One is injured. Two decided not to come out. We lost some guys we were going to be counting on as part of our season, so we're filling in."
One of those filling in for Colonel, 120-pounder Elisee Pierre-Louis, won by injury default. Pierre-Louis was taking Otto Perez to the mat, when the Easton freshman injured his arm while trying to brace his fall. Perez was taken by ambulance to have the injury treated.
"That was a momentum punch in the gut for the guys," Easton head coach Jason Biringer said of losing Perez.
Easton (0-3) had built an early 12-0 lead on Skye Matthews' forfeit win at 106, and Esteban Velasquez' 1:59 pinfall over Brody Omohundro at 113.
The injury default cut Easton's lead in half, but Colonel (2-2) won the next three matches. Jayquan Wilkins crafted a 17-2 technical fall over John Seymour at 126, pulling Colonel within 12-11. Zy Nichols (132) and Evan Alexander (138) each won by forfeit, pushing the Colonels' lead to 23-12.
The Warriors stopped that streak when Adonis Schmidt pinned Trynton Parks in 59 seconds of the 144-pound match, drawing the visitors within 23-18.
But Colonel Richardson won six of the final seven matches, scoring bonus points in five of the bouts.
Anthony Alexander (150) started Colonel's roll, pinning Matthew Bravo just as the first-period buzzer sounded. Gary Koeneman (157) followed, working a 19-4 technical fall over Vlad Oslam. Colonel's Ethan Thomas then got turned to his back, yet rolled through on the way to a 2:47 pinfall over Darren Foxwell at 165, stretching the Colonel lead to 40-18.
"They wrestled amazing," Hall said of his team. "We've been shocked by Ethan Thomas. He's a freshman, just started wrestling last year in a middle school club. He's wrestling up a weight class and has been huge.
"Other guys we expected to win, won," Hall continued. "Other guys we're expecting to go out there and wrestle hard, are. It's been a good season so far."
Tony Melendez got Easton back in the win column with a 1:07 fall over freshman Brox Meissner at 175. But the Colonels closed the match, with Richard Taylor (190) pinning Wahaab Popal in 2:15, Wilson Clough (215) winning by forfeit, and Chatydrick Pickrom (285) pinning Matthew Brunner in 2:45.
Still, Biringer was encouraged by what he saw.
"We are seeing some better habits," Biringer said. "We're also seeing some self-destructive moves, where it's, 'Don't make up your own moves. Do the moves you're taught.' Usually when something bad was happening they were trying something that wasn't a fundamental move. So it's beginner's mistakes, but at the same time a lot more effort, and progress is being made."
Colonel's girls earned 39-22 victory in what was Easton's first girls dual meet. Each team won two of the four matches wrestled.
Colonel's Luna Infante-Reyes (115) pinned Leah Gonzalez-Reyes in 3:38, and Estelle Lima (190) earned a 7-0 decision over Khadija Popal.
Easton's wins came from Shiza Gondal (135), who pinned Lizzy Hesson, and Thanh Mai Pham (140), who earned a 10-2 major decision over Aiyanna Groce.

 In tournament bridge nowadays, almost everyone bids much more than they used to. One weapon in this armoury of attack is the five card weak two-bid. It isn't my style, but it does have its moments, like in today's deal.North expected a six-card suit opposite.Against four hearts doubled, West led the diamond ace: five, three, four. He continued with three rounds of hearts to stop a diamond ruff in the dummy.To make the contract, South had to establish a spade for a diamond discard, and he had to find the club queen. He played a spade to dummy's king, cashed the ace and ruffed a spade in hand.Declarer judged that West had three diamond honours because East hadn't played a higher diamond at trick one. Along with the heart ace-king and spade queen, that made at least 17 points.Clearly East, not West, had the club queen. However, South had to be careful.He led the club seven to dummy's king. Now followed a spade ruff, the club ace, a club to dummy's 10 and the fifth spade for a diamond discard.Well played!If East had covered the club jack, declarer would have won with his ace and played the club nine to dummy's 10. title: Dubois readies for another fresh start
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Dubois readies for another fresh start

 June 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 488
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The life Pierre-Luc Dubois envisioned for himself a year ago no longer exists.Back then, he had requested and been granted a trade from Winnipeg to Los Angeles, signed a contract for $68 million over the next eight seasons and thought he would be a big part of the Kings' future.
Instead, Dubois endured a disappointing, underproductive season and was traded again last week to the Washington Capitals for goaltender Darcy Kuemper.
Dubois turned 26 on Monday and has already been traded three times since 2021. After the first and second were wanted by him, the latest forced him to change his perspective quickly upon joining his fourth NHL organization.
"I don't think there's any time for anybody to feel sorry about themselves," Dubois said on a video call with reporters Wednesday, one year short of the anniversary of signing his current contract. "You learn in the hockey world teams will do what they think is better for their team, and there's no hard feelings. For me, I could take it multiple ways, but I'm choosing to take it as extra motivation and to just get myself ready for next season."
Dubois acknowledged he probably did not need more motivation after putting up just 40 points, the lowest of his career in a full, 82-game season. Kings general manager Rob Blake took responsibility for Dubois not being put in the right roles and the situation not being a great fit.
The trade gives Dubois, picked third by Columbus in the 2016 draft and traded to Winnipeg five years later for Patrik Laine and Jack Roslovic, another fresh start. Dubois is the Capitals' latest reclamation project, two summers after signing another center who was a No. 3 pick and already on his second team.
That one worked out swimmingly, with Dylan Strome establishing himself as an important part of Washington's evolving core in the final years of the Alex Ovechkin era. Strome and Dubois were actually roommates when they played together on Canada's world junior team in 2017.
"I'm sure that we'll push each other, and he'll teach me what he's learned already," Dubois said. "To be able to play with him again will be really fun and get to know him again. Obviously, we're in different stages in life, but it'll be exciting."
Dubois is at the stage of trying to get back on track. On three previous occasions he scored 27 or more goals in a season, and GM Brian MacLellan when acquiring him said Dubois had immense potential to be a top-tier player because of his size, skating and hockey IQ — in part because he's expected to have a bigger role than in L.A.
"It was exactly what you want to hear as a player: How excited they are, how I can help in a lot of ways for this team," Dubois said of his first conversation with MacLellan. "You want to feel welcome. You want to feel like you're a part of it."

title: 'Made with love': Delaware film festival will feature 58 short films
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
'Made with love': Delaware film festival will feature 58 short films

 August 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Newark Independent Film Festival is returning for its second year next week.The Delaware event is set for Aug. 14, 15 and 16 at Chapel Street Players on Creek View Road.
"We're offering audiences something completely different, something that was made with love," organizer Kazy Tauginas said. "Regardless of genre, the filmmakers that made these films, they put their souls into them, and you can feel it on the screen. I think that people will be very pleasantly surprised at the quality of the films that they're going to be watching."
The festival will feature 58 short films spanning many genres, including horror, drama, comedy, documentaries and art-house films. Filmmakers are coming from all over the United States and from as far away as Germany.
"Just hearing the stories and what people went through just to tell something that they felt was really important to them at that time, that separates us from what studio films are all made for," Tauginas said. "They're all profit-driven. Indies are a lot of times just driven by the heart."
There are also a number of films that were shot right here in Delaware, including "Return to Hockessin No. 107C," which is about the history of the Hockessin Colored School, and "Unseen American Dream," a documentary about a blind couple from Wilmington raising sighted children.
"Delaware locals have their own category at my festival," Tauginas said. "And then, of course, we have filmmakers from Los Angeles and New York and everywhere in between."
Tauginas is an actor, director and writer who has written and starred in more than 20 independent films. His acting career also has included guest spots in major television shows, and he has appeared in several movies, including "The Equalizer 2," starring Denzel Washington.
He lives in Newark and also works as a real estate agent and serves on the Newark Planning Commission.
The film festival will include the premier of the feature film "Mirror Life," which Tauginas wrote, directed and starred in. The movie is about a woman who's searching for her cousin who disappeared after entering an illegal human clinical trial.
Tauginas said that major film studios are moving more and more of their productions overseas, leading to fewer opportunities for actors here. That's part of what inspired him to start the film festival, to provide an opportunity to showcase more independent films.
"Filmmakers are going to be able to see their film on screen, in front of an audience, on the big screen with a dynamic sound system in a proper venue, so that it can get the attention that it deserves," he said. "I think it's a really important thing, especially for independent artists."
He added that he hopes the festival is an economic boost for Newark as the filmmakers from out of town arrive in Newark, stay at the Hyatt Place hotel on Main Street and patronize local restaurants and shops.
Tauginas, who used to own the Korner Diner on Main Street, said he knows that the summer is a slow time for Newark businesses. With a location right off Interstate 95 and a walkable downtown, Newark is a great place for the festival, he said.
"I can't think of a better place that you would want a film festival," he said.
The Newark Independent Film Festival will show 58 films in seven blocks spread over three days. Tickets for each block are $15. For more information and to buy tickets, visit newarkindependentfilmfestival.com.

 CHESTERTOWN - Excitement filled the Animal Care Shelter for Kent County in Chestertown on Nov. 11, as Claire Anderson-Schultz, Amelia Beach, Clara Gerber and Ayesha Tapia brought in lots of handmade supplies and needed items to the shelter. These four sixth graders earned their Bronze Award for Girl Scouts by setting their sights on helping the cats and dogs at the shelter.To earn their Bronze Awards, the girls from Troop 899 in Centreville had to complete 20 hours of service in a service project. Sharing a love for animals, it was easy to decide that the project would help animals in need. Claire's mom shared that Claire has been visiting animal shelters for years with her grandfather to spend time cuddling the animals after school.This past summer, the girls toured the facility to learn about what the shelter did and what it needed. From June to September, the girls worked independently and as a team to meet these needs. After reaching out and doing research, the girls learned the ACSKC had recently moved into a new building and had many needs.These needs included: a new cat tree, cat and dog toys, pet food and treats, new storage benches, and cleaning items. The girls explained the shelter had to throw out a beautiful, carpeted cat tree due to a sickness that had hit the shelter. The girls quickly began their mission to make a cat tree that was easy to clean and maintain.During these 20 hours or more of time, the girls strategized in meetings (in person and on Zoom) on how to meet these needs and then worked together to create and build the items needed. The cat tree was thoughtfully made, and with a little help from their parents, the girls found a plan that would use easy-to-clean PVC pipes. After making sure the pipes fit, they glued them together and painted them gold. The girls also made Velcro patches of fabric from reused clothing. "These fabric patches were made from my grandpa's old jackets and now they can be velcroed off and on for easy washing" explained Amelia.Shelter worker, Paige Tucker, said they currently have 109 dogs and cats at the animal shelter. Right now, there are 32 animals in need of homes. Allison Otadan, Shelter Media Coordinator, shared the shelter is "so grateful for the efforts of the girls" for the new cat trees and other pet items. She is excited for the new benches, as the current benches are all scratched up. At this shelter, there are special rooms for the animals to freely roam, but that also causes some of the items to get worn down and scratched. In addition to the cat tree and wooden benches, the girls sewed catnip toys, hand tied snuffle mats (where pet treats can be hidden and found), and collected lots of donations from their whole troop, grades kindergarten through fifth grade.If you would also like to help the shelter, they are currently in need of kitten food, cat food, dog food, and cat/dog treats. There is a complete Wish List on their website that includes the specific brands needed at https://acskc.org/
