title: Easton High School graduate dies in car crash
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton High School graduate dies in car crash

 June 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 386
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Easton community is mourning the death of recent high school graduate Darren Foxwell.Foxwell, 18, died following injuries sustained as a passenger in a single-vehicle car crash just outside Trappe on Tuesday morning. He was transported to Shock Trauma in Baltimore for treatment of life-threatening injuries. He died on Wednesday afternoon, his family said on Facebook Thursday.
In a Facebook post on Wednesday, Darren's father, Len Foxwell, wrote that the family is "eternally grateful for everyone who has sent their love and support, for those who have stepped up with profound gestures of support, and for Darren's friends who drove here from Easton yesterday to say goodbye to their childhood buddy."
"Each of you have been a lifeline and have honored Darren in your own special way," Len Foxwell wrote.
His father added that the team at Shock Trauma in Baltimore "fought like a tiger to keep Darren comfortable, preserve his dignity and provide solace for a family that has been destroyed."
A member of Easton High School's wrestling and lacrosse teams, Foxwell graduated last month. He planned to attend Bethany College in West Virginia this fall and play lacrosse for the Bison.
Foxwell played the last two years for Easton as a backup defenseman. Easton High boys head lacrosse coach Dennis Keenan said he was popular among his teammates and had a "bright future."
"I think he was funnier than he actually thought he was," Keenan said. "The things he would say would just crack me up. He was getting better each day. You could see flashes of brilliance."
Foxwell wrestled for three years at Easton, including under head coach Jason Biringer during his senior year. Biringer said Foxwell had an "infectious" personality.
Early this past season, Foxwell stepped away from the wrestling team. But after speaking with his coach, he returned and started at the 167-pound weight class for the Warriors.
After returning to the team, Biringer made Foxwell a team captain because of Foxwell's work ethic and focus.
"The other wrestlers looked up to him," Biringer said. "He has such a good, gentle demeanor that he was just very well liked."
"He just had one of those infectious smiles that you're like, 'It's always good to see Darren,'" Biringer added.
Family said on Thursday that arrangements for funeral services and a celebration of life are being made and will be announced soon.

title: Warriors survive Bulldogs' rally
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Warriors survive Bulldogs' rally

 September 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 836
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — It didn't matter that North Caroline High's football team had lost its first two games this season.The Bulldogs just scared Easton head coach Matt Griffith. And in a furious fourth-quarter span of just over four minutes they showed why, shaving a 28-point Warrior lead to just seven.
That's when Mikey O'Connor took over. Easton's senior quarterback ran for a pair of first downs and threw for another in the final 2:52 Friday night to finally secure a 28-21 victory that pushed the Warriors' record to 3-0.
"They got great athletes all over the field," Griffith said of North Caroline. "They've struggled early on, but you saw exactly how explosive they can be, and how quick they can be explosive. That's what I was worried about. Sometimes you can do all the right things, but sometimes really good athletes can make plays. And that's a lot of what happened in the last five minutes of the twilight zone that we're calling it."
O'Connor hit Diontaye Copper for a 35-yard touchdown pass 1:41 into the third quarter, and Dominic Stanco tacked on the point-after kick for a 28-0 Easton lead.
The Warriors had not allowed a point all season until North Caroline's Tyson Weber scored on a 16-yard run with just under seven minutes left in the game, drawing the Bulldogs (0-3) within 28-7. Mason Shilling added the extra point.
Easton went three-and-out on its next possession, with O'Connor booting a quick kick to North Caroline's 27. Bulldog senior quarterback Corey Bunce hit Derek Jones for 13 yards, then connected with Zymear Smith for a 33-yard pickup. Weber scored on a 27-yard touchdown run on the next play and Shilling again converted the PAT, narrowing Easton's lead to 28-14 with 3:57 left.
North Caroline recovered the ensuing onsides kick at the Warrior 47. Bunce hit Jones for a 20-yard gain. Easton's Tymiere Thomas sacked Bunce for a 5-yard loss. But the Bulldogs' quarterback fired toward the end zone on the next play, and watched the ball deflect into the hands of Jones for a 33-yard touchdown. Shilling's point-after kick made it 28-21 with 2:52 remaining.
"Hell of a comeback," North Caroline head coach Nic McMorris said. "I'm so proud of the resilience of our guys. It was the first time that we recognized this team.
"They're a great team," McMorris added of Easton. "They have such a dynamic offense. But we were moving the ball and just kept shooting ourselves in the foot. And then we just started playing inspired football."
North Caroline drove from its 38 to the Easton 12 when it fumbled the ball away late in the first quarter. But the Bulldogs regained possession four plays later when O'Connor's pass was deflected and intercepted by Smith. Again Caroline moved the ball, marching 32 yards to the Warrior 8. But the Bulldogs again fumbled, with Easton recovering at the 1.
Easton's next drive ended with a fumble, giving North Caroline possession at the Warrior 25. But North Caroline went no where on three plays. Shilling came on to attempt a 40-yard field goal, but slipped on his approach, the kick falling well short.
The Warriors, who took a 7-0 lead on O'Connor's 3-yard touchdown run and Stanco's PAT with 3:54 left in the first quarter, stretched their lead to 14-0 with 2:11 left in the first half, when Jordan Horsey slammed in from five yards out. Stanco again made the extra point.
Easton took advantage of a short Caroline punt, as O'Connor hit Carter Mooney for 18 yards, and Copper for 17 yards before scoring on a 2-yard run for a 21-0 halftime lead.
"We came out with a game plan and we executed very well," Griffith said. "I think we did a lot of really good things early, even with two turnovers. Those are our first two turnovers of the year. We were able to bounce back."
So was North Caroline.
"No excuses," Griffith said. "Caroline's a good football team. They're a very good football team for being 0-3."
It's one-time 28-point cushion reduced to just seven, Dustin Blue recovered the onsides kick for Easton after North Caroline had gotten within 28-21.
O'Connor ran for three yards before Caroline called time. O'Connor then ran for eight yards and a first down. North Caroline stuffed Easton's quarterback for no gain on the next play and again burned a timeout. O'Connor then fired an 11-yard dart to Carter Mooney for a first down, then found room around left end for a 22-yard pickup and a first down that clinched the win. O'Connor took a knee on the next two plays to bleed the final minute.
'We got up and then we just kind of let off," O'Connor said. "And we just can't do that against a great team like this. Great first half. Then the second half we slipped off. But we need to play two halves of football."
Griffith agreed but applauded his quarterback.
"He did a phenomenal job," Griffith said of O'Connor. "And he took control at the end of the game to make sure we were able to seal the victory."

title: Dorchester County Council passes property registration, accessory structure bills
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester County Council passes property registration, accessory structure bills

 March 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 396
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Council passed two housing-related bills at its meeting on March 5.The first bill establishes property registrations for vacant buildings, short-term rentals and rental units. These properties and units would need to be registered with the county annually.
Short-term rentals are defined as properties that are rented for more than 15 days and less than 30 days.
At a council meeting Feb. 6, County Planning and Zoning Director Susan Webb said the intent of creating these three different registrations is life safety and property maintenance.
She said with these registrations, the county would be able to contact property managers and owners in case of an emergency. Webb also said that the registrations would keep property owners accountable when it comes to property maintenance and following county codes and regulations.
The second bill the County Council passed on March 5 amends the zoning chapter of the county code to lessen restrictions on residential accessory structures.
The amendment makes it so that, for lot size of up to 1.99 acres, a residential accessory structure can't exceed 200% of the building footprint of the principal residential structure.
For a lot size of two acres to 4.99 acres, a residential accessory structure can't exceed 300% of the building footprint of the principal residential structure.
For a lot size of five acres or more, a residential accessory structure can't exceed 500% of the building footprint of the principal residential structure.
Before this bill was passed, for suburban residential, suburban residential-RCA, rural residential and rural residential-RCA zoning districts, the sum total of residential accessory structures on a property couldn't exceed the building footprint of the principal residential structure or 1,200 square feet, whichever is greater, without a special exception by the Board of Appeals.
For agricultural conservation, agricultural conservation-RCA, resource conservation, resource conservation-RCA and rural residential-conservation zoning districts, the sum total of residential accessory structures on a property couldn't exceed the building footprint of the principal residential structure or 1,600 square feet, whichever is greater, without a special exception by the Board of Appeals.
At the Feb. 6 council meeting, Webb said the amendment would provide relief to both property owners and county staff. She said 75% of the county's Board of Appeals cases in the past two years have been for accessory structures that are greater than what is allowed by county code, which has incurred more legal fees for the county and made meetings longer.

title: Maryland couple celebrates 70th wedding anniversary
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@ceciwlhig.com
content:
Maryland couple celebrates 70th wedding anniversary

 June 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@ceciwlhig.com | Section: News 
 
 645
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When Wayne Smythe and Joan Bines got married 70 years ago today, Dwight David Eisenhower was president, On the Waterfront was big at the box office, Sh-Boom by The Crew Cuts was the hot song on the radio and the first Jonas Salk polio vaccines were being administered.He was 20 and she was 16 when they stood before The Rev. Jack Patterson at Hopewell United Methodist Church in Port Deposit and got married.
"My father was strict," Joan recalled. "I wasn't allowed past the sidewalk after 8 p.m."
So the young couple eloped June 14, 1954. They had been dating about a year.
"I met him through his cousin," Joan said. "I think we clicked right away." Dating meant driving around, talking and going out to dinner.
"We'd go to the one (restaurant) in North East and one in Chesapeake City," Wayne recalled.
"The one in North East you could sit and watch them cook through the window," Joan added.
Then came 'The Day.'
"I proposed to him," Joan said. It was one of several days she had ditched school to hang out with Wayne.
"I was just being silly. I asked if he'd marry me. He said, 'yeah,'" Joan said, adding, "I wasn't expecting that."
For the wedding, Joan wore a dress from her own closet.
"I snuck off wearing a dress I already had," she said. "It was a purple dress with a black bolero and black suede shoes."
She also wore a white corsage; a gift from Wayne.
Wayne wore his uniform. He was in the US Air Force from 1953 to 1957. Trained as an aircraft mechanic during the Korean War, he spent 15 months in the Philippines and also served in the Formosa Islands, among other stops.
"It was good to see what other people lived like," Wayne said of his service years. "They didn't like the U.S. and they still don't."
After a short honeymoon in the Poconos, the couple lived with her cousins — Gert and Frankie Bines — for a time before buying their first home.
"We found a little house on Richmond Street (in Perryville) for $4,000," Wayne said. "When we had that house we used to have all the kids over with big dinners."
Those five kids led to 12 grandchildren and now 26 great grandchildren. Big family dinners are a thing of the past.
Except for the house Wayne built in Port Deposit near Burlin Road, the couple has always lived in Perryville.
From Port Deposit, they moved into Joan's parents' house for 43 years, then into a smaller rancher about 15 years ago.
"This has everything on one floor," Joan noted.
The secret of their success
According to the American Psychological Association, more than 30% of first marriages end in divorce.
So how have the Smythes made it to 70 years?
"No arguments over money," Wayne said simply. "Money is what breaks a lot of people up. I brought home all the paychecks to her."
"With a large item to buy, we'd discuss it," he added.
Joan worked until she had their first child, Joanne, when she was 18. After Wayne Jr, Douglas, Michelle and Jennifer were old enough, she went back to work while Wayne worked as many as four jobs. That included his own oil burner service company.
"I raised a bunch of kids. He worked all the time," she said. "It has paid off."
He did have some fun in between all those working hours.
"He bought an old bakery truck and turned it into a camper," Joan said, remembering all those fun trips as a family.
"I used to have classic cars," Wayne added. The one he admits to missing the most is a 1962 Chevrolet Corvette. "I also had a Ford Coupe, a Mercury and a Thunderbird."
Now as they approach their Platinum Anniversary, Wayne looked back and commented he was "just a plain country boy" when he and Joan got married, and they have had a good marriage.
"I have no regrets in my life," Wayne said.

title: 4-time US Open champion dies at 95
author: Assoclated Press
content:
4-time US Open champion dies at 95

 October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Assoclated Press | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 569
 Words 

 Read News Document

 LEWES, Del. - Betsy Rawls trained to be a physicist and instead devoted her life to golf, first as a fourtime U.S. Women's Open champion and later as a tournament administrator, a remarkable career that landed her in the World Golf Hall of Fame.Rawls, who won eight majors in her 55 LPGA Tour titles, died Saturday at her beach home in Delaware, the LPGA Tour confirmed. She was 95."There are simply not many careers that can compare to Betsy's," said Mike Whan, the CEO of the USGA and former LPGA Tour commissioner.He cited her 55 wins and eight majors - Rawls ranks sixth on both lists - along with her induction into the LPGA and World Golf Hall of Fame, the Bob Jones Award and her 17 years as tournament director of what was then the LPGA Championship."She was a legend in the game who would have been successful in anything she pursued, so we are all lucky she made golf her passion,"Whan said.The intention was always in the field of physics. That's what Rawls was studying at the University ofTexas when she connected with fabled swing coach Harvey Penick. She won the Texas Women's Amateur in 1949 and 1950, and she finished runner-up to Babe Zaharias in the 1950 U.S. Women's Open."I had every intention of being a physicist," Rawls said in a story posted on the LPGA's website. "I played golf for fun and never considered turning professional. Then I decided it would be more fun to be in golf than physics, and Wilson paid me a salary and all my expenses. They paid my expenses for 20 years. One year, I gave 120 clinics."She won the U.S. Women's Open by five shots over Louise Suggs in 1951, the first of four titles in the biggest event in women's golf. Only the late Mickey Wright won as many Opens.Wright once said, "Betsy has always been committed to work and dedicated to the game. I can think of only two women who have achieved as much, not only as players but for their lifetime contributions, and that's Betsy and Patty Berg." Rawls was born May 4, 1928, in Spartanburg, South Carolina, though she moved to Texas in 1940 and grew up mostly in Arlington.She won at least once a year from 1951 through 1965. She won the last of her eight majors at age 41 in the 1969 LPGA Championship by four shots.Rawls led the LPGA Tour money list in 1952 and 1959. She won the Vare Trophy for the lowest scoring average in 1959 and led the LPGA in victories three times.She was part of the inaugural class for the LPGA Hall of Fame in 1967 and in 1996 received the Bob Jones Award, the highest honor by the USGA. She became the first woman to work the men's U.S. Open as a rules official in 1980.She also was the LPGA president in 1961 and 1962, and after retiring from full-time competition in 1975, she worked a tournament director and later ran the LPGA Championship."Anyone who can make a living in golf is lucky," Rawls once said. "Then to receive all the benefits accorded to me in the process well, that makes me feel fortunate. It's more than I could possibly deserve."

title: Maryland's wineries begin to thrive as reputation grows
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland's wineries begin to thrive as reputation grows

 June 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Port of Leonardtown Winery Winemaker Lauren Zimmerman relayed a story back when a judge during a wine tasting contest didn't believe the drink had come from the winery. In fact, he even requested to see the bottle complete with the label.But wines from Maryland in general, and Southern Maryland in particular, have come a long way since then.
"I think our reputation has definitely improved," Zimmerman said during a lecture titled "Port of Leonardtown Winery, and the History of Wine in Maryland" held May 21 at Historic Sotterley. "I think people and their wineries experience has improved. There's also a lot of experienced winemakers coming into the area, which has improved the quality of Maryland wines immensely."
The Leonardtown winery is celebrating its 15th season this year and has won numerous wine industry awards.
"We're very well known for producing wines in general, dry and sweet," Zimmerman said.
The lecture also featured wine tastings of a limited edition sparkling red the winery will release in June.
"It is a dry red sparkling and it's loaded with red berry flavors," Zimmerman said of the wine, the label of which was designed by local artist Bernard Matus. "It has lots of notes of blueberry, raspberry. I think it's going to fly off the shelves."
The lecture also included Southern Maryland Grape Grower's Cooperative President David Wood, who is also owner of Forest Hall Farm Market in Mechanicsville.
"We needed a viable alternative. Nobody's going to create a market just for grape juice," Wood said of the winery's beginnings in 2007. "Just like anything else that is new, you learn as you grow. The money's not in the grapes, the money is in the profit of the wine."
But Wood added it wasn't easy for former tobacco farmers to start growing grapes.
"You weren't prepared to do the marketing, to go out and shop your crop to find a buyer who was willing to buy it," he said. "That's not a farmer's strength; they're used to staying at home and dealing with their crops. The selling of the crop was the big issue and the co-op stepped up and provided a solution to that challenge."
With the start of the wine co-op in 2007 — the first in the state — farmers still faced hurdles before seeing the literal fruits of their labors.
"The [profit] net was pretty good because tobacco was labor-intensive; it didn't require a lot of investment," Wood said. "Grapes on the other hand are costly and it takes about three years of growing the grapes before you get your first harvest."
Wood said wineries require an investment of about $10,000 an acre "before you get your first crop, and you probably won't break even until your fifth or sixth harvest."
But he added growers will "probably get 20, 25 years of harvests, so once you get over the hump, you can really get ahead."
The Port of Leonardtown Winery had its first crush of grapes in 2009 and opened a year later.
Wood added that a single winery can usually offer the basic red and white varieties, but having a co-op means a selection of 20 labels or more.
"It gives us not only more grapes, but a wider variety," he said. "It turns into a product mix of more unique wines."
Zimmerman said Port of Leonardtown produces about 5,000 cases annually, and that red and white grapes are treated differently; reds get a mix of seeds and skin where it gets its flavor and color, while whites are made with whole cluster pressing.
All reds are aged in an oak barrel, while all white grapes are aged in a stainless steel drum.
"Chardonnay made in stainless steel barrels have crisp, clean like green apple flavor," she said, "versus chardonnays in made in oak barrels have a baked apple, vanilla cinnamon-spiced, clove flavor. They're different styles, but just both beautiful wines."

 "Batman" (Heroes & Icons, Sunday, Aug. 13): One of this series' best villains is showcased in "Pop Goes the Joker"/"Flop Goes the Joker," as the Cesar Romero-portrayed Joker becomes a rival to Andy Warhol - or so he believes - as he tries to make a splash in the world of pop art. The tale gives Adam West a big chunk of time as Batman's alias Bruce Wayne."The Jetsons" (MeTV, Sunday, Aug. 13): A series about the future - even an animated one - would have to consider the computer age to be even mildly accurate, and the first-season episode "Uniblab" sees George Jetson's (voice of George O'Hanlon) career placed in jeopardy by a machine that seems capable of performing all of the same functions, without the requirement of a paycheck."Face/Off" (AMC, Tuesday, Aug. 15): Director John Woo's 1997 melodrama has a great conceit, with an FBI agent (John Travolta) very reluctantly - and very literally - surgically switching faces with a master criminal (Nicolas Cage) in a scheme to thwart a major attack being planned by the felon. As far-out as the plot might seem, there's enormous entertainment value in watching each star approximate the other, as both characters and performers."The Lost World" (FXM, Saturday, Aug. 19): Before he became the movies' "master of disaster" with the likes of "The Poseidon Adventure" and "The Towering Inferno," Irwin Allen made his mark as a producer-director of science fiction, one example being this 1960 adaptation of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's story about an expedition's discovery of prehistoric territory, The special effects are rather primitive (pun intended) by today's standards, but there's still fun to be had; stars include Michael Rennie, Jill St. John, David Hedison and Claude Rains.

 ANNAPOLIS - The Maryland Board of Public Works approved 14 new Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation easements during the Aug. 2 meeting. The easements will permanently preserve 1,400 acres of prime farmland in Baltimore, Charles, Dorchester, Frederick, Garrett, Queen Anne's, Washington and Wicomico counties, for an investment of more than $8 million."Keeping farming viable in Maryland starts with preserving farmland," said Maryland Department of Agriculture Secretary Kevin Atticks. "Fortunately, Maryland has one of the most successful agricultural land preservation programs in the country. And with these additional easements being approved, 1,400 more acres are secured for the purpose of providing food and fiber to the region." Easements approved on the Mid-Shore include two farms in Dorchester, totaling 84.10 acres, at a cost of $396,750, and one farm in Queen Anne's, 197.08 acres, at a cost of $740,455.42.The Maryland Agricultural Preservation Foundation was established in 1977 as part of the Maryland Department of Agriculture. title: Final Four beckons Bueckers and Clark
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Final Four beckons Bueckers and Clark

 April 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 1167
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CLEVELAND — Their memories are blurry.Of AAU tournaments and Team USA practices. Of gold medals and deep 3s. Of the girl with the brown ponytail with the unlimited range who always seemed to know what was coming next and the blonde who never got rattled with the ball in her hands, by opponents or the sea of eyes constantly transfixed on her.
Yet ask Iowa's Caitlin Clark and UConn's Paige Bueckers their earliest impression of the other and you get generalities, light on details if heavy on respect.
Maybe because those years shadowing each other on the travel circuit across the Midwest or teaming up for the occasional international competition seem so long ago. Maybe because in some ways — in the most meaningful of ways — they are.
The NCAA Tournament that Clark grew up watching in Iowa and Bueckers took in from the outskirts of Minneapolis doesn't exist anymore. Back then, the inequalities between the men's and women's versions of March Madness were massive, from facilities to swag to TV ratings, even the branding.
It's not that way anymore.
Not with Clark and Iowa selling out everywhere they go. Not with Bueckers finally healthy after spending the better part of two years recovering from knee injuries that left her fearful the generational skills that made her the first freshman to win the AP Player of the Year award would never return.
Only they have. Just in time for the two players who have helped propel interest in the women's tournament to an all-time high to take center stage.
When Clark and the top-seeded Hawkeyes face Bueckers and third-seeded UConn on Friday night in the Final Four, they'll do it not in some anonymous gym with nothing but parents, scouts and college coaches watching.
They will play in front of a packed arena with millions watching on television and millions more keeping track on social media, an ever-growing group that includes LeBron James and Steph Curry and Luka Doncic and aspiring ballers from all over.
It's not that women's basketball hasn't had stars before. It has. Just never quite as many as this who play quite like this.
And while Iowa coach Lisa Bluder made it a point on Thursday to say she didn't want the national semifinal to be pitted as "Caitlin vs. Paige," everyone else involved seems to be OK with the arrangement because of what it means for not just their respective teams, but the women's game in general.
"It's a star-driven society that we live in," UConn coach Geno Auriemma said. "It's a celebrity-driven, star-driven, influencer-driven world that's been created."
One in which both Clark and Bueckers are comfortable traveling, perhaps because it's the only world they've ever known.
BIRD VS. MAGIC 2.0? YES AND NOThe parallels to the rivalry between Magic Johnson and Larry Bird that began when Johnson and Michigan State faced Bird and Indiana State in the 1979 NCAA championship are obvious.
"All of a sudden those two particular players came on and it just lit everything up, and it just took off from there," Auriemma said. "So it needs some stars. It needs people that have the right personality, the right game. And we have that now."
Thing is, Bueckers and Clark don't view themselves as rivals. Not in a traditional sense. If anything, they believe they're simply riding the crest of a wave that's been building for years, long before they reached a first-name-only level of fame.
Ask Clark why interest in women's basketball has spiked and she doesn't point to her record-setting career or her "did she really shoot that" range or even her team's success but simple exposure.
To Clark, the women's game has always been great. It's just taken a while, a long while, for the world to catch up.
"It's the platforms that (we're able to have now) that should have been there for a really long time," Clark said. "We've had some amazing talents come through our game, over the last 10, 20 years."
Talents that haven't quite connected in the way that Clark and Bueckers have connected. The easing of rules surrounding name, image and likeness compensation has allowed them to market themselves and their game in ways once unimaginable.
FOLLOWING LEGENDSIt's a history not lost on either of them. They understand and embrace the responsibility of being a role model, knowing they were once on the other end, looking up to the likes of college and WNBA stars Maya Moore and Lindsay Whalen.
"They were everything that I wanted to be like," Bueckers said. "And they won."
A trait that has followed Bueckers seemingly from the first time she picked up a ball. It's telling that when asked about Bueckers' game, Clark didn't talk about her impeccable court vision or precise midrange jumper but what the scoreboard says after nearly every game in which she plays.
"She's always been dominant," Clark said. "Every team that she's ever been on, she's led them to great success. It's just what she does. She's a winner."
That hasn't changed, though the dynamics around the way Clark and Bueckers are perceived have flipped over the last three years.
ROLE REVERSALIt was Bueckers, not Clark, who was the top recruit in the Class of 2020. It was Bueckers, not Clark, who was recruited by the Huskies, though Auriemma did point out this week "if Caitlin really wanted to come to UConn, she would have called me." It was Bueckers, not Clark, who won that first meeting in 2021 and became the "media darling," as Bueckers put it Friday.
Clark is in that position now. Setting the NCAA Division I scoring record and playing with a fearlessness that is equal parts thrilling and accessible will do that.
Security people had to clear a path deep inside Rocket Mortgage Fieldhouse on Friday to make sure she could make it from one media opportunity to the next. When UConn and Bueckers came through an hour later, the throng was half the size.
Even for a player who says on the court she can see things before they happen, it's been a lot. The 22-year-old Clark welcomes the attention because she understands it has brought new people to her sport. Yet she's not here to be The Star, as much as people want to thrust that moniker on her.
Three years ago, it was Bueckers. The last two years, it's been her. Next spring it might be Bueckers during her redshirt senior season. Bueckers is leaning toward this year's blockbuster freshman class, a group that includes USC's JuJu Watkins or Notre Dame's Hannah Hidalgo. A decade from now, it might be some young woman who didn't pick up a ball until she watched Clark hoist it from deep and Bueckers weave through traffic in the lane.
In that way, Clark doesn't see herself or Bueckers as the end result of something, but simply the latest links in a chain growing ever stronger with each passing season.
"It doesn't need to be one end-all, be-all (star) just like I think there doesn't need to be one end-all, be-all team," Clark said. "The young talent, it's only going to get better."

title: 'We have a lot to do' - Maryland Commission on Public Health holds inaugural meeting
author: Michael Reid; mreid@somdnews.com
content:
'We have a lot to do' - Maryland Commission on Public Health holds inaugural meeting

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid; mreid@somdnews.com | Page: 2 | Section: News

 Read News Document

 Maryland's Commission on Public Health met virtually for the first time as a group on Dec. 14 and spent much of the time in the organizational phase.The commission will be tasked with making recommendations to improve the delivery of foundational public health services, assessing the foundational health capabilities of the Maryland Department of Health as well as local health departments and make recommendations for reform.
It will also address foundational public health areas, including as they relate to behavioral health, and respond to COVID-19, overdoses, maternal and infant mortality and other major public health challenges.
"Our main task ultimately is reporting; it's not just meeting, discussing, working in our work groups, coming up with recommendations, analyzing," said Lushniak, who added that assessing, analyzing and recommendations are key features.
The commission will be in effect until June 30, 2025, when it must submit its final report.
An interim report was due Dec. 1, which was submitted by the co-chairs who were able to meet a few times "as we didn't want to be late with our homework assignment," Lushniak said.
That report was sent with a few amendments, one of which was a request for an extension to June 30, 2025, for its final report. Though the commission took effect last June 1, appointments were not completed until late October.
The commission also requested the ability to seek financial support mechanisms as it believes "there may be opportunities in public health foundation-level support through grant mechanisms." The commission members requested the establishment of maryland.gov emails as well as the establishment of a website. The members also officially recognized the contributions of staff providing subject matter expertise and noted "government-involved staffing helps facilitate the logistics and work of this commission." "I think we all experienced the incredible challenge of the pandemic of the century in the past few years, and during that challenge recognized how incredibly strenuous the task was ahead of our public health force in particular, and the roadblocks and the gaps in public health, funding and resources really restricted our ability," said Dr. Meena Brewster, one of three co-chairs on the state board.
"We have a lot to do to be out there and be a part of this," said Lushniak, who added the commission has no hidden agendas and will be "transparent." The next meeting will be held at 2 p.m. on Thursday, Jan. 4, at the Baltimore County Department of Health. There will also be a virtual option.
For more information on the Commission of Public Health, email MD.CoPG@maryland.gov or go to smchd.org/commissiononpublichealth/.

Welcome home: QAC honors Vietnam era veterans

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 503

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Proving it's never too late to say "welcome home", a special commemoration honored the service, valor, and sacrifice of Vietnam Era veterans at the Queen Anne's County High School Auditorium March 29.Commemorating the 50th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam War, the ceremony led by Vietnam veterans presented recognition for some decades in the making.
Ceremony speaker Jack Farley, served as a U.S. Army captain in Vietnam and acquired four Bronze Stars, two Purple Hearts and left a leg behind.
Farley said, "Those who decide to go to war are generally not the ones who fight," and the lessons of the war can be found in the more than 58,000 names etched into the national Vietnam Veterans Memorial wall in Washington D.C.
No matter the branch of the armed forces, American service members answered the call to serve the country and were treated the same upon their return, according to Farley.
At that time, many Americans were vocal in their disdain for the war and connected that to the soldiers as well, he said.
Returning service members realized that the county they went off to fight for was no longer there when they returned, Farley said, and highlighted the need to "separate the war from the warrior."
Farley was especially glad to see so many younger people in the ceremony's attendance to share legacies, keep history alive and resolve to ensure the reception military members received from their countrymen during Vietnam never happens again.
Joe Sikes, along with Boy Scout Troop 278, led a missing man table ceremony recognizing the sacrifice of those lost. As a member of the United States Naval Academy Class of 1968, the ceremony was particularly significant for him in losing classmates to the war.
To this day, remains from those missing in action continue to be identified and brought home, he said, and for some, the war never truly ended as some families are kept waiting. Sikes said he himself never heard a thank you for his service until well into the 1980s and seeks to connect the community, especially the younger generation to remember the battles fought and the sacrifices made in duty in Vietnam.
Alongside music performed by the Centreville Middle School Symphonic Band, a pin ceremony honored all members who served in active duty anywhere in the world from 1955 to 1975.
March 29 was established as National Vietnam Veterans Day in 2017 and local ceremonies are crucial in continually providing recognition to noble service members, according to Farley.
Navy veteran in Vietnam and organizer Dave Peterson led recognition of the five Queen Anne's County residents who died in the Vietnam operating theater and their Gold Star families.
The ceremony's Presentation of Colors was performed by the U.S. Naval Sea Cadet Corps Maryland Division. The National Anthem was presented by the Quee Anne's County High School Chorus.
Taps was performed by Stephanie Shields.
Prayer was led by Rev. Reginald Ryans.
Participants and sponsors also included Centreville Veterans Information Center (CVIC), Veteran and Military Support Alliance (VAMSA), American Legion Jeff Davis Post 18 and Compass Regional Hospice.

 Q: What has Armando Iannucci been doing since "Veep" ended?A: Actually quite a lot. He had a whole HBO sitcom, "Avenue 5," come and go since 2019, when his beloved, award-winning political comedy "Veep" ended.If you didn't know that, it's likely because "Avenue 5," a sci-ficomedy about a space cruise ship that gets stuck far from Earth, never really found an audience.Its first-season ratings, in early 2020, were poor, and then the pandemic happened, which meant the second season didn't air for another two and a half years. He's currently focused on the stage, namely a live-theatre adaptation of the classic film "Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb" (1964).Even worse for TV fans: It's being staged across an ocean in Iannucci's native Britain."Dr. Strangelove" offered a cutting satire of government war-making when it was released in the midst of the Cold War, but Iannucci told the BBC that its message is just as relevant today.As for why he chose the stage instead of the screen, the ever-topical Iannucci said it was also about timing and current affairs. "In the last three years, we've been so enclosed in our homes because of the lockdown, and have got addicted to our screens, so actually going out and seeing something live and in the flesh is all the more exciting.  On Aug. 10, 2020, a powerful derecho struck several Midwest U.S. states, causing four fatalities and an estimated $11 billion in damage, making it the costliest thunderstorm in modern U.S. history.Also on this date:
In 1792, during the French Revolution, mobs in Paris attacked the Tuileries Palace, where King Louis XVI resided. (The king was later arrested, put on trial for treason, and executed.)
In 1821, Missouri became the 24th state admitted to the Union.
In 1945, a day after the atomic bombing of Nagasaki, Imperial Japan conveyed its willingness to surrender provided the status of Emperor Hirohito remained unchanged. (The Allies responded the next day, saying they would determine the Emperor's future status.)
In 1969, Leno and Rosemary LaBianca were murdered in their Los Angeles home by members of Charles Manson's cult, one day after actor Sharon Tate and four other people were slain.
In 1977, postal employee David Berkowitz was arrested in Yonkers, New York, accused of being "Son of Sam," the gunman who killed six people and wounded seven others in the New York City area.
In 1988, President Ronald Reagan signed a measure providing $20,000 payments to still-living Japanese-Americans who were interned by their government during World War II.
In 1993, Ruth Bader Ginsburg was sworn in as the second female justice on the U.S. Supreme Court.
In 2006, British authorities announced they had thwarted a terrorist plot to simultaneously blow up 10 aircraft heading to the U.S. using liquid explosives made to look like soft drinks.
In 2018, Richard Russell, a 29-year-old airline ground agent, stole a commercial plane from Sea-Tac International Airport near Seattle; he flew for 75 minutes, performing dangerous stunts while being chased by military jets before crashing into a remote island in Puget Sound, killing himself.
In 2019, Jeffrey Epstein, accused of orchestrating a sex-trafficking ring and sexually abusing dozens of underage girls, was found unresponsive in his cell at a New York City jail; he was later pronounced dead at a hospital. (The city's medical examiner ruled the death a suicide by hanging.)

title: Talbot Board of Ed voices mixed opinions over 2025-26 calendar draft
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Board of Ed voices mixed opinions over 2025-26 calendar draft

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A draft version of a calendar for the 2025-2026 school year drew varying opinions from Talbot County Board of Education members on Wednesday evening.The calendar committee, which plans the district's upcoming calendars, put together the draft that was shown Wednesday. It included two days off in the second week of March 2026 for students and a five-day spring break for students from April 2 to April 6, 2026.
"The thinking of the committee was to put some days off in March, and then to do the April holiday," Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, said. "Dividing the break would also minimize the impact on our students who rely on the support of our schools for their meal support."
Board President Emily Jackson, who serves on the calendar committee, expressed confusion with the draft calendar that Einhorn presented.
"It was a surprisingly contentious group, with a huge set of ideas that ran the gamut," Jackson said of the committee. "So what I am seeing presented today, to me, does not accurately reflect what I took away from the discussions that were had."
Jackson said she was expecting multiple draft calendars, not just one. She added that past surveys have indicated there are strong opinions on extending spring break and having "time for teachers in their classrooms without students."
"Personally, I come back to wanting to give our community what they're asking for," Jackson said. "So I'm looking for a calendar that has an actual spring break on it."
Board Member Deborah Bridges said she liked the two days off in March.
"I think the March break is wonderful from a mental health standpoint, because March is long, dreary," Bridges said. "And everybody — kids, parents and teachers — need a little break, and I think that's a really good thing to do."
Board Member Dyshekia Strawberry raised concerns that the shorter spring break could increase chronic absenteeism in April. Vice President Amy Dodson said while the draft calendar "looks good," an off day in March could possibly be moved to extend spring break.
Jackson also brought up the possibility of staggered starts for students in "transition" grades that are starting at new schools. Einhorn said that she is waiting on direction from the state to understand how other districts do staggered starts while still complying with 180-day requirements.
Feedback from Wednesday's meeting will be taken back to the calendar committee and discussed before a draft calendar is presented for second reader at the board's January meeting.
Einhorn said it'd be possible for the committee to look at keeping the two off days in March, as well as extending spring break, by moving the last day of school back.
Jackson vouched for "consistent breaks" in order to accommodate student needs surrounding mental health, travel needs, college tours and more.
"There are ways to put this together that do make sense and don't look like this," the board president said.
"I think we have to put everything out on the table because we have constraints," Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said. "We can't have it both ways.
"And while I know we want extra days off, I hear loud and clear from parents (about) child care. But we also want to balance, because I also hear from staff, more planning time. We just have to find out, what is that balance?"

title: Leonard provided vision; let's make it happen
author: Staff Writer
content:
Leonard provided vision; let's make it happen

 August 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The City of Cambridge owes Matt Leonard a huge thank you.Some people might find that statement unusual. This newspaper has been critical of Leonard and his leadership of the Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc.
His actions as the executive director have rung up more than $200,000 in unbudgeted legal expenses and driven an excellent city manager from Cambridge.
This week, corporation board President Angie Hengst announced that Leonard was leaving as CWDI executive director effective immediately. No reason was given, other than to say the decision was mutual.
According to Hengst, the board decision was unanimous and the board members and Leonard signed an agreement on Thursday.
Hengst said "moving forward it was best for both parties." Hengst would not elaborate on why it was best for both parties.
Leonard was hired as CWDI's executive director in January 2022. In the last year, Leonard and CWDI have been in the spotlight. The Cambridge Harbor project — a project to develop land along the Choptank River — has become a frequent topic of conversation in Cambridge.
In May, tensions between CWDI and the City of Cambridge came to a head when the city filed a lawsuit against CWDI alleging the organization had violated a transfer agreement it entered into with the city in June 2021. Later that month, the city and CWDI entered into mediation before a retired judge.
Also in May, Cambridge lost its city manager, Tom Carroll. In his resignation letter to the mayor and City Council, Carroll cited ongoing concerns with the Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc.'s Cambridge Harbor project, in particular the financial feasibility of the project.
In an email to the Star Democrat in May, Carroll said he hoped that he was wrong and that Cambridge Harbor will "become a storybook success."
"But I fear that I will be correct in its lasting and long-term negative impacts for Cambridge unless it is fundamentally changed," he wrote. "I can no longer stand by while this project moves forward in its current form and with the current governance structure."
The agreement for Leonard to leave could be that fundamental change Carroll talked about.
Leonard leaves CWDI in poor financial shape, and the board will have to its work cut out to fix that problem.
Hengst said neither the ongoing legal disputes nor the development corporation's dire financial situation led to Leonard's departure, but she noted that CWDI does not have the money to hire a new executive director at this point.
"Unfortunately, based on our financials, ... we do not have the funds to take a new executive director," she said.
So why should Cambridge residents thank Matt Leonard?
For all of his faults — and there were many — Leonard offered a grand vision for Cambridge and a prime piece of real estate along the Choptank River. Leonard dreamed big. The projects he proposed were spectacular and would have transformed Cambridge Harbor.
The CWDI board needs to repair its ties with the City of Cambridge and its residents. The vision Leonard proposed is worth pursuing. It just needs to be done in a financially prudent manner and needs to involve the community from start to finish.
We heard a developer recently talk about Cambridge residents, describing many of them as disillusioned and defeated. A successful Cambridge Harbor project could change that.
We think that Angie Hengst has the leadership skills to rebuild trust in CWDI and begin a new partnership with city officials to move the Cambridge Harbor project forward.
Removing Matt Leonard was a good first step. Now she will need to put those leadership skills to work and make this project a reality.
We wish her luck.

title: Striped bass restrictions head to Supreme Court
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@kibaytimes.com
content:
Striped bass restrictions head to Supreme Court

 March 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@kibaytimes.com | Section: Local News 
 
 911
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — A coalition of Maryland fishing associations and charter boat operators have escalated their legal battle against new striped bass fishing restrictions, filing an emergency petition with the U.S. Supreme Court seeking to block the regulations. Captain Robert Newberry, chairman of Delmarva Fisheries Association stated, "We will take this case to the highest court until this matter is resolved — it is far from over."The Delmarva Fisheries Association and the Maryland Charter Boat Association, along with two individual commercial fishermen, argue that the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission's (the Commission) recent measures impose "drastic, unwarranted, and illegal limitations" on striped bass fishing in the Chesapeake Bay and along the Atlantic coast. The petition, filed March 4, claims the restrictions violate the U.S. Constitution and could jeopardize the livelihoods of many small businesses.
The case follows months of legal disputes in lower courts, where the plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction to halt the Commission's 2024 striped bass management plan, known as Addendum II. The plan, approved in January by a 14-2 vote, reduced commercial quotas, shortened fishing seasons, and limited recreational anglers to catching just one striped bass per day instead of two.
Maryland and New Jersey voted against the measure, but Maryland ultimately implemented the restrictions under pressure from the Commission and federal agencies. The Maryland Attorney General's Office acknowledged in a letter that failing to comply could trigger a federal moratorium on all striped bass fishing in state waters.
When confronted with having to cut the catch limitation in half, Assistant Director and Fisheries Manager at the Maryland Department of Natural Resources and proxy to the Marine Fisheries Commission Michael Luisi, warned the Commission that limiting Maryland's charter boat clients' catch to one fish a day "will put people out of business."
Documents filed with the court by the plaintiffs state Luisi was "pointedly correct in this assessment but the ASMFC and its federal and other illegally voting partners as well as other member states, including Maryland at that point, decided that its guesstimate on fish-spawning futures five years into the future was more important than the impending demise of these family-run, small businesses."
Newberry said, it is was "extremely perturbing that Governor Moore and Attorney General Anthony Brown turned their backs on us in the seafood industry in Maryland and also all of us here on the Eastern Shore." Moore never weighed in on this constitutional issue affecting those in the seafood industry, but will "spend millions of taxpayers dollars defending the citizens of Maryland against the so-called constitutional violations of President Trump," Newberry said. "We have not only been left behind, we have tire tracks on our backs from where we have been run over, and left behind."
"The economic damage is undeniable," said Brian Hardman, president of the Maryland Charter Boat Association. "We've seen a 75-85% decline in business, boats being sold off, and captains leaving the industry. The Commission rushed through regulations without considering the devastating impact on local livelihoods."
Hardman continued, "...the 2025 numbers are continuing to be off by the same ratios or worse; that an unprecedented 53 charter boats have been sold or listed for sale since 2024; and, that 43 "for hire" Charter Boat businesses have already been forced to close their doors with another 11 companies losing money at a rate that will soon bring about the same result."
The legal challenge focuses on alleged constitutional violations, including the 10th Amendment's prohibition on federal overreach, the 5th Amendment's protection against government takings without just compensation, and the 14th Amendment's due process clause. The plaintiffs also argue that the Commission, originally established as an advisory body, has unlawfully assumed regulatory powers without proper state and federal oversight.
Despite warnings from industry representatives that the new rules would cripple the state's fishing economy, the Commission stood by its decision, citing concerns about overfishing and the need to rebuild the striped bass population by 2029. However, critics claim the commission relied on faulty data, pointing out that the agency's own projections have fluctuated — from a 97% chance of population recovery in 2023 to just 15% in 2024, before rebounding to 50% in 2025.
In a statement, the Commission defended its methodology, emphasizing that conservation measures are necessary to prevent further declines in the striped bass stock.
"The science may be imperfect, but the consequences of inaction could be severe," said a Commission spokesperson. "We understand the economic hardship this creates, but the long-term health of the fishery must come first."
Yet the plaintiffs stated, there are in excess of 240 million striped bass in U.S. waters and the annual number of fishing removals is approximately six million.
The Supreme Court previously declined to hear an emergency appeal in May, citing a lack of prior appellate review. The plaintiffs now return to the high court after exhausting their legal options in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, which ruled in February that the lawsuit should be dismissed because the plaintiffs had sued the Commission rather than the state of Maryland.
With the 2025 fishing season set to begin in May, the petitioners are urging the Supreme Court to issue an injunction that would restore previous fishing limits while the legal battle plays out. Without relief, they warn that more charter businesses will shut down, further damaging Maryland's historic fishing industry.
"The Supreme Court is our last hope," Hardman said. "We're not asking for special treatment—just the right to keep our businesses afloat."
A decision on the emergency petition filed March 4, could come within weeks.

In 1968, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed into law the Civil Rights Act of 1968, which included the Indian Civil Rights Act and the Fair Housing Act, one week after the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.
In 1970, Apollo 13, with astronauts James A. Lovell, Fred W. Haise and Jack Swigert, blasted off on its ill-fated mission to the moon. (The mission was aborted following an oxygen tank explosion two days after liftoff, and the crew splashed down safely in the Pacific Ocean on April 17.)
In 1980, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission published guidelines saying sexual harassment in the workplace amounted to unlawful sex discrimination in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

 OXFORD — The Town of Oxford has a new employee in its office.Vickie Sharp was sworn into the role of clerk-treasurer at a Commissioners of Oxford meeting Tuesday. Commission President Tom Costigan administered the oath of office.
After Sharp was sworn in, Costigan introduced Sharp. He said that she previously worked for the Town of St. Michaels. According to the Town of St. Michaels website, Sharp was the town's finance clerk and Water Department and billing clerk.
"We're thrilled to have her with us, and we expect great things," Costigan said to Sharp.
The clerk-treasurer is a new position for the Town of Oxford.
According to the job posting on the town's website, Sharp will be tasked with directing and managing the town's finances under the town manager's direction and implementing policy set by the Commissioners of Oxford. The clerk-treasurer will act as the chief financial officer of the town.
The creation of this position was talked about at a Jan. 11 commissioners meeting, when Commissioner Katrina Greer said she wanted to discuss the possibility of hiring someone to take on the town's financial duties.
At the Jan. 11 meeting, Greer said this could address a material weakness detailed in the town's audit for the town's lack of internal controls. This has been a finding in town audits going back to 2016.
"This would take some burden off the manager and enable us to comply with the audit recommendation of having multiple people performing financial roles," she said at the meeting.
Town Manager Cheryl Lewis said she had shared this idea with the commissioners originally because hiring more employees is the way to solve the internal controls issue.
"Admittedly most towns our size can't afford more staff," Lewis said at the Jan. 11 meeting. "Oxford is not in that situation, per se."

title: Time to reframe conversation about literacy
author: LISA BLOTTENBERGER and TRISH BRENNAN-GAC
content:
Time to reframe conversation about literacy

 August 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA BLOTTENBERGER and TRISH BRENNAN-GAC | Section: Columns 
 
 774
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland State Department of Education's draft literacy policy aims to establish a framework to support students and teachers. Yet, the conversation around this policy has been dominated by the issue of retention. By doing so, we are overlooking its broader intent: creating a robust support system.With the Maryland State Board of Education discussing this policy last Tuesday, it's time we shift our focus to what truly matters: preparing and empowering our children to become fluent readers.
MSDE's draft policy seeks to tackle the reading crisis by addressing far more than the potential retention of students. It seeks to equip teachers with the tools, training and resources they need to foster foundational reading skills in every child, track their progress and provide strategic, targeted interventions when necessary. The draft policy includes several critical components designed to achieve this goal, yet these have been largely overlooked in the public discourse.
One of the most vital aspects of the draft policy is how it leverages the Ready to Read Act with its emphasis on early screening and assessment. Historically, teachers have lacked resources and guidance to identify and address reading deficiencies early on. The draft policy aims to change that by providing a step-by-step guide that helps teachers flag students who may be at risk, identify the specific skills they need to develop, and target the support students need.
Another cornerstone of the policy is the emphasis on professional learning and coaching. Diagnostics are only effective if teachers know how to use the results to inform instruction.
The draft policy outlines a plan for ongoing professional development to equip teachers with the knowledge and skills they need to support students at every stage. Training and support, with regard to the science of reading, must be provided to all teachers of reading, pre-K to 12 in order for the data to translate into improved student outcomes.
The draft policy also introduces the concept of a Student Reading Improvement Plan. This plan is designed to be a collaborative effort between teachers and parents, ensuring that everyone involved in a child's education is on the same page. To bridge the gap between the technical language used by educators and what parents can easily understand, MSDE is developing a toolkit that educators can use to communicate more effectively with parents.
While much of the debate has centered on retention, it's crucial to understand that this policy is as much about prevention as it is about intervention. Perhaps retaining students may indeed prevent those who lack foundational reading skills from advancing and ultimately falling through the cracks. We say "may" because we acknowledge the research is complex and the findings are mixed.
However, if the state adopts a retention approach, it must be implemented with great care. Retention should be strategically designed as a last-resort intervention, after all other support measures have been exhausted.
In some cases, retention might be a more effective short-term solution than advancing students who are not prepared, as long as additional time and support are provided. And, we should recognize that the retention component of the policy may incentivize districts to collaborate closely with the MSDE, ensuring shared responsibility for implementing a comprehensive system of support for all students.
Finally, if we are serious about addressing the reading crisis, we need to extend our focus beyond early elementary grades. Middle and high school students who lack foundational reading skills require targeted interventions to help them catch up. This will extend to students who may be advancing to high grades without the foundational skills needed to master challenging texts. The conversation about retention should therefore include discussions about how we support older students who have fallen behind.
MSDE's draft literacy policy represents a comprehensive statewide approach to improving literacy. However, the public discourse has been too narrowly focused on the issue of retention, neglecting the critical support that the policy seeks to provide. It's time we change this conversation and recognize the full scope of the policy's potential. It's a straightforward approach that, if implemented correctly, could have a significant impact on literacy outcomes for all Maryland students.
By focusing on assessments, comprehensive professional development and coaching, and better parental engagement, we can create a system that not only addresses the reading crisis but also ensures that every child in Maryland has the opportunity to become a fluent, confident reader. An ongoing dialogue with MSDE to learn how they are responding to the feedback they received is essential to building public trust and educators' buy-in to the final policy.
Lisa Blottenberger is the founder of Boundless Expectations Inc., a Maryland READS board member and co-founder of Decoding Dyslexia Maryland. Trish Brennan-Gac is the executive director of Maryland READS.

title: Oxford's next town manager faces controversies on western shore
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Oxford's next town manager faces controversies on western shore

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 835
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — As Oxford prepares to welcome Holly Wahl as its next town manager, controversy is swirling in the town where she was previously employed.Wahl announced her resignation as Chesapeake Beach's town administrator on Dec. 4, amid some turmoil in the western shore town.
Bruce Wahl, who had served as mayor of Chesapeake Beach from 2008 to 2016, ran for the position again earlier this year and was elected mayor on Nov. 5.
Prior to Election Day, in social media posts, Bruce Wahl said that if elected, the "persecution of town citizens" by "the current town administration will completely cease."
His comments were related to complaints from residents who claimed their water and sewer bills have recently risen dramatically.
Holly Wahl and Bruce Wahl are not related.
In interviews with the Star Democrat on Friday, the Commissioners of Oxford said they were aware of and not concerned about the controversy in Chesapeake Beach.
"We're confident that we hired the right person," Oxford Commission President Norm Bell said. "We were delighted to talk to her. We're very comfortable in her experiences and how they can help the town. And that's what we based the decision (on)."
Bell said his understanding of the water and sewer bill issue is that people weren't paying annual water and sewer bill connection fees. He said that when Wahl took on her position in Chesapeake Beach, she saw that as a problem and made sure the town started collecting that money.
During a Chesapeake Beach Town Council work session in early September, Wahl said audits revealed "significant underpayment of connection fees" by commercial properties and said the delinquent payments amounted to a $6 million loss to the town.
In an email, Wahl told the Star Democrat: "My record of contributions to the Town of Chesapeake Beach, MD, is publicly available on the Town's website, along with meeting minutes and recordings. I am very much looking forward to working with the Commissioners, staff, citizens, and businesses of the Town of Oxford."
Oxford Commissioner Katrina Greer said Friday that Wahl is a "highly qualified and ethical manager" who was "wringing out corruption" in the connection fees issue.
"And it only made me feel stronger about hiring her," Greer said.
Oxford Commissioner Tom Costigan said Wahl was carefully vetted by the hiring search firm Baker Tilly. He said the information coming out about Wahl is not something the commissioners are worried about.
"We interviewed a lot of candidates," he said. "We narrowed it down to four. She was by far the strongest of the four, and we are optimistic about her future performance here in Oxford."
Oxford hired Baker Tilly to do the search after the town announced the hire of — and then three days later announced they would be parting ways with — Michael Calvert as the next town manager.
Shortly after the news of Calvert's hire, some Oxford residents expressed concerns about the town's candidate vetting process. The week the town announced the decision to part ways with Calvert, Peggy Edwards, a former council member from the town where Calvert was previously employed, told the Star Democrat she resigned from the council due to issues with Calvert and the city's mayor. She said that when Calvert was in the position, there was a lack of transparency and mismanagement of money.
SEVERANCE PACKAGE CONCERNS
On the same day Wahl announced her resignation, the outgoing mayor and the Chesapeake Beach Town Council met for what was labeled an "emergency meeting" to consider for approval of an "emergency ordinance" approving a severance package for Wahl. The town's previous Mayor Pat "Irish" Mahoney said the severance package was reasonable.
The ordinance, which was unanimously approved by the current council, gives Wahl a severance of six months' salary and all accrued vacation time. Southern Maryland News, which is owned and operated by the same company as the Star Democrat, has filed a Freedom of Information Act request for the dollar amount of Wahl's compensation package.
The approved ordinance states that Wahl will receive the compensation "in a lump sum with one payment paid prior to Dec. 18, 2024, based upon her wage rate on the date of her resignation."
In addition to the compensation, the ordinance stipulates that "the town agrees to hold Holly Wahl harmless in any future actions including all indemnification and attorneys' fees for any action that may be pursued against her."
During the public comment portion of the Dec. 4 meeting, a few citizens spoke out against the pending action. Daniel Duvall, who lost the race for a Chesapeake Beach Town Council seat by three votes, said approving a severance package "is not an emergency" and was "a questionable use of taxpayer funds."
Another Chesapeake Beach resident, Deborah Buckingham, reiterated the ordinance did not "meet the criteria of an emergency." She added, "Holly Wahl doesn't deserve any severance."
There was plenty of praise for the town administrator at the meeting, too.
"She's fantastic. I've never seen so much communication in the last eight years," Randy Getman, the town's election administrator, said. "I have no issue with Bruce Wahl wanting to pick his own town administrator."
