title: Dangerous minds - Israel-Hamas war, Musk comments, police surveillance spark new social media fights
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor
content:
Dangerous minds - Israel-Hamas war, Musk comments, police surveillance spark new social media fights

 November 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1895
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Holy Land war between Israel and Hamas is birthing increased police and government surveillance of social media, prompting calls for more Americans to report "hate crimes" and proposals to require all social media accounts to have public name verifications amid concerns about increases in antisemitism and terrorism threats.There are also pushes to deport some anti-war, pro-Palestinian foreign college students deemed supportive of U.S. designated terror groups and expel and ban Palestinian refugees from entering the country.The efforts are born out of security concerns stemming from U.S. support for Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza after the Oct. 7 terror attacks. But they are also sparking concerns about stunting or intimating dissent, privacy and other free speech protections.There is also a new social media battle over Twitter/X owner Elon Musk's support for a social media post that talked about anti-white sentiments among "Jewish communities." A number of major media and technology advertisers, who also compete with social media platforms and some of Musk's technology ventures, have paused advertising on X. That includes Disney (which owns ABC and ESPN), Apple, Paramount Global (which owns CBS and Comedy, IBM, Comcast/NBC Universal (which owns NBC and MSNBC) and Warner Bros/Discovery (which owns CNN).Musk said he agreed with a post from a Twitter who said "Jewish communities have been pushing the exact kind of dialectical hatred against whites that they claim to want people to stop using against them." "You said the actual truth," Musk said in a reply Nov. 15, latter adding that his concurrence was geared toward progressive activist groups and the Anti-Defamation League.The Biden administration condemned Musk's statement Friday. "We condemn this abhorrent promotion of antisemitic and racist hate in the strongest terms," the U.S. administration said in statement drawing parallels to the beliefs of the Robert Bowers, who faces the death penalty after the Tree of Life Synagogue shooting in Pittsburgh left 11 congregants dead.The ADL on Nov. 16 also criticized Musk. "it is indisputably dangerous to use one's influence to validate and promote antisemitic theories, said ADL CEO Jonathan Greenblalt, who on Friday then praised Musk for his condemnation of pro-Palestinian and pro-Hamas phrases 'from the river to the sea' and 'decolonization.' Musk said Saturday some of the critics are dangerously using the episode to squelch free speech and that. he plans on suing progressive activists he claims inaccurately showed neo-Nazi and antisemitic posts next to Twitter/X advertisers' promotions."I am sticking to my principles. As for any fake advocacy groups who seek to suppress free speech, they should remember that karma is real," Musk said on his social media platform.EXPELLING FOREIGN COLLEGE STUDENTSThere is a GOP push to expel foreign college students deemed to be supporting Hamas, Hezbollah and other groups on the U.S. government's list of terrorist groups.A group of 21 GOP attorneys general - including Ashley Moody of Florida and Austin Knudsen of Montana - want the federal government to "vigorously renew vetting of foreign students' and deport those deemed to have endorsed or provided "material support to foreign terrorist organizations." "It is possible that renewed vetting of foreign students already admitted to the United States may reveal activity that renders them ineligible to hold a student visa and liable to deportation," Knudsen, Moody and their cohorts wrote in a letter Nov. 8 to U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and the U.S.Department of Education.Free speech and civil liberties advocates say the reactions to anti-Israel war protests (some of which have seen antisemitic rhetoric) can bleed into censorship as well as quieting and punishing voices of dissent."Free speech means protecting speech you don't like. Sometimes it even means protecting speech you find abhorrent and hateful," said U.S. Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Kentucky, after voting against censure measure aimed at U.S. Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D-Michigan, over her anti-Israel rhetoric and use of a pro-Hamas slogan.BANNING PALESTINIAN REFUGEESA group of congressional Republicans - including U.S. Reps. Andy Thomas, who represents the Eastern Shore, along with U.S. Reps. Ryan Zinke of Montana and Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia and U.S. Sen. Steve Daines of Montana, are also leading efforts to keep Palestinian refugees from the war out of the U.S. Zinke, Harris and Greene also wants to kick out Palestinians who entered the country on or after Oct. 1 in the aftermath of the Hamas' Oct. 7 terror attacks inside Israel that sparked the war in Gaza.They say said he does not trust the Biden administration or Palestinian authorities to adequately screen potential refugees.Critics say the proposal is xenophobic.Similar sentiments related to refugees and college students have been echoed by 2024 GOP presidential candidates such as former president Donald Trump and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, who has suspended pro-Palestinian students' groups in his home state deemed extremist and favored restrictions on public library and school curricula content deemed inappropriate or offensive.While conservatives press universities, who have sometimes aggressively banned right-wing voices from their campuses, to condemn and crackdown on pro-Palestinian student protesters, the American Civil Liberties Union wants them to uphold free speech principles."It is precisely in times of heightened crisis and fear that university leaders must remain steadfast in their commitment to free speech, open debate, and peaceful dissent on campus.These principles are the bedrock of academic freedom at all universities," the ACLU said in a statement."The First Amendment protects all people who live in this country, whether they're here as citizens, foreign nationals, or visitors," the civil liberties group said.ENCOURAGING MORE HATE CRIME REPORTINGDaines and a bipartisan senators including U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen, D-Maryland, have also recently written to FBI Director Christopher Wray and the U.S. Department of Homeland Security asking for more investigative and enforcement resources to be dedicated to addressing antisemitism.The Anti-Defamation League reports a 300% increase in anti-Jewish threats, vandalism and violence since the start of the war, which has seen more than 1,400 Israelis and more than 11,000 Gazans killed.In a separate letter, U.S. Sen Jon Tester, D-Montana, also said FBI and DHS efforts should also be focused on white supremacists echoing past and current Biden administration efforts to go after alt-right groups.The Biden White House, which has put a focus on going after right-wing groups since taking office in 2021, has also launched a new task force to go after "Islamophobia" during the war.On Tuesday, the FBI said it added Oregon to a nationwide effort aimed at encouraging getting more Americans to report "hate incidents' ' with billboards posted in Eugene, Medford and Corvallis as well as digital signs at Portland International Airport.Similar hate crime billboards have been put up across the country, including last month in North Carolina, along with ads on public transit systems, social media platforms and local media outlets.Last month, the U.S. Department of Justice and FBI released new data showing there was a 7.3% increase in reported hate crimes in 2022 (11,634 cases versus 10,840) in 2021.There were more than 6,500 racially motivated incidents - 52% of them aimed at Blacks - and more than 2,000 cases related to religion - with 55% targeting Jews, according to DOJ.SOCIAL MEDIA SURVEILLANCE, FORCED VERIFICATIONSA state law in Montana backed by Knudsen and GOP Gov.Greg Gianforte banning Chinese-owned social media app TikTok is also one of the central fronts in efforts to restrict social media platforms and content.Montana lawmakers worry about TikTok's data security and ties to the Chinese government.The ban is being mirrored in other states.The Montana prohibition is being challenged by TikTok and free speech advocates in court.But there are also other efforts to increase government regulations and scrutiny and law enforcement surveillance of social media.New York Gov. Kathy Hochul said Nov. 13 that state police have ramped up social media surveillance and will reach out more to individuals and groups posting hate speech online."We're very focused on the data we're collecting from surveillance efforts. What's being said on social media platforms.And we have launched an effort to be able to counter some of the negativity. and reach out to people when we see hate speech being spoken about on online platforms," Hochul said. "Our media analysis, our social media analysis unit, has ramped up its monitoring of sites to catch incitement to violence; direct threats to others." The New York governor said the rise in extremist and violent threats after the start of the war in the Middle East "poses a clear and present danger." But the idea of more aggressive police surveillance of social media posts raises some concerns.Gerard Kassar, chairman of the New York Conservative Party, said police social media monitoring is potentially "chilling to the core"."Law enforcement authorities can and should monitor legitimate terrorism suspects online, but spying on everyday citizens is unconstitutional and wrong," Kassar said.Republican presidential candidate and former South Carolina governor and U.S. ambassador Nikki Haley wants to require all social media accounts be verified by name thus eliminating anonymous online speech on major platforms."Every person on social media should be verified by their name," said Haley, who is increasingly being promoted as an establishment and neoconservative 2024 alternative to former president Donald Trump."First of all, it's a national security threat. When you do that, all of a sudden people have to stand by what they say. And it gets rid of the Russian bots, the Iranian bots and the Chinese bots. And then you're going to get some civility when people know their name is next to what they say, and they know their pastor and their family members are going to see it," Haley told Fox News.Haley also backs a TikTok ban pointing to the recent viral traffic of a letter criticizing Israel and the U.S. from Osama Bin Laden.Harris told Fox News Nov. 16 that Congress could soon take some actions related to TikTok and the issue will come down to speech versus national security, citing the platform's Chinese ownership.The verification push sparked a backlash from free speech advocates, particularly on the right who have already been upset over social media bans and content restrictions over coronavirus vaccines and challenges to the 2020 election results.They say it will eliminate anonymous dissent and speech."Nikki Haley is 'openly' pushing for the government to use private tech companies to censor speech. This is a flagrant violation of the Constitution and straight out of the Democrats' playbook.Any politician who thinks it's OK for the government to use the private sector as its censorship bureau shouldn't be allowed anywhere near the White House," said Vivek Ramaswamy, who has frequently sparred with Haley over TikTok and other issues.

title: Police: Fentanyl overdoses killed Perryville siblings, 10 and 14
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Police: Fentanyl overdoses killed Perryville siblings, 10 and 14

 March 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 422
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PERRYVILLE — An "accidental overdose" is what killed two children who were found unresponsive in their Perryville home in January — and now investigators are trying to determine how the illegal drug got into the residence, got into the siblings' possession and got into their systems, according to the Maryland State Police."The toxicology report came back positive for fentanyl," reported Elena Russo, an MSP spokeswoman.
MSP detectives and Cecil County Child Protective Services agents are involved in the ongoing investigation, according to Russo, who further reported that the Cecil County State's Attorney's Office "has been apprised of the ongoing investigation and is aware of the progress."
The drug overdoses claimed the lives of Skylar Alice Marie Jones, 14, and her 10-year-old brother, Gaige Marshall Dehaven.
Their 12-year-old sister found Skylar and Gaige unresponsive inside their residence in the 600 block of Cole Street early in the early afternoon of Jan. 16 and called 911, police said. The children lived at that Cole Street residence with their mother, police added. Investigators have not publicly identified their mother.
Troopers assigned to the agency's North East Barrack responded to the Cole Street residence shortly before 1:20 p.m. on Jan. 16 to assist Perryville Police Department officers with what law enforcement officials described at the time as the "cardiac arrest of two juveniles," police reported. Paramedics were attempting emergency medical care on the children when troopers arrived, police said. Paramedics later pronounced the boy and girl dead at the scene, police added.
"The sister reported her brother and sister were suffering from an unknown medical condition. She later told police that she came home and found her siblings unconscious on their bedroom floor. Police believe there was no one else in the home at the time," an MSP spokesperson outlined one day after the deadly incident.
That spokesperson also reported that "there was no indication of violence in the area surrounding the location where the juveniles were found."
Investigators found "drug paraphernalia" and "other items of evidentiary value" while searching the Cole Street residence, after obtaining a warrant to do so, police reported.
On Jan. 17, one day after the children died, MSP officials reported that the cause and manner of their deaths remained unknown after autopsies performed on the bodies of Skylar and Gaige "revealed no abnormalities." They further reported that, at that point, investigators were hopeful that then-pending toxicology results might reveal the cause and manner of the children's deaths.
MSP investigators recently received those toxicology results, which indicate that fentanyl overdoses caused the deaths of Skylar and Gaige, according to police.

title: Victims of crime, family members experience catharsis
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Victims of crime, family members experience catharsis

 May 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 943
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WORTON — There was healing through pain and hope shining through exceedingly dark times during the Maryland Statewide Memorial Service for crime victims and their families last week.Held at the Kent County Community Center, the service was hosted by the Baltimore, Carroll, Kent and St. Mary's County State's Attorney offices and the Maryland State Board of Victim Services.
Victim/Witness Coordinator for the Kent County State's Attorney's Office Shelly McMath said, the service alternates each year between counties. This year, it was in Kent County and had a turnout of about 30 people.
During the service, McMath was honored for her time and dedication.
"She's an angel," one of her clients said.
Another client and survivor of domestic assault, Abby Joiner, said McMath was instrumental in her healing process.
"I am thankful to the village of people who helped me heal," Joyner said.
During this somber ceremony to remember victims of crime and their families, Kent County professionals who work in the crime field all had a role to play.
Following some emotional lyrics and skilled keyboard play by musician Marion Saunders, Rock Hall Police Chief William Dempsey read "Say Their Names," adapted from a book by Don Hackett, "Say Olin to Say Goodbye."
Guests called out the names of the victims they wished to memorialize.
Along that same spirit, Kent County Clerk of Courts Sherise Kennard read the poem "Don't Quit" by Edgar Albert Guest.
It's a reminder that in the most trying of times, sunnier skies are ahead.
Commissioner Albert Nickerson was the guest speaker for the day. He grew emotional when talking about his brother, Michael Scott Nickerson, who was killed in the line of duty in the 300 block of Hammond Street in Centreville on Feb. 13, 2001.
His message was that through adversity, it's vital to seek out a support system, family and friends, and to turn personal pain into productivity — a way to help others.
Those survivors who stepped up to talk next exemplified that determination. They spoke of their traumatizing ordeals but also about the strength to live on, thrive and prosper.
Celestine Heath's 15-year-old niece, I'kea Nicole Jackson, was murdered Dec. 5, 2016, in Glenn Burnie, she told attendees. As horrific as that was, she said God got the family through. Now she sees reflections of Jackson's personality in her 7-year-old granddaughter.
Fighting back tears, Heath said the two are so much alike that "her and I'kea would have had a ball together."
Lorena Batson dealt with her ex-husband's domestic violence for eight years before having the courage to break free. Now, she's remarried, healed, and has a great relationship with her husband and children.
One of McMath's first victim-survivors, Amy Mitchell, was attacked in Rock Hall in 2007, when a person she knew for several years became "increasingly diabolical." McMath's guidance connected Mitchell to the Whitsitt Center, where she got sober, and because her abuser violated his protective order, the system put him away.
She's thankful for the services and thankful for Kent County as a supportive place to live.
Reflecting back, Mitchell said she's amazed at the life she has now.
Many more victim-survivors stepped up to tell their story.
All were different, but the drive to overcome despite the circumstances was a common theme.
Sue Nickerson, the commissioner's mother, added to her son's story, reliving those moments of riding to the hospital after hearing that her son was shot.
Looking back, she said she's grateful for the huge amount of support she received from family and friends, especially during the two-year period between the incident and the trial of her son's killer.
Now she helps others through their pain as the president and executive director of the Maryland Concerns of Police Survivors.
She found a way to still see her son in the profession he loved.
"I was told a long time ago that if I were to look into the center of every officer's badge, I would see Michael," she said.
McMath said talking about these experiences encourages others to step up.
Even Kennard walked up to the podium to speak, not as Clerk of Courts, but as a victim survivor.
For the first time publicly she told the tragic story of her mother, Joyce Henson, who was set on fire by her husband while Kennard was in school at 16 years of age.
Kennard drew strength from that, seeing the way her mother was able to embrace life after being burned on 80% of her body.
"She is a survivor, thank God. She is so strong. She's physically burned, but when I look at her I see beauty and faith," Kennard said.
Beth Anne Dorman, president For All Seasons, spoke close to last, and was also closely acquainted with domestic violence. Not only did she work with victims everyday, as a clinician, she witnessed it through her husband, whose sister was killed at the hands of an ex-boyfriend.
Dorman said she sees how it affected him and his journey to come to terms with it.
She encouraged survivors to do everything they can to care for their well-being, taking the time and space they need to heal.
After a responsive reading of "We Remember Them" written by Marilyn Gilbert and read by Chief Ron Dixon of the Chestertown Police Department, McMath was honored.
She accepted two proclamations from the Governor's Office and the State's Attorney's Office of Kent County with gratitude, recalling later how she started working with the police as a dispatcher right out of high school.
She said she loves what she does, helping people through tough times and getting them the services they need.
Master of Ceremonies, Kent State's Attorney Bryan DiGregory, said, "I have been fortunate enough to work with Shelly. Her intelligence is only surpassed by her compassion. And I think many of you in this room know her compassion. It's extraordinary."

title: Warriors battle but can’t extend win streak against undefeated Bennett
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Warriors battle but can’t extend win streak against undefeated Bennett

 October 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 714

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Avery Brice was eager for Monday night."I was very excited about this game tonight just to see where we were at as far as playing against top competition," Easton High's first-year boys head soccer coach said of facing undefeated and defending Bayside Conference champion James M. Bennett.
After 80 minutes, the Warriors were where everyone else has been this season after playing the Clippers — behind on the scoreboard.
And yet despite watching Easton's four-game win streak come to a halt in a 3-0 loss, Brice was largely encouraged by what he saw from his team.
"Goals change momentum," said Brice, who watched the Clippers take a 1-0 lead, when star Noah Blankensop gained possession on left wing, and, with Easton keeper Sam Hutchison far from his goal, sent a ball drifting over everyone before settling into the right side of the net with 15 minutes, 27 seconds left in the first half. "I loved how we responded. Going down a goal sucks. Guys responded great. Better than we have previously. We get scored on and it's like, 'Wow.' You just see everyone drop. But tonight you saw guys, 'Hey come on. Next play. Let's go again.' I was really proud of them for that."
Brice was also proud of Hutchison's play in goal. The junior keeper stopped a hard shot by Blankensop in the 9th minute and made a save on Sebastien Dorvelus just a moment later to keep the game scoreless. Hutchison then made perhaps his stop of the game, when he punched away a shot that banged off the left post with 7 minutes left in the first half, keeping it a one-goal game.
"Goalie had a huge night," Brice said of Hutchison, who finished with 11 saves. "Crazy saves. One of the best games I've seen him play."
Bennett (8-0), which has beaten six of its eight opponents this season by six or more goals — the exceptions, Queen Anne's (3-0 on Sept. 19) and now Easton — looked ready to take a 1-0 lead halftime. But with just over 10 seconds remaining, Grant Ziervogel served a ball that Easton's Felix Valentin attempted to head away, only to watch it go into the net for a 2-0 Clippers lead.
"The own goal, miscommunication," Brice said. "We learn from it. Felix, he is an amazing defender and I told him, he's saved games prior to this. 'Don't even worry about it. It happens. It's part of the game.'"
The Warriors (6-2) thought they cut their deficit in half with 20:20 left in the game, when Clay Nagel, with Bennett keeper Jake Ziervogel away from the goal and two defenders on his back, caught up to a ball and touched it into the net. But the goal was waved off, when Nagel was ruled offsides.
"First competitive (game)," Bennett head coach Gabe Kane said. "First one that wasn't decided by halftime.
"We don't want 12 strolls," said Kane in reference to the Clippers outscoring their opponents, 53-2 this season. "We want to be battle tested, and Easton came at us for 80 minutes today. There was no quit in them. They seemed to play harder after the third goal. I think they had more chances at the end of the game when I know they were tired. But they kept battling."
Bennett bumped its lead to 3-0 as Grason Adkins scored from the right side of the box with 7:26 left.
Jake Ziervogel, who according to Kane has not had more than one save in a game this season prior to Monday, made a leaping stop on Ale Monroy with 6:45 left. Blankensop, who was recruited by a number of Division I schools but is headed to Salisbury University, just missed pushing the lead to 4-0 in the waning moments when he blasted a shot off the crossbar.
"I knew they were going to be our best opponent we'd play to date," Brice said. "I think we made some silly mistakes and we paid for them. But they are just minor ones. We switched off for a moment, not marking in the box, not getting and winning the second ball in the box.
"The score does not reflect how we played," Brice continued. "I think going forward, we work on finishing our chances and then just being a little more creative up top."

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education on Wednesday approved contracts for two upcoming projects: auditorium lights at Easton High School and windows at Chapel District Elementary School.New auditorium lights at Easton High will be installed in the summer of 2026, Director of Operations Kevin Shafer told board members. Shafer said some preliminary work will be done this spring before school ends. The school play and other concerts or events won't be impacted, Shafer said.

 CHESTERTOWN — On Oct. 17, health agencies, partners, businesses, nonprofits and community organizations attended the Kent County Family YMCA for the annual Health and Wellness Expo.Pickleball players and basketball hoopers were momentarily replaced with health vendors. Tables were set up in the gymnasium, where attendees could get information for health wellness; anything from house gutter protection to cochlear ear implant options.
"This expo is dedicated to fostering partnerships among local organizations that provide valuable services and education on essential health and wellness topics," said Gale Drenning president of HomePorts, a partner of the event.
This year, Acme Pharmacy provided flu and COVID vaccines.
At the next table over, the new Health Educator at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Chestertown, Sandy Wilson-Hypes demonstrated CPR practices on a mannequin, inviting guests to try it out.
Teenager, Nate Perogoy was up for the challenge, exercising chest compressions to the tune "Staying Alive," a perfect tempo at 100/120 compressions per minute.
In addition to the vendors, classes were provided.
In "Unlock the Secrets of Ancient Nutrition," Bill Schindler author, internationally-known chef and founder of Eastern Shore Food Lab, instructed how to get the most nutrients from food and sustain your health amid a worldview of unhealthy practices.
Lt. Sean Maloney of the Kent County Sheriff's Office gave his presentation: "Don't Be A Victim! The Latest Scams, Schemes, and Frauds." He said threats come from everywhere: computer hackers, romance scams, fake scanners at ATMs and stores, dumpster diving and mail.
He pointed out victims can be anybody, but especially retirees with disposable income.
Gloria Carter offered a dance-based cardio class, available Mondays and Wednesdays at the YMCA.
Throughout the afternoon, while people went from table to table, they were treated to the musical talents of River Voices from Chester River Chorale directed by Stephanie LaMotte.
Outside, under a blue sky and moderate weather, food was provided by Happy Chicken and Lockbriar Farms. Patrons enjoyed squash soup, pumpkin ice cream and fresh-pressed apple cider.
The expo was well-attended, with over 300 programs handed out, said a volunteer.
Throughout the years the expo had many homes, but for the past three years the YMCA has been proud to host it.
Executive Director of the YMCA Erica Osterhout and her staff expressed excitement welcoming the expo each year.

 STEVENSVILLE — Compass Regional Hospice welcomed more than 200 guests to shop, bid on auction items and enjoy lunch while benefiting local hospice care during its annual fashion show Sept. 18 at Kent Island Resort. The sold-out event showcased selections from Compass Closet, the organization's retail consignment boutique, with prominent community members serving as volunteer models. "We are excited to reach out to more of the community," said Jessica Sherbrooke, volunteer manager. "The community always comes out for a great time and shows their full support," Guerieri said. The consignment boutique operates entirely through volunteers, who Sherbrooke described as essential to Compass' mission. Leading up to the event, Compass highlighted volunteers through fashion show model spotlights on social media. Compass Closet is located in Kent Towne Center in Chester. title: Rardin scores five goals in return as top-seeded Sabres grind way past Falcons for spot in MIAA B Conference championship
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Rardin scores five goals in return as top-seeded Sabres grind way past Falcons for spot in MIAA B Conference championship

 May 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 881
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — It was the No. 1 seed.It had won 11 of its last 12 games, and had already twice beaten its opponent.
But none of that matter to Saints Peter and Paul High boys head lacrosse coach Todd Wolters after the first half of Tuesday's Maryland Interscholastic Athletic Association B Conference semifinal.
After mustering just one first-quarter goal and carrying a four-goal cushion into halftime, Wolters made clear to his team he wasn't happy.
"Coach pulled us over at halftime and told us that this could be the end of our season," sophomore face-off man Grant Messick said. "'We could be done here.' But none of us want that. I think he kind of brought that out of us, just saying we could be going to Navy this Friday to win a championship that hasn't been done in a decade."
The Sabres responded, outscoring No. 4 Gerstell Academy by three goals in a decisive third quarter, catapulting them to a 13-8 victory on a dreary Tuesday afternoon.
Sts. Peter & Paul (15-4) advances to Friday's MIAA B Conference championship game where it will meet second-seed and two-time defending champion Archbishop Curley (11-7) at Navy-Marine Corps Memorial Stadium at 5 p.m. The Sabres defeated Curley twice during the regular season.
"They were taking a team lightly, like they've already won," said Wolters, whose team won 7-6 at Gerstell on April 12, then routed the Falcons 16-3 on their home turf April 30. "And they've done that before. We just lose focus."
In his first game back from injury, JJ Rardin (five goals) gave the Sabres a 1-0 lead with 2:22 left in the first quarter, when he scored off an assist from Andrew Steinhardt.
Gerstell (6-10) tied the score on Bronson Peters' goal less than 2 minutes into the second quarter. Rardin gained possession out in front of the net and fired his second goal just under the crossbar to make it 2-1 just 18 seconds later. But the Falcons came right back with Ryan Ellis beating Sabres goalie Hank Wolters (11 saves) to make it 2-all.
Davis Kimminau whipped a shot in from the right side, and less than two minutes later, set up Vincent Dyer's goal to nudge Sts. Peter & Paul to a 4-2 lead. But Peters (four goals) scored at the midway point of the second quarter to make it a one-goal game again.
"They came out and they didn't want their season to end," Messick said of Gerstell. "They came out with nothing to lose. We're the one seed. They come out and they beat us, then it's a huge upset. And if they don't it's not what they were expected to do. So I think they had that mentality while we came out thinking, 'Well, we smoked them before. We're going to roll them this time.' But they didn't. They came out and they fought really hard."
The Sabres scored the last three goals of the half, as Liam Durnbaugh, Noah Zimmerman and Rardin each tallied to make it 7-3 at the break.
"Our guys were in it," Gerstell head coach Ryan Drenner said. "We stayed in the fight the entire game. That was the biggest difference. We were here a couple weeks ago April 30. Very lopsided. We try to learn a lesson from every game regardless of the outcome of the game. And so for that one it was we had to come up with a better plan of how to travel down here and be ready to go from the jump. So we changed how we warm up just to be a little bit more alert from the start. I thought our guys did that today and we played four quarters of a great lacrosse game."
Gerstell cut its deficit to 7-4 just 19 seconds into the third quarter on a goal by Peters. Zimmerman scored for the Sabres, but Matthew Schols answered for the Falcons.
Sts. Peter & Paul took control the remainder of the quarter, getting one goal each from Steinhardt (four assists) and Kimminau, and two more from Rardin for a 12-5 lead heading into the fourth quarter.
"We know how good we are," Wolters said. "The third quarter we go and we really just started opening it up. And then in the fourth quarter we thought it was done."
The Sabres extended their lead to 13-5 before Gerstell scored the game's final three goals.
"We weren't hustling," Wolters said of certain stretches. "We'd come down and throw it away and then they would go down and score on unsettled situations. They had eight goals and I know five to six were unsettled and we can't have that.
"It's a win. We'll take it," Wolters said. "You can't win a championship unless you're in the championship. And we're in the championship."

COL. RICHARDSON 1, ST. MICHAELS 0
AMERICAN CORNER — Jack Walls walked, advanced to second and third on a pair of low pitches, and raced home on a wild pitch in the third inning for what proved to be the only run Tuesday, as Colonel Richardson blanked the Saints to win the Class 1A East Region II final.
Colonel Richardson winning pitcher Daniel Hesson hurled a two-hitter. Connor Wheeler and Henry Mullikin each had a hit for the Saints.

title: Dyer achieves Eagle Scout

Dyer achieves Eagle Scout

 March 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — A crowd of family, politicians, civic leaders and Boy Scouts assembled in the Scout House on St. Mary's Square to present the Eagle Scout Badge to Vincent Thomas Dyer Sunday.Multiple candles were lit to commemorate different aspects of his journey that started when he was 5. This is the highest honor a Scout can achieve and only about four in 100 Scouts reach it.
Dyer's sash had 26 merit badges on it, and his final project was raising $2,000 to raise a flag pole honoring veterans in Cordova. Of course, this achievment took hours of input from his family, his Troop 741 leaders and his fellow Scouts.
"It is now time to formally present you with Scouting's highest badge of accomplishment. The symbol of your success is the Eagle Scout badge and neckerchief, which will now be presented by your parents," Scoutmaster Brendan Beers said.
One of the most touching moments was when his parents, Paul and Kimberly, attached the Eagle Scout pin. He then attached pins on them for being a supportive Eagle Scout mom and dad.
Vincent's brother Paul Jr., also an Eagle Scout, said, "What does the rank of Eagle Scout represent? To me it represents saying you are going to do something and then doing it. It represents goals realized, focus and strength of character. When the pressure is on and others would run around and panic, the Eagle Scout stays calm, cool and collected in the face of atrocity."
Another person who was there to guide and bear witness is Steve Bealefeld, assistant scoutmaster.
He said, "He is a hard-working young man who has always had his head on straight."
Vincent's father listed many of the places the Scout troop went to go camping like the C & O Canal, Dorchester County and Tennessee. The biggest test was a 10-day hike at Philmont in New Mexico.
There was a testament to Vincent's leadership in the field. He was said to be an excellent cook with a Dutch oven. He can make peach cobbler and chicken pot pie.
"When he was in the lead, you were never going in the wrong direction. In the spartan wilds of Philmont, this was no small feat. Vincent is an excellent navigator. Vincent's attitude was equally as unflagging as his physical stamina. There is a deep keeled steadiness to his emotional thermostat," scout leader JoRoy Lizewski said.
Then it was time for the politicians to offer large citations. President of Town of St. Michael's Commission David Breimhurst, Del. Tom Hutchison (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), community liaison to Andy Harris Mike Detmer and Maryland state Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) all spoke briefly. Vincent was given the United States flag and the Maryland Flag.
Vincent had the last word.
"I am so proud. I am happy that all my friends from 190 and 741 were here to celebrate this event with me, because it has been a long time coming. It is a bittersweet moment. I am glad I got Eagle Scout, but I will miss Scouting as a whole," Vincent said.
He tentatively has plans to attend University of Maryland at College Park in the fall.

title: Former 1st-rounders Toney, Farley cut
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Former 1st-rounders Toney, Farley cut

 August 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 1124
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Kansas City receiver Kadarius Toney and Tennessee cornerback Caleb Farley, both first-round picks in the 2021 NFL draft, were among the cuts Tuesday as teams trimmed their rosters for the regular season.Toney, who figured to be on the roster bubble, was on his second team since the New York Giants drafted him 20th overall three years ago. The Titans took Farley two picks later.
Teams had to cut their rosters to 53 players from the training camp maximum of 90. Toney, Farley and hundreds of others will be eligible to return on practice squads that allow up to 17 players, including a spot allocated for the International Player Pathway Program.
Miami receiver Odell Beckham Jr. will begin the season on the physically unable to perform list, meaning he'll miss at least the first four games. Beckham has not seen the field with the Dolphins since signing a one-year contract in May.
San Francisco's initial roster is missing a big piece with holdout All-Pro left tackle Trent Williams remaining on the reserve/did not report list as he seeks a new deal. Star receiver Brandon Aiyuk is on the roster but has refused to practice unless he gets a new contract or is traded.
Injuries shortened both of Toney's first two seasons, and he was traded to the Chiefs during his second year with the Giants. The 25-year-old never displayed his dynamic playmaking skills consistently, but did have a big role in the first of the two Super Bowl rings he got with the Chiefs.
In a three-minute span in the fourth quarter of Kansas City's 38-35 win over Philadelphia in Super Bowl 57, Toney made two monumental plays. First, he caught a 5-yard TD pass that gave the Chiefs a 28-27 lead. Then, he returned a punt 65 yards to the Eagles 5-yard line to set up another TD.
But Toney couldn't build off that success. He struggled last season, was inactive from Week 15 through the playoffs and sat out when the Chiefs finished their repeat against San Francisco.
Kansas City added veteran wideout Marquise "Hollywood" Brown and drafted Xavier Worthy in the first round to go with Rashee Rice. The Chiefs also have Skyy Moore, Mecole Hardman and Justin Watson.
The Titans drafted Farley out of Virginia Tech after he was the first player from a major college to opt out of the 2020 season because of the pandemic. Farley was drafted weeks after a second surgery to repair a back injury from college.
Farley started just twice as injuries limited him to 12 games over his first two seasons. Farley had another back procedure in 2023.
The 25-year-old never played last season. The Titans kept him on the physically unable to perform list after his father was killed last August in an explosion that destroyed Farley's home in North Carolina.
Arizona released quarterback Desmond Ridder, which means Clayton Tune will be Kyler Murray's backup. Ridder started 13 games for Atlanta last season before being traded to the Cardinals in the offseason.
Jacksonville released eight-year veteran quarterback C.J. Beathard with an injury designation, presumably clearing the way for Mac Jones to back up Trevor Lawrence. Jones started 42 games over the past three seasons with New England after the Patriots drafted him in the first round in 2021.
Receiver JuJu Smith-Schuster was cut by the Chiefs after re-signing with them following his release by the Patriots this month.
The Cowboys put CeeDee Lamb on the commissioner exempt list a day after the All-Pro receiver agreed to a $136 million, four-year contract extension that ended his preseason-long holdout. Lamb signed the contract Tuesday.
The move allowed the Cowboys to put offensive lineman Chuma Edoga on the 53-man roster for a day. Lamb would take the place of Edoga, who could return from injured reserve sooner than four weeks.
Seattle had outside linebacker Uchenna Nwosu on the active roster, a sign the Seahawks believe the three-year starter can be ready in fewer than four games. Nwosu injured a knee in the preseason finale.
The New York Jets waived safety Jaylen Key, who was "Mr. Irrelevant" as the last pick in the draft. The former UAB and Alabama standout had a solid training camp, but was buried on the depth chart behind starters Chuck Clark and Tony Adams and veteran reserves Ashtyn Davis and Jarrick Bernard-Converse.
The Minnesota Vikings kept recovering tight end T.J. Hockenson on the physically unable to perform list, meaning the two-time Pro Bowler must miss at least the first four games. Hockenson is working through the final stage of his rehabilitation after tearing an ACL against Detroit last Dec. 24.
The Vikings waived safety Lewis Cine, the final pick of the first round two years ago in the first draft directed by general manager Kwesi Adofo-Mensah.
Cine badly broke his leg on special teams in a game early in his rookie year and never made much traction on the depth chart last season. He played a total of 10 defensive snaps in two seasons.
Denver let go of receiver Tim Patrick, whose TD in the second preseason game was his first in 974 days. Patrick, who sustained season-ending injuries at start of training camp in 2022 and '23, had a solid summer but was victim of the Broncos' depth at his position.
As expected, Cleveland placed star running back Nick Chubb on the physically unable to perform list as he continues to recover from two surgeries last year. The club is optimistic Chubb will play this season.
The Browns released running back D'Onta Foreman, who overcame a scary neck injury in training camp. With Nyheim Hines on the non-football injury list, the Browns currently have only Jerome Ford and Pierre Strong Jr. at running back.
Washington released veteran receiver Martavis Bryant, who is in his second season of trying to end a long hiatus from the NFL.
The oft-suspended 32-year-old, who last played in the NFL in 2018, spent most of last season on Dallas' practice squad and could land in the same place with the Commanders, who signed him Aug. 13.
For the second season in a row, the Saints are making a change at punter, and again, they're going with an Australian rookie. This time it's 27-year-old Matthew Hayball taking over for 31-year-old Lou Hedley, who surprisingly won the job a year earlier.
The Buffalo Bills released receiver K.J. Hamler, their primary preseason returner, and filled the hole on special teams by acquiring defensive back Brandon Codrington in a trade with the AFC East rival Jets. The teams swapped late-round picks in next year's draft.

title: Talbot County farmers markets ready for spring season
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Talbot County farmers markets ready for spring season

 April 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 667
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As sure as bumblebees circling blossoms, the opening of Mid-Shore farmers markets is a sign of spring.The fresh and local offerings will start this weekend in St. Michaels and next weekend in Easton.
The Easton Farmers Market, opening on April 20, will be open on Saturdays from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m.
According to Marie Pierre Nuthall, the outdoor event manager for the Avalon Foundation, which runs the Easton Farmers Market, the weekly event is about supporting local artisans, bakers, farmers, watermen and more.
"Farmers markets are important because they support local small businesses," Nathall said. "The money is kept in the community. Everything you see is either grown here or produced here. Nothing is flown in. It is supporting and sustaining our own food production on the Shore."
The full scale market opening on April 20 will be an expansion of the Avalon Foundation's Winter Market, which it has run in the off-season. The full market will run until the second week of December, after which the Winter Market will pick back up.
"This year was the first that we went all year round with some vendors. This constitutes the opening of the Spring Market in its full glory as we expand to fill the entire municipal lot," Nuthall said. "We have lots of vegetables because many of our farmers are growing in high tunnels. We do have vendors there this Saturday, but the full market won't open until April 20."
The market is located in a municipal parking lot on the 100 block of North Harrison Street in downtown Easton.
Some of the vendors include Triangle Acres, Cottingham Farm, Honeybee Flower Farm, The Federal Brewing Company, CD Produce, Quarter Acre Farm and Gingersnap Farm.
The market will have several bakeries, produce growers and local honey. It will have woodworking and textile crafts for sale, along with other locally-made goods. There will be live music every Saturday starting at 10:30 a.m.
An interactive map of vendors is available at maps.managemymarket.
Nuthall said in addition to being able to view the roster of vendors for the duration of the calendar year, those who visit the link can also view vendor contact information, the types of items they sell and their location in the market.
There is parking available at Brewer's Lane, or the lot on the corner of Washington and Bay Streets. There will be a marked accessible parking space for those with disability parking needs.
The St. Michaels Farmers Market will be open from April 13 to Nov. 23 on Saturdays from 8:30 to 11:30 a.m. It is located on 206 S. Talbot Street.
"(St. Michaels Farmers Market) is in its 27th season and is the small town, producer-only farmers market of Maryland's Eastern Shore," said Market Manager Sandy Lawler. "We are also the only market on the Eastern Shore that has a SNAP dollar for dollar matching program."
Like Easton, the St. Michaels market has a wide array of bakers, farmers and artisans. Some of these include Little Fields Floral, Tilghman Island Baking, D&D Dog Treats, Scottish Highland Creamery, Chesapeake Mushrooms and Lyon Rum. There is also a weekly changing community and education tent and weekly musicians. Building African American Minds will be in the community and education tent on opening day.
For veggies, vendors include Shaky Wheelbarrow Herb Sales, Krieder's Tomatoes, Oksana's Produce Farm, Vintage Family Farm and Mindful Acres. Cottingham will have organic vegetables.
Night Kitchen Coffee Roasters, Casa Carmen Wines, Willwaw Farm, Fat and Happy Farms and Agave Juice and Elysium Farm will all be offering their creations.
Lawler put her finger on why this market is so enduring.
"Farmers Markets are important for so many reasons," she said. "... The biggest one is the support of our own community. Neighbor feeding neighbor with minimal transport, which means fresher healthier products including a lower environmental impact. Knowing your farmer means you are buying from someone who is a steward of the land."
Opening day, the market will have Talbot County Public Schools students playing from 8:30 to 9:30 a.m., followed by WabiSabi to close.
For more information, call 410-713-0507.

title: LIONS EXTEND REIGN
author: Bill Haufe
content:
LIONS EXTEND REIGN

 May 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 908
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — The thought was to pull the ball out, burn some clock, and perhaps go for the last shot.Then Baillie Pinder found herself alone in front of the net with the ball.
"Baillie's a see net, shoot net," Queen Anne's County High girls head lacrosse coach Kesley Fitzgerald said. "And she put one up for us. That was an awesome play."
Pinder found the back of the net for what proved to me the winning goal with 3:08 remaining, then watched goalie Maddie George and her defense survive three shots in a frenetic final 20 seconds Monday, as the Lions held on for a 7-6 victory over Stephen Decatur and their third straight Bayside Conference championship at Kent Island High's Andy Schipul Stadium.
"It feels so good to win, especially after losing the first time," Pinder said of Queen Anne's 10-7 loss at Decatur on April 16. "This time I think we knew we were a better team, and we had changed since the beginning of the season. And we had a lot more confidence in ourselves, and we really just wanted to come out and prove ourselves."
But Decatur senior Sadie Kauffman (four goals) scored to break a 4-4 tie with 8:27 left in the third quarter, then converted a Lions turnover into a 6-4 Seahawks lead less than 3 minutes later.
That would prove to be Decatur's final goal though.
"Stephen Decatur did an amazing job," Fitzgerald said. "We just needed to execute on our possessions a little bit better and show a little bit more patience. But they always make it happen. I trust them. We're in those huddles and they're giving feedback on what needs to happen on the draw and they're the ones out there."
Among those out there was junior standout RJ Ensor (four goals, assist), who pulled the Lions (11-2) within 6-5 with 2:26 left in the third, when she scored on a free-position opportunity.
The Lions pulled even at 6-all with 5:44 left, as Ensor took a feed from Pinder (two goals, three assists) and deposited an overhand shot past Decatur goalie Addison McDaniel.
Kauffman won the ensuing draw, but the Seahawks turned the ball over with 4 minutes remaining.
"We were calling to pull it out and take a little bit more time off, and maybe work for last shot. And she finds herself right on top of the goal," Fitzgerald said of Pinder.
Pinder didn't miss, dumping a shot past McDaniel for a 7-6 Lions lead.
"We knew that we could come back," Pinder said. "We just had to play patient and smart, and we knew we had it.
"I knew I had to take my time and put it in the net," Pinder said of her game-winner. "I knew I was on top of the goal and knew I had to do it and make it."
Decatur called time and appeared to win the ensuing draw. But the Seahawks were called for an apparent empty-stick check, that initially appeared to be against the Lions.
"I don't understand what it was," Decatur head coach Lindsay Owens said. "I definitely thought it was an empty-stick check on Queen Anne's because Sadie's stick went flying. And he (the official) was pointing our way too.
"But here's the thing," Owens continued. "We shouldn't have left it up to the ref's call. It shouldn't come down to whether a ref makes a call or not. I can never blame a ref on a game. That's the easy way out. And we had every opportunity to try and seal the deal."
The Seahawks had three chances to at least tie the deal in the final 20.6 seconds. Caitlin Shimko fired high on a free-position attempt. Jillian Burton got the ball and sent a shot wide left. Kennedy Kirby managed to get off one final shot that George got to and covered to secure the win.
"I'm not going to lie, I was nervous," George said. "But I was keeping it composed. I was just telling myself, 'We got this. We got this.' We've worked so hard for this and it's all paying off.
Decatur took a 1-0 lead on Ava Konyar's goal less than 3 minutes into the game. Queen Anne's tied it on Ensor's first goal with under 7 minutes to play in the first quarter. McDaniel made a huge point-blank stop on Pinder. But the Lions' senior attacker retrieved the ball and tucked a shot into the back of the net for a 2-1 lead with 5:05 left in the opening period.
Kauffman tied the game at 2-2 on a free-position chance 2:11 into the second. Riley Klepper pushed the Lions back in front less than a minute later. Kirby forged the game's third tie with 3:29 left in the first half. Ensor scored a free-position goal with 43.1 seconds to go in the half. Kauffman won the following draw, raced downfield, and after a few stick fakes put a sinker past George for a 4-4 halftime tie.
But the Lions goalie and her defense shut out the Seahawks over the game's final 17:50, including the chaotic final 20 seconds.
"That's Maddie George," Fitzgerald said. "She comes out and that's her style of play. We forced a lot of girls to shoot the high shot and were on their sticks all night. Maddie at that point, when she's in situations like that, she's locked in and just doing anything she can. It might not be the most soundest thing but she's making sure that ball does not go by her body."

Snow fall brings snow day on the Eastern Shore

 January 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News

 EASTON — Residents woke up to two inches of snow Tuesday morning in Easton.With the snow came a snow day for Talbot County Public Schools students. Weather conditions caused the school system to close for the entire day.
Dorchester County Public Schools also closed for the day due to icy road conditions. Caroline County Public Schools closed for students, but offices opened at 10 a.m. for its 12-month employees.
Easton's Superintendent of Public Works Mike Dickerson said Easton Public Works used 46.92 tons of salt to keep the town's roadways safe. He said the department applied salt to the town's main roads — roads like Washington Street that get you into town — three times.
After receiving a notification from the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, Easton Public Works began salting roads at 4 p.m. Monday. Dickerson said the last of the department's five trucks finished salting for the third time at 4:44 a.m. on Tuesday.
"We had five trucks out," he said. "And each one of them has an assigned route."
According to the National Weather Service, winter weather advisories for Queen Anne's, Talbot and Caroline counties were issued early Tuesday morning and in effect until 1 p.m. on Tuesday.
The advisories were for mixed precipitation with additional snow of up to an inch and ice accumulation of around one 10th of an inch. The advisories stated that morning commutes could be affected due to slippery road conditions.
Dorchester County received a winter weather advisory from the National Weather Service for freezing rain and additional ice accumulation. The advisory was in effect until 11 a.m. Tuesday morning.
As of noon on Tuesday, according to the National Weather Service, snow and freezing rain were likely in Easton before 1 p.m. with a chance of rain and snow between 1 p.m. and 2 p.m. and a chance of more snow after 2 p.m. Little or no snow accumulation is expected. A tenth of an inch of ice accumulation is possible.
Dickerson said Easton Public Works has its trucks prepared in the event that employees have to go back out to take care of the roads.

title: Warriors rally to edge Bucs
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Warriors rally to edge Bucs

 September 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Jordan Horsey had a question for his teammates at halftime."I just told the guys, 'How bad do you not want to lose this game,'" Easton High's junior football standout inquired.
A little over an hour later, Horsey had his answer.
Horsey scored all three Easton touchdowns, including a game-tying 1-yard dive into the end zone with 1 minute, 28 seconds remaining, then watched Luke Stanco drill the point-after kick Friday night, lifting the Warriors' to a 21-20 come-from-behind victory over Kent Island.
"The boys played hard," Easton head coach Matt Griffith said after his team improved to 3-0. "They didn't quit. That's the biggest thing I'm proud of. They're dogs."
After a scoreless first quarter, Kent Island (1-2) took a 3-0 lead on Spencer Chappell's 44-yard field goal with 7:06 left in the first half. The Buccaneers stretched that lead to 10-0, when running back Jaxson Hess caught a short pass from quarterback Trace Klapaska and broke a handful of tackles en route to a 52-yard touchdown 32 seconds before intermission. Chappell added the extra point.
"The speed of the game was really fast, especially for our quarterback and our offensive line," said Griffith, who watched quarterback Brady Walls battle pressure for most of the first half. "They've got a great defense. They play fast, they play hard.
"Tim had a great game plan," Griffith added of Kent Island head coach Tim Goodrich. "We've played each other so many times. He's got a lot of defenses you practice for. So even what they were doing we practice. But you can't simulate how hard and how fast they play. They gave us a helluva time in the first half."
Kent Island put the Warriors in a deeper hole with just under 8 minutes left in the third quarter, when fullback Alex Brestensky busted loose for an 87-yard touchdown jaunt that — together with another Chappell PAT — made it 17-0.
Easton answered.
Three Jamier Copper carries netted 26 yards. Horsey ran for 8 and 5 yards. Walls then connected with Kyree Acree for a 37-yard gain, setting up the first of Horsey's three TD runs, a 3-yard run up the middle. Stanco's first PAT made it 17-7 with 5:33 left in the third quarter.
The Bucs widened their lead to 20-7 with 1:26 to go in the third on Chappell's 42-yard field goal.
Kent Island maintained that 13-point cushion, when Easton took over from its own 20 with 7:13 left in the game. Walls hit Zach Barnhart for a 42-yard pickup, completed a 12-yard gain to Carter Mooney, then found Barnhart for a 21-yard to the 1. Horsey capped the drive, slamming in from the 1. Stanco's second PAT made it 20-14 with 6:03 to go.
Easton forced a three-and-out and took possession at its 30 with 4:23 remaining. A 9-yard completion from Walls to Barnhart coupled with a roughing-the-passer penalty on Kent Island, moved the Warriors to Kent Island's 40.
On third-and-10, Walls dumped a short pass to Horsey for a 22-yard pickup. A Walls-to-Mooney connection pushed Easton to the Bucs' 6. Horsey carried for gains of 2 and 3 yards, before launching himself over the goal line from 1 to tie the game at 20-20 with 1:28 left.
"I felt like (NFL Hall of Fame running back) Emmitt Smith jumping over the pile," Horsey said of his tying touchdown.
On came Stanco to convert his third PAT of the game for a 21-20 lead.
"After I made the first (point-after) kick, got the nervousness out," Stanco said. "Then I made the second and we got close. And then the game was on me; game was on the line. I had to put it through the uprights and I did."
"I was nervous for him," Griffith said of Stanco. "We've struggled on our special teams this year. It was an emphasis this week that specials had to be perfect and we were pretty good tonight. That was big. He (Stanco) has a great leg. He's very talented. And so does Kai Ferraris. Both of them, very talented. They just need more reps and it's hard when they're soccer players."
Kent Island's Andy Bennett returned the ensuing kickoff 10 yards before slipping at the 25. Four incompletions later, Easton took over, with Walls taking a knee twice to complete one of the bigger come-from-behind wins over Griffith's career as head coach.
"Second half I think we wore them down a little bit and we hit some big plays," Griffith said. "And that was the difference."

title: Oxford moves $2 million from BayVanguard
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Oxford moves $2 million from BayVanguard

 September 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News

 Words

 OXFORD - The Commissioners of Oxford voted to temporarily move $2 million from an account with BayVanguard Bank to the investment bank, Maryland Local Government Investment Pool, at a town meeting Tuesday.Of the three commissioners, Commissioner Susan Delean-Botkin voted against this decision to move the money for two weeks until Town Manager Cheryl Lewis can come back with a report on alternative investment options.With this report, the commissioners will be able to compare different rates and decide whether it makes sense to put the money back into BayVanguard Bank or keep it elsewhere.The money being moved is currently earmarked for temporary funding for capital projects, Lewis said. She said the town will be using it as cash flow and so that $2 million amount will fluctuate.Commissioner Katrina Greer, who made the motion to temporarily move the money, said investment pool is offering higher interest rates than BayVanguard Bank, which she said impacts the town's budget. She said MLGIP's rate is almost 5.4%, while BayVanguard is offering 4% rates."Heretofore, [BayVanguard Bank] had our $3 million to $4 million of regular checking accounts at an absurdly low rate at three-10ths of a percent," Greer said to Lewis during the meeting. "And I realize you did get it moved up to 4%, but they really needed to step up to the plate." Greer talked about the ease of putting money into and taking money out of MLGIP."Because MLGIP is an instrument where it's completely liquid, we could put the funds in tomorrow and then we could take them out Thursday," she said.Lewis warned commissioners and the town about the possible consequences of taking the money out of Bay-Vanguard Bank. She said she understands the benefit of gaining interest, but said it could result in BayVanguard Bank closing its Oxford branch."We are about half of the investors in this branch," Lewis said, adding that it is very possible the bank will "seriously consider" closing the Oxford branch."Because it has been a conversation over the years," she said.Lewis said she thinks residents need to determine whether the branch is of value to them before a decision to move the money is made. Both Lewis and Greer agreed that public participation was necessary to make this decision.During the meeting, residents brought up different reasons for why it does or doesn't make sense for the town to move the money.Some residents said that while the branch is local, they don't consider BayVanguard Bank a "community bank." Others brought up the fact that other banks in Easton are a short distance away.Multiple residents talked about how staying with BayVanguard Bank essentially leaves money on the table."I don't think there's anyone in this room who would not like to have a higher rate of return," Russ Gray said. "No one." Gray asked if the town has gone to Bay-Vanguard Bank to see if they could match rates. Commission President Tom Costigan said this is a possibility. He said the commissioners have spoken with the bank and continue to speak with the bank.Resident Art Murr talked about the risk of pulling the money from BayVanguard's Oxford branch."You pull $2 million out of a branch, that branch manager, that branch itself, it has to account for that," he said. "I understand how you can make more money. I really do get it.But let us not minimize the potential impact of what happens if you get rid of that." At the meeting Greer talked about possibly forming a finance and budget committee "for better cash management."

title: Budget, Blueprint, energy are top issues for Shore legislators this session
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Budget, Blueprint, energy are top issues for Shore legislators this session

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: General Assembly 
 
 710
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As Eastern Shore legislators prepare to cross the bridge and return to Annapolis for the first day of the Maryland General Assembly's 2025 legislative session on Wednesday, the state's budget is top of mind."It's just a tough time right now, and we're going to have to be very cautious and very thoughtful of the citizens and the impacts that our citizens are feeling," Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said in an interview with the Star Democrat.
The state is facing a predicted $2.7 billion budget deficit in fiscal year 2026. Jacobs said when it comes to the budget process this year, he thinks everything will be on the table. "The devil is in the details," he said.
"We're certainly — on the Shore — fiscal conservatives concerned with any cost increase, any tax increase or any cost toward citizens," Jacobs said.
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said he hopes state Democrats realize that some state goals, such as the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and some climate initiatives, are unrealistic and need to be reexamined.
"So I hope there's some reality checks," he said.
Del. Jefferson Ghrist (R- Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said the state has overspent. He said although House leadership seems to be ok with raising taxes to balance the budget, the governor might not be "comfortable" with that.
Ghrist said he expects to see a "clash" in the Democratic Party regarding the budget.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) sees this legislative session as a "defining" one for Gov. Wes Moore (D).
"He's going to have to balance this out within his own party," Mautz said about Moore. "Because the policies that are in place now that have caused these economic problems largely come from the Democratic Party and Democratic leadership."
BLUEPRINT FOR MARYLAND'S FUTUREThe Blueprint for Maryland's Future is another issue that legislators on the Shore expect to be one of the top issues this legislative session.
The Blueprint — a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and education quality across the state — has garnered some concern across the state due to funding challenges.
Hutchinson said that with a budget shortfall, the state should be "pulling back" on the Blueprint. He said the plan has "been devastating" to counties across the state.
Jacobs said he thinks this legislative session will result in adjustments to the timeline of certain Blueprint goals.
"I don't think that they're going to do away with Blueprint by any means," he said. "I just think that there may be some changes in the timeline of different parts of it."
Mautz said "something has to happen" with the Blueprint. He said he isn't sure if legislators will create bills "to address the damage that's been done" or create bills that put pauses on the plan.
ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTFrom solar energy to electric vehicles, Eastern Shore legislators see energy and environment issues as important heading into this legislative session.
Ghrist called the state's renewable energy goals "virtually impossible to achieve." He said he has concerns about who is controlling where solar energy systems are being placed in the state. He plans to put out "several" bills that address solar energy.
"Our number one industry is agriculture and it's being threatened right now by solar," he said.
Jacobs said he has heard that there have been some "serious conversations" about expanding nuclear energy in the state. He said he hopes state leadership and legislative committees that deal with energy issues will look more into nuclear energy and figure out if it's a direction the state should be going in.
When it comes to electric vehicles, Hutchinson said he doesn't think the state has the capacity for its electric vehicle initiatives.
"There's not enough power stations to be able to charge them," he said. "And based upon what I'm hearing from our local dealers, there's not a market for them and they want to stay with combustible engines."
Hutchinson said he expects a lot of debate this session.
"And again, I hope that we see some reality coming that we can't continue to afford to spend and that we have to make sure we address this $2.7 billion short fall that's going to get worse and worse each year if we don't do anything today," he said.

title: Easton Town Council vote on cannabis moratorium delayed - Tabled measure leads to heated discussion among council members
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Easton Town Council vote on cannabis moratorium delayed - Tabled measure leads to heated discussion among council members

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 710
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - A move by Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus to continue a hearing on a proposed cannabis moratorium drew strong reactions from other council members.A tense back-and-forth exchange between Gunsallus and Ward 3 Councilman David Montgomery toward the end of Monday's council meeting stemmed from the council president's executive decision to delay a vote on the moratorium for an additional three weeks.The nine-month moratorium on cannabis businesses, introduced this summer, was originally slated for a public hearing and vote at the council's Sept.18 meeting. The matter had been tabled until Monday so all five council members could be present to vote.The moratorium, if passed, would place a pause on applications, approval, construction, expansion, processing or issuance of building permits for a business that grows, processes or sells cannabis within the Easton town limits.The moratorium would also allow the town to consider and adopt a revised zoning ordinance.Easton's existing zoning ordinance already contains definitions and permitted zoning districts for medical cannabis dispensaries and growing and processing facilities, but does not include language on standards for recreational facilities.Montgomery strongly objected to Gunsallus' continuance, saying the council president did not have the authority to do so. Gunsallus affirmed that he did."Sir, you will contain yourself please," Gunsallus said, speaking over Montgomery, who started to make a comment.Gunsallus reaffirmed he had the power to continue discussion on the moratorium until the next meeting, explaining that he wanted to wait until the town's planning commission made an additional recommendation later in the week.However, in August, the commission unanimously gave a favorable recommendation to approve the ordinance.Montgomery called for a vote on the continuance, questioning Gunsallus' authority."The fact that four of us could reveal that we want to vote now means nothing to you, that you will override the wishes of the council because you are sitting there as the town council president," he said.Town Attorney Sharon Van Emburgh chimed in, saying the council can override the president's action. But in the past, the council has typically given members additional time to vote as a courtesy.Montgomery pointed out that the council had already given an additional month for consideration.Gunsallus reemphasized the upcoming planning commission meeting would provide more clarifying information."Excuse me, what information will that be?" Montgomery said."(The planning commission's) recommendations, as I've stated, so please contain yourself - you've already spoken more than permissible," Gunsallus said.Montgomery motioned to overrule Gunsallus and vote on the ordinance as presented.Ward 2 Councilman Don Abbatiello interjected, saying while he understood Montgomery and "definitely" disagreed with how the decision had been handled, he agreed that granting additional time to decide was in line with past council actions.Mayor Megan Cook, a former council president herself, interrupted the quarreling, calling for the councilmen to settle down."I agree that we are a group of five where you all are independent and you all have various opinions - absolutely.We must respect ourselves - the fighting, we need to" she said, trailing off and moving her arms to motion to calm down."Please." Ward 4 Councilman Rev.Elmer Davis Jr. initially seconded the motion, rescinding his vote just minutes later to agree with Abbatiello's stance on the council's precedent. He voiced worry with how the situation was handled."We have never had such a dialogue that we had tonight regarding issues and concerns," he said. "That dialogue - I'm quite concerned about things that have been said, I've never seen this on this council in all my days." The council will again table voting on the ordinance until its Monday, Nov. 6, meeting.Uncertainty still remains on the moratorium. During Monday's meeting, council members and town residents raised questions on the moratorium's duration, specifics on licensing for both recreational and medical facilities and zoning laws for both types of establishments.The Easton Planning Commission will discuss zoning requirements for adult-use cannabis dispensaries at its Thursday, Oct. 19, meeting.

author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Molly's Place brings outdoors lovers together for fun fall event

 October 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 593
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENNEDYVILLE — Molly's 14th annual fall tent sale returned bigger and better, rebranded as the Maryland Outdoor Festival this year.All through the weekend, Sept. 20-22, Molly's Place set up a massive tent courtesy of Eastern Shore Tent and Events, packed with savings from favorite hunting, fishing and outdoor brands, offering up to 70 percent off purchases.
In addition, there were giveaways like four Yeti coolers worth $250 a piece, autographed by Orioles players and a Sunday Sweeps with a Traeger Grill package.
For three days, residents enjoyed the comfortable weather, browsing the sales, seeking familiar brands like Benelli USA, Hevi-Shot, YETI and many more.
But Molly's tent sale is not just for the hunters and anglers. Rebranded now, the staff aims to create an event enjoyed by the entire community.
One of the organizers Prakash "Chikki" Shajwani emphasized this point, "We wanted to give back to the community. This is a way of getting kids outdoors and for families to get together."
Marketing Director Sara Dion echoed his statements, mentioning the new vendors this year to do that: the decoy table, duck and goose call makers, and some fun activities for kids along with food trucks.
Under the tent with the callers and decoy makers, there was a wealth of information from experts of their craft, people willing to discuss their workmanship, honed from years of experience.
Like Sean Mann the World Goose Calling Champion of Champions. He won championships for duck calling and for making his own calls.
Working beside his son, Ian, who shows his talent for making calls, Mann said he owed his career path to the late Dan Edwards, an instructor at Anne Arundel College and a good friend.
"He made the dream possible. Without him none of this would have happened," Mann said.
These awe-inspiring stories weren't limited to just the vendors.
Looking at crossbows, Delaware resident Rene Swing casually mentioned how she once got a bear using a Horton Legacy crossbow, in a deer stand, in Maine.
These outdoor stories were all over the place, uniting residents and visitors.
Outside the tent, children enjoyed climbing the bouncy castle, The Triple Shots 4-H crew taught kids archery and beside them was a BB gun range run by the National Wild Turkey Federation along with the Queen Anne's County High School Clay Target Team, ensuring proper safety.
With cold beverages and good food there was also a nice mix of local talented musicians entertaining while spectators sat on hay bales.
The Quinn Arnold Band played on Friday, Joe Bryan sang and strummed classics on Saturday, and newcomer Elena Barnett with musician Justin Singleton, closed out Sunday with country, blues and rock covers.
For three days Molly's was bustling with activity.
Dion said last year they drew approximately 15,000. They anticipated recording as many this year, if not more.
Shajwani showed appreciation to all the volunteers such as the Chestertown Lions Club for helping park cars, the Kennedyville Volunteer Fire Company selling beer, and the Maryland State Police for helping on that busy stretch of road navigating people who came as far as Virginia and Baltimore for the event.
And he thanked the community recalling when the place was called Vonnie's noting how it was a hub for Marylanders to meet.
With their tagline, "Fuel your adventure," Shajwani said Molly's shows that same appreciation to the location's history and the culture while making their own mark.
Dion said, "We want to express our gratitude to the wonderful members of our community who attended the event and continue to support Molly's. Kent County holds a special place in our hearts, and we are honored to be part of this remarkable community."
