author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Eastern Shore Arts Festival showcases art for all ages

 April 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 435
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — The arts are for everyone, as emphasized by the second annual Eastern Shore Art Festival on April 13.Aiming to inspire a new generation of artists and showcase the wonderment of creativity, the Chesapeake College Todd Performing Arts Center came alive with a full day of local artistry and creativity during the Eastern Shore Arts Festival.
This year's festival had a significant focus on art opportunities for students in kindergarten through 12th grade, according to Michael Bell, Queen Anne's County Public Schools supervisor of instruction for visual and performing arts.
Director of Arts at Chesapeake College, Robert Thompson, with Bell, presented Chesapeake Choice Awards, along with additional top three awards.
"It was amazing to be able to give seniors their kudos and be able to show student work. For many of them it was really their first opportunity to present and it provided a unique opportunity to a bigger audience," Bell said.
Inside the theater, a dance studio showcase graced the stage with original performances featuring studios including the Community College of Baltimore County Dance Company, Mid Shore Dance Academy, Step 1 Dance 2 Academy and To The Pointe Dance Studio.
Also captivating audiences was a performance by the Gunston Choir.
The Chesapeake Film Festival presented short student films and provided opportunities for aspiring film buffs to learn about what happens behind the scenes.
Welcoming masters and students alike, aspiring artists were encouraged to explore new techniques and create something new with workshops on storytelling, improv, arts and crafts, dance, theatre, music and film.
"It is a great way to bring in new experiences," Bell said.
Adrienne Kraus Latanishen, teaching artist with the Carole Cascio Fund, led a contemporary dance class teaching dancers of all levels to "take up space" and not to be afraid. Latanishen seeks to continually create more opportunities for dancing on the Eastern Shore.
"Dancing really mixes the best of both worlds, the art and the physical," she said.
The mission of the Carole Cascio Fund is to connect students of all ages, with a love of dancing intertwined with mind and movement, Executive Director Peter Pucci said.
The Carole Cascio Fund was excited for the opportunity to partner with the college, Pucci said.
The dance showcase sponsored by the Carole Cascio Fund provided an opportunity for different dance companies to meet and experience new dances, he said.
With a diverse offering of art, the Eastern Shore Arts Festival continues to be a strong community effort between local organizations, teachers, dance companies and programs and looks forward to returning again, organizers said.
"It has been a great collaboration," Thompson said.
More information about Chesapeake College Todd Performing Arts Center can be found at chesapeake.edu/TPAC.

title: 'Biden butchered this decision': Democrats split over U.S. lifting ban on Paraguayan beef imports
author: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers
content:
'Biden butchered this decision': Democrats split over U.S. lifting ban on Paraguayan beef imports

 March 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers | Section: National 
 
 1037
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The six Democratic senators representing the Delmarva Peninsula voted against a measure that would reverse the Biden administration's decision to allow beef imports into the U.S. from Paraguay.The U.S. Senate voted 70-25 Thursday to reverse the administration's move to lift longstanding prohibitions on Paraguayan beef imports in an effort led by U.S. Sen. Jon Tester, D-Montana.
The agricultural and trade battle has divided Democrats and comes as U.S. beef prices could hit all-time record highs this year with production inventories at their lowest levels since the 1950s.
The White House "strongly opposes" the reversal in an issue that has split Democrats saying it will undermine U.S. trade relations including with Paraguay which has taken pro-U.S. stances related to Russia and China.
Paraguayan beef imports that been prohibited into the U.S. for the past 25 years over concerns about foot-and-mouth disease outbreaks.
The U.S. Department of Agriculture reversed that ban in November.
Tester and other critics of the change — including U.S. farm groups — worry about impacts on U.S. food supplies.
The Senate vote saw Democrats split on the issue with 26 favoring reversing the Biden decision — Majority Leader Chuck Schumer of New York along with Tester and U.S. Sens. Sherrod Brown of Ohio and Jacky Rosen of Nevada. The latter trio all face tough reelection bids in November.
Twenty-two Democrats — including Maryland's Chris Van Hollen and Ben Cardin, Delaware's Chris Coons and Tom Carper and Virginia's Mark Warner and Tim Kaine — sided with Biden's meat move.
"President Biden butchered this decision," said Tester, in a statemetn. "By cutting corners to resume beef imports from a country with a recent history of foot and mouth disease, the Biden Administration is jeopardizing our food supply and giving Montana consumers and producers a raw deal. We cannot allow beef imports from Paraguay until we have data that shows they are meeting same high animal health standards as American ranchers, and I'm proud to have secured overwhelming bipartisan support in the Senate to force the Biden administration to reverse course."
'MUST BE HALTED'
The measure still needs to pass the U.S. House.
Most Senate Republicans — including South Dakota'a Mike Rounds, Montana's Steve Daines and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky — vote re-impose the Paraguayan beef ban.
Rounds was the prime GOP sponsor of the measure.
U.S. agriculture and cattle industry groups — including the Livestock Marketing Association, National Farmers Union and R-CALF USA, also want Congress to nix the Biden administration's decision.
"The last time U.S. government officials stepped foot in a Paraguayan meat processing facility was in 2014. That nearly ten-year gap since the last site visit does not inspire confidence in Paraguay's animal health and food safety protocols," said Justin Tupper, president of U.S. Cattlemen's Association (USCA).
The group warns a foot-and-mouth disease outbreak (FMD) could cause as much as $99 billion in economic damages in the U.S.
Agriculture groups in Tester's home state — including the Montana Farm Bureau Federation, Montana Farmers Union and Montana Stockgrowers Association — also backed the Senate measure.
"Until it can be absolutely proven that there is no risk of an infectious animal disease outbreak in the U.S. domestic animal population caused by these imports, they must be halted," said Cyndi Johnson, president of the Montana Farm Bureau.
WHITE HOUSE PUSHES BACK
The Biden administration issued a statement to Congress March 19 opposing the Tester and Rounds-led measure.
"The administration strongly opposes passage of S.J. Res. 62, which would disapprove of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) action to allow imports of fresh beef from Paraguay into the United States. USDA conducted a rigorous scientific evaluation including site visits, a full risk analysis, and ongoing review of the region's animal health status and concluded that the risk of fresh beef imports from Paraguay is low," the White House said.
"If enacted, S.J. Res. 62 would undermine the credibility of long-standing science-based decision-making processes respected by the U.S. and upheld in our trade agreements, and could in turn severely threaten fair access to new and existing export markets for U.S. farmers and ranchers," the White House statement to Congress continued.
The U.S. administration said the measure would indefinitely ban Paraguayan beef imports and "mark a significant setback in the United States-Paraguay bilateral relationship and U.S. credibility as a reliable economic partner across Latin America."
The White House said a pullback could have national security and geopolitical ramifications, pointing to Paraguay's condemnation of Russia's invasion of Ukraine and standing as the last South American country recognizing Taiwan.
China, in particular, has been making significant investments in Latin America and other developing regions. Russia restricted Paraguayan imports after the Ukraine rebuke.
The Biden administration was re-instituting a U.S. ban could send Paraguay into the economic arms of Moscow and/or Beijing.
"Access to the U.S. market is critical for Paraguay to recover exports lost to Russia and to withstand pressure from the PRC to withdraw diplomatic recognition of Taiwan," the White House contends.
Paraguayan beef imports would be a small slice of of the total U.S. market — 0.05% of the total market and 0.5% of imports, according to an October 2023 analysis by the USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. The USDA arm also defended its decision to ease the ban.
RECORD HIGH BEEF PRICES?
The dustup over Paraguay beef imports also comes as U.S. beef production has been dropping and prices are on the rise.
Beef and veal prices were up 7.4% in February compared to a year ago, according to the Consumer Price Index.
The American Farm Bureau Federation said beef prices could hit record highs with supplies at their lowest since 1951.
The Farm Bureau said there were 87.2 million heads of cattle in the U.S. in January. That's down the 8.9% from four years ago and the lowest inventories in 73 years.
"Farmers have been driven to sell off cattle because of severe drought conditions and the rising cost of supplies needed to support their herds. There are now fewer female cattle available for breeding, which means it will take time to restock the cattle population, AFBF said in a statement.
"The latest cattle numbers are a stark reminder of the challenges facing America's farmers and ranchers," said AFBF President Zippy Duvall. "Severe weather, high inflation and geopolitical uncertainty are taking a toll on farmers across the country, and families will see the effects in their grocery bills."

title: Hosler at 100 and counting
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Hosler at 100 and counting

 October 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 693
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — As Queen Anne's County High's boys soccer team prepared for its victory jog across the field Wednesday night, a handful of Lions coaxed head coach Wade Hosler to find a place in line and join the run.Hosler made it halfway across the field then started applauding.
"It's senior night," he said. "Let them have it."
It was also the night Hosler earned his 100th career victory, as Jamison Kendall's first-half goal proved enough in a 1-0 victory over a no-quit North Dorchester bunch, keeping the Lions atop the North Bayside.
"I guess it means I'm getting old," said a smiling Hosler of his milestone. "I didn't really sit down and think about it too much. It's been a lot of tremendous players, a lot of great assistant coaches, administration. A lot of people have helped me along the way.
"It's been an amazing journey," continued Hosler, now in his 13th season at the helm. "We have great kids. They come out and they work hard every year. We graduate good kids, and good kids fill their shoes. So it's a good place to be. If it wasn't I wouldn't have lasted this long."
With their fourth win in five games, the Lions (5-3 overall, 5-0 North Bayside) remained in first place in the division via their fourth one-goal win of the season.
"It's always a little stressful," Hosler said of senior night. "We didn't finish the ball, which makes it difficult. We finish a couple more early (chances) and it would be a different game. But we don't put the ball in the back of the net and it becomes a struggle."
Queen Anne's got four corner-kick chances in the opening 15 minutes but couldn't convert. And though the Lions controlled possession for much of the first half, the Eagles (4-4-1, 1-4-1) found openings and opportunities, the biggest coming with 26 minutes, 18 seconds remaining, when Christian Chase drilled a strike off the crossbar.
The Lions cranked up the intensity on the offensive end, with James Rath sending a pair of shots on goal that North Dorchester keeper Jayden Coleman stopped. But with just under 18 minutes left before half, the Lions worked the ball down the right side and over to Kendall, who steered a left-footed shot past Coleman for a 1-0 lead.
"We had good pressure," Eagles head coach Gabe Guzman said. "It's one of those nights where things don't fall your way and you have to live with the results. Unfortunately, we had one mistake in the back end."
Queen Anne's continued building chances toward padding its lead in the second half. Coleman stopped Trey Moore's header with 27:27 to go. Kendall was denied with 13:30 remaining and Rath unloaded a drive wide left 2 minutes later.
North Dorchester pushed into the Lions end in the final 5 minutes in a bid for the equalizer. Senior captain Chris Sanchez, who booted a number of long clears and balls into the Queen Anne's end throughout the game, drove a direct kick wide left with a little over 5 minutes left. The Eagles got a corner with 3 minutes to go, but couldn't muster a shot.
About a minute later, the Eagles sent a through ball into the box. But Lions sophomore keeper Braeden Livingston sprinted off his line and scooped the ball before anyone else could get a touch.
"It makes it stressful," Hosler said of his team's one-goal wins. "But hey, we're playing well. We're still undefeated in the North. And I'm proud of the way we grind. It's not pretty. We're not finishing as many opportunities as we would like, but we keep grinding. We keep fighting. And we find a way to win."
Guzman also liked his team's fight, and with a little work, hopes to be a force in the Class 1A East playoffs.
"We're still working things out," said Guzman, whose team is 4-1-1 against 1A competition this season. "Finishing is still a little bit of an issue. It's a work in progress. Hopefully come playoff time we won't have that issue.
"Kudos to them," Guzman added of Hosler and Queen Anne's. "Hundredth win. That's a wonderful feat. Hopefully one day I'll be there. But they did their job."

title: Some Maryland households face disconnect from federal discount internet program
author: HAILEY CLOSSON Capital News Service
content:
Some Maryland households face disconnect from federal discount internet program

 May 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HAILEY CLOSSON Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 556
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Over 287,000 Maryland households risk losing access to high-speed internet at the end of this month unless a bipartisan agreement can be struck in Congress to extend a discount program.Around one in eight Maryland households benefits from the Affordable Connectivity Program (ACP), which provides a monthly discount on high-speed, broadband internet costs to qualifying homes. Marylanders have saved $8.3 million on monthly internet bills statewide, according to the White House.
The Biden administration is pushing Congress to support an extension of the broadband program.
President Joe Biden last October requested an additional $6 billion in funding for the program.
Last month, he made public appeals for support in tweets.
"During the pandemic, we saw just how essential high-speed internet really was — from telemedicine, online school, and small business e-commerce to the ability of millions to work remotely and connect with one another when it wasn't safe to gather," Biden said.
"It's past time Republicans in Congress joined their Democratic colleagues and worked to pass funding for this essential program."
A bipartisan effort by 17 senators to amend the Federal Aviation Administration reauthorization bill to include $6 billion for the internet program failed Thursday. Senate leaders resisted efforts to include the program and other non-aviation-related amendments in the FAA measure.
"Congress must take action to save the ACP to lower costs for American families, boost the economy, and promote job creation and economic mobility," Sen. Ben Ray Lujan, D-New Mexico, said in a statement. He was the sponsor of the amendment.
In the House, 122 Democrats and Republicans on Thursday wrote a letter to congressional leaders urging action to preserve the discount internet program.
"While certain bipartisan reforms to the program are necessary to improve efficiency and effectiveness, it is the most vulnerable families across the nation that will bear the burden of our inaction if funding lapses," the lawmakers warned.
The program offers internet discounts of up to $30 a month for qualifying households and up to $75 a month for homes on tribal lands, according to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). Also available is a one-time discount of up to $100 to purchase a laptop, desktop computer, or tablet from participating internet service providers under conditions.
A Baltimore-based Twitter/X user under the pseudonym"Fearturnip" tweeted in January about the program's pending expiration, saying, "Not only is the national Affordable Connectivity Program tanking in April, the Maryland Broadband Benefit is also ending."
"I guess we're back to 'normal,' where the digital divide ravages America."
Over 23 million households nationwide have benefitted from the program, according to the software company WhistleOut, with most of the program's beneficiaries being low-income, veterans, minorities, and seniors.
More than 77% of discount internet program users said losing their benefits would force them to change their internet plan or drop internet service entirely, according to an FCC survey last year.
Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Maryland, met with St. Mary's County leaders and county stakeholders last month to discuss his plans for keeping the internet accessible to low-income households and securing funding for the internet program.
Hoyer said he is committed to "narrowing the digital divide" and enabling everyone in Maryland's 5th District with internet access, according to the Lexington Park (Maryland) Leader.
"The Affordable Connectivity Program has transformed St. Mary's County and communities across the country," Hoyer said. "Education, health care, and our economy rely on America's workers, students, seniors, and families being connected to the internet."

title: Federalsburg officials address town's mounting issues at public forum
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Federalsburg officials address town's mounting issues at public forum

 July 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — The Federalsburg Town Council hosted hundreds of residents for a public forum at Federalsburg Elementary School Monday evening.Town officials wanted to set the record straight about town rumors, addressing issues like misappropriation of town funds, employee resignations, $5 million of debt, wastewater treatment issues and police department cost.
A 50-minute explanation by the council members explained the root of these issues and the options and plans to solve them.
Debt and staff accountability
Council members revealed the town's $5 million of debt dates back to 1995.
"We did not get into a over $5 million debt overnight, but here we are and we're trying to clean it up piece by piece," council member Brandy James said. "When I came on council, the math just didn't add up. So, looking into things, some of this debt goes back to 1995.
"The town has had a very historic past of one not paying bills on time, two robbing Peter to pay Paul, and three in order to get anything done instead of doing the right thing and figuring out how to better utilize the funds that were coming in, they would just take out loans or they would take out grants. Some grants were grants that the town wasn't even qualified for, but that's what they would do."
James said the town must pay back grants to grant providers because the grant providers have discovered that the town wasn't eligible to receive the grants. She said the town has lost grants because of not having audits done since fiscal year 2023.
Federalsburg officials plan to establish a plan to pay off debt within 12 months using money from the town's general fund. The town has frozen spending and committed to a hiring freeze, except for a part-time code enforcement officer.
After the hiring freeze, James said that the town will shift its employment focus to hiring staff who are qualified for their positions, no longer hiring employees based off relationships.
Wastewater and water issues
Council member Darlene Hammond led the discussion on the fire department water usage. She said the town will not charge the fire department for water used to fight fires, but the fire house will be metered for non-emergency uses, which it previously has not been.
The town will install meters on hydrants to help track and detect leaks and start billing churches and other town serving companies for water and sewer usage.
Town officials acknowledged past issues with inconsistent billing and old meters. They plan to take steps to clear billing statements and update account balances. They will explore tools for online payments and text alerts when bills are due.
The town's wastewater treatment plant was also discussed at the meeting. The facility was built to support a housing development in the town that was never constructed, making it outsized to the town's needs.
Mayor Kim Abner said the facility is built to handle 750,000 gallons a day, more than double the current usage of 350,000 gallons per day.
The town has many issues with taking care of the facility due to cost and improper usage.
"It costs a lot of money to fix the water main. It costs a lot of money to maintain the wastewater treatment plant," Abner said. "There are state mandates that we have to deal with. We also need a new sludge press because the sludge press presses the water out, and if you don't press all the water out, you're paying more at the landfill. So, the wastewater treatment plant's a lot. It's a big investment. It's a lot of money, but we have to do it for safe drinking water and safe toilets."
Police Department
Council member Ian Ferguson talked about the cost of the town's police department.
If the town were to sign a memorandum of understanding with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to provide policing services, it would save the town between $300,000 and $500,000, he said.
The town currently pays $1.146 million for the Federalsburg Police Department.
Sheriff Donald Baker told residents that the his would hire Federalsburg's police officers if it were to assume policing duties for the town.
According to the Town Council, the current police station could be used as a substation for the Sheriff's Office if the town signs a memorandum of understanding.
The town plans to continue to have quarterly public meetings to keep the town informed on all issues and improvements.

title: Body-worn camera footage from fatal officer-involved car crash released
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Body-worn camera footage from fatal officer-involved car crash released

 September 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 677
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — On Wednesday, the Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Office of the Attorney General released the body-worn camera footage from the fatal officer-involved vehicle pursuit that occurred on July 22 in Easton.The preliminary investigation revealed deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, in marked police cruisers, encountered a car in the area of westbound Route 50 and Dutchmans Lane, where they attempted to initiate a traffic stop. The car did not stop, and a pursuit ensued.
Body-worn camera footage was released from four officers: Talbot County Deputies Brittanie DiMichele, William Barnett and Owen Joseph, and Easton Police Department Officer Nicholas Lange.
DiMichele led the pursuit as Joseph drove a second county police vehicle with Barnett in the passenger's seat. The driver of the car being pursued did not stop and continued to drive on Route 50. Officers pursued the vehicle for several minutes, sometimes reaching speeds over 100 MPH.
"We looked at our policy and we looked at the body-worn camera footage," Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said in an interview. "We listened to the dispatch record of our deputies as well as the communication behind the deputies, and our deputies followed proper procedure and policies."
In the video, officers can be seen taking a left turn onto Black Dog Alley just before stopping and exiting to approach the crashed vehicle at the 8300 block at 7:14 p.m.
"Let me see your hands. Let me see your hands," DiMichele shouted. The armed deputies asked for the people in the car to put their hands out the window.
DiMichele approached the rear passenger door on the left side, slightly opening it as repeated asks for "help" can be heard from inside the car. The rear passenger pressed his hands on the window, as Barnett repeatedly asked the driver, a juvenile male, to stick his hands out the window.
"If you keep reaching, you're going to get shot if you pull something out, you understand me?" Barnett said.
Gamble said it is "totally appropriate" for the officers to draw their weapons while approaching the vehicle.
"For their safety, they drew their weapons, ordered the people out," Gamble said. "Once they realized the injuries and there was entrapment, then they holstered their weapons and tried to assist."
Barnett asked the driver if he had any weapons, then began to attempt to help the driver exit the car at 7:16 p.m.
"We're here to help you now, okay, I need you to climb out this window," Barnett said.
The two rear passengers, a juvenile male and an adult woman, exited the car with assistance from the officers.
Officers were unable to extract the adult woman from the front passenger seat. "She's just agonal," an officer said of her breathing. One officer noted she "definitely wasn't wearing a seatbelt." EMS arrived on the scene at 7:22 p.m., the video shows.
The driver and the front seat passenger were transported to a local hospital for treatment of serious injuries. The front seat passenger was later pronounced dead at the hospital, the attorney general's office said.
The decedent was previously identified as 18-year-old Yemaya Wilson.
The two rear passengers were transported to an area hospital for treatment of serious injuries.
In an August interview, Gamble said after the crash, police learned the vehicle had been stolen from Montgomery County.
"We suspect the criminal charges will be brought at some point in the case, against, at the very least, the driver of the stolen vehicle, if not more," Gamble said on Wednesday. "But that's going to be in the hands of the (Maryland) State Police and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office."
The Independent Investigations Division will generally release body-worn camera and dashboard camera footage within 20 business days of an incident. The release of body-worn camera footage in this incident was delayed to allow additional time to conduct witness interviews, the Attorney General's Office said in a press release.
The Independent Investigations Division continues to investigate the circumstances of the fatal pursuit.

title: Pelosi, Biden: A fractured political friendship
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Pelosi, Biden: A fractured political friendship

 August 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 687
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Since President Biden withdrew from seeking re-election in late July, there has been speculation about the individual or individuals most responsible for that happening.On a nationally televised address, Biden said, in part, "So, I've decided the best way forward, is to pass the torch to a new generation."
That announcement followed a series of Biden's emphatic denials that he would step down from running for a second term despite almost universal agreement that his debate performance against Donald Trump was a disaster.
On June 28, Biden acknowledged his poor debate performance but vowed to "fight on."On July 5, Biden said, "If the Lord Almighty came down and said, 'Joe, get out of the race,' I'd get out of the race. The Lord Almighty's not comin' down."On July 8, Biden said, "I'm not going anywhere."On July 11, Biden said, "It's essentially a toss-up race."On July 21, Biden announces he is leaving the presidential race.
Since then, there has been widespread speculation on the role of Nancy Pelosi on this outcome. Despite no longer serving as speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi is proof that power and influence in politics is not always based on a position.
Some believe strongly that Pelosi played a key role, if not the key role in convincing Biden to abandon his re-election campaign.
When asked if she helped apply pressure on Biden, Pelosi initially responded with, "I didn't call one person." She later acknowledged she did make a call to one person and that was President Biden. On that call she opined that based on polling his re-election prospects were dismal and that would have significant negative impacts on Democratic candidates in competitive down ballot races.
She has also admitted she took calls from key Democratic Party power brokers and opinion leaders where she expressed the same concerns she raised on her call with Biden.
When Nancy Pelosi talks about politics, most people listen. When she doesn't talk, most people notice her silence especially on matters like the viability of a Biden bid for a second term.
Now that Biden has stepped down from running, she has been somewhat more forthright.
At a recent roundtable with reporters, she still insisted she did not lead a behind-the-scenes effort to pressure President Biden to drop his re-election bid. The operative word here is "lead." While she may not have led those behind-the-scenes efforts there is increasing evidence she was very involved in them.
Like so many past and present events in politics, we may never get the full story.
We do know that this chain of events reinforces the brutal reality of politics. Whenever a candidate becomes unelectable, they become expendable.
Ultimately, who Pelosi called or did not call, did or did take calls from, exactly what was said or not said on any of those calls, a mission she was involved to some degree to replace Joe Biden as the Democratic presidential nominee became mission accomplished.
Achieving that mission formerly viewed by many as "mission impossible" has been a game changer in the 2024 presidential election and beyond. It has energized, galvanized, and mobilized a previously despondent Democratic Party. It increases the odds for Democrats to control at least one or both houses of Congress starting next year.
It has also forced the Trump campaign to explore adjustments to a campaign strategy that did not ask the question — what if Biden is not the opponent?
This change is not without some residual turbulence in the Democratic Party.
Politico recently reported Biden is angry with Nancy Pelosi. Their report includes the following quote from an anonymous senior White House official: "Biden views Pelosi as 'ruthless' and willing to set aside long-term relationships in order to keep her party in power."
As a result, Pelosi has said she and Biden have not spoken since July 19.
Based on the late scheduling and even later delivery of Biden's speech at the DNC convention it is clear the Democratic Party has no time for him going forward.
I suggest Joe Biden needs to heed advice attributed to former Democratic President Harry Truman: "If you want a friend in Washington, get a dog."
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton.

title: Singing Captains to lead Buffett celebration at The Mainstay
author: BOB FORD Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Singing Captains to lead Buffett celebration at The Mainstay

 August 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BOB FORD Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 552
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Jimmy Buffett was a musical legend with a phenomenal career and a unique following, but on the Chesapeake Bay, he was just another boater looking for good fishing, good food and good times.Well, maybe not just another boater. When Last Mango, his 42-foot custom sportfisher, made its way north to Sag Harbor in the spring, or south in the fall to the tropical climes that inspired many of his songs, Buffett delighted in exploring the bay from the ocean to the C&D Canal. He even filmed a music video at Thomas Point Light on one of the trips.
Boaters, beach bums and backyard pool drifters all lost a friend when Buffett died at 76 on Sept. 1, 2023, due to complications from a rare form of skin cancer.
To honor the Labor Day weekend anniversary of his passing, and to celebrate his musical legacy, the Singing Captains are performing a Buffett-only concert of his hits on Sunday, Aug. 31, from 4 to 6 p.m. at the outdoor amphitheater of Rock Hall's iconic music venue, The Mainstay.
It will be a "family-friendly celebration of music, memories and Margaritaville vibes, with special musical guests and good company," according to Mark Einstein, a member of the Singing Captains and a day-job charter boat captain in his own right.
The event is ticketless and free to the public, with a suggested donation of $10 to help The Mainstay continue its mission of providing a wide variety of musical offerings for the community. The Mainstay cash bar will be operating, with margaritas and more. Ice cream will be available for purchase from Get the Scoop, and That Place on Main will have Cheeseburgers in Paradise on the menu at the show.
Opening for the Singing Captains, and joining them on a number of Buffett songs that follow, will be steel pan virtuoso Trevor Stubbs. He is a native of Trinidad, where the instrument was first fashioned out of industrial steel drums. Stubbs, who is one half of the duo Island Vibes, has played at The Mainstay previously. Beginning with the song "One Particular Harbor," a 1983 release from the album of the same name, Buffett often used steel pannists on his Caribbean-flavored songs.
"What connects Rock Hall to the Jimmy Buffett thing is that this is a premier sailing and boating town. We've all got Hawaiian shirts, and we like to emulate that laid-back lifestyle that his music captured," Einstein said. "His music, when it burst on the scene, influenced the whole boating world. You would hear it walking down literally any dock."
Buffett, originally from Pascagoula, Mississippi, made his way to New Orleans and Nashville before discovering that Key West was just the right latitude for his attitude, and the tropical-tinged hits followed quickly. Over the course of his career, Buffett sold more than 20 million records, and 17 of his albums were either gold or platinum in sales. He was posthumously inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2024.
Those attending the Buffett celebration at The Mainstay will find plenty of seating at the open-air amphitheater, but if so inclined, there is room on the lawn for beach chairs, too. Visitors can bring those, wiggle their toes in the grass and pretend it is sand.
"Wear your loudest shirt and come help us toast Jimmy," Einstein said.

title: Jury finds Tilghman man guilty of child sexual abuse
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Jury finds Tilghman man guilty of child sexual abuse

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 732
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - After roughly five hours of deliberation Thursday, a Talbot County jury found a Tilghman man guilty on all but one count relating to the sexual abuse of a child earlier this year.The jury found Eric L. Werner guilty of 16 counts, including sexual abuse of a minor, third-and fourth-degree sex offenses, second-degree assault and displaying obscene matter to a minor.However, the jury did not convict Werner on one count of sexual abuse of a minor.The verdict comes after a four-day jury trial in Talbot County Circuit Court.The child's mother, whom the Star Democrat is not naming to protect the victim's privacy, expressed gratitude for the guilty verdict."Justice has been served today," she said in an email. "We can't thank the Talbot County Sheriff's (Office), and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office enough for their dedication to this case and the support that they've given my daughter and our family these past 8 months." She continued: "I'd also like to express how important it is that parents, and guardians educate themselves and their children on the statistics and signs of sexual abuse and grooming. Empower your kids to speak up if someone is hurting them, being inappropriate with them, or making them feel uncomfortable. If your child discloses abuse to you, believe them, support them, and report the abuse to authorities or a mandatory reporter." "What happened to my daughter was horrible, but it could have been a lot worse if she had not spoken up when she did.She will carry this trauma with her for the rest of her life, but we all hope that because she spoke up, it will help encourage another child to do the same and stop their abuse." Defense attorney Philip Cronan said he was disappointed in the verdict, but would see what comes next with sentencing, which is yet to be scheduled.Detectives from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office began investigating Werner, 61, in February after learning of multiple child sexual abuse incidents that occurred at a home in Tilghman that month.Police investigation revealed that Werner sexually assaulted a preteen girl through inappropriately touching her on three different occasions in February.Werner showed the child pornographic videos, which the child remembered in detail during the trial. Police testified to a specific adult website appearing in Werner's phone's search history.In closing arguments Thursday, Talbot County Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel highlighted the testimony and evidence presented during the trial as concrete proof that Werner established an inappropriate relationship with the child, grooming her, she said.Numerous text messages between the two, plus the child testifying to Werner initiating sexual conversations with her, further illustrated the inappropriate relationship, Endzel said.Later, Werner, asking the child to delete messages, indicated that he continued to coax the child into becoming comfortable with sexual contact, she added.Endzel also pointed to recordings of calls Werner made to his wife while in the county jail as additional corroboration for his guilt. During one call, Werner said the truth would get him "into some trouble." And during another, he attempted to discredit her, telling his wife they needed to give a reason why she would lie, Endzel said.Countering the prosecution, Cronan acknowledged that the allegations against Werner would bother any juror, but questioned what the prosecution presented as facts.A point of contention between both attorneys Thursday morning was whether or not Werner had permanent or temporary care or custody or responsibility for the supervision of the child - criteria that needed to be met to move forward with the sexual abuse of a minor charges.Though Talbot Circuit Judge Stephen H. Kehoe ruled that the prosecution had provided evidence demonstrating that Werner had temporary responsibility for the child during the incidents, Cronan still questioned if there was a change in responsibility between adults during his closing arguments.Cronan also questioned the consistency of the child's statements made to police compared to what she testified to on the witness stand, urging the jurors to find Werner not guilty if they only thought he "probably" or "maybe" touched the child inappropriately.In her final remarks to the jurors, Endzel said the child had no incentive to lie. She turned attention back to Werner, again highlighting his request for the child to delete text messages and pointing to the jail calls attempting to discredit her story."If that's not consciousness of guilt, I don't know what is," she said.

title: Talbot County passes 1-cent resolution for 2024 ballot
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County passes 1-cent resolution for 2024 ballot

 June 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 424
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Voters in Talbot County will see a familiar question on November's ballot.The Talbot County Council passed a resolution Tuesday to place a question on the 2024 ballot to amend the county's charter to raise residents' taxes for public safety.
The amendment would allow, but not require, the council to add up to 1 cent per $100 of assessed value above the revenue cap for an additional seven years beginning July 1, 2026.
After the council passed a similar 1-cent resolution in 2020, a majority of Talbot County voters in the 2020 general election approved the charter amendment.
Martha Sparks, the county's finance director, said the 1-cent resolution has allowed the county to add 26 public safety positions, including paramedics, EMTs, school resource officers and 911 operators. County Manager Clay Stamp vouched for the 1-cent resolution funding.
"In the last number of years, this additional funding has allowed us to see the best of our services," said Stamp, who is also the county's former emergency services director. "We've stabilized our workforce. We've been able to attract quality individuals as paramedics, correctional officers, deputy sheriffs. We've enhanced our technology, we've enhanced our coverage."
The original resolution from 2020 amended the charter for five years up until July 1, 2026. Resolution 359, which was passed Tuesday, adds an additional seven years.
Originally, Resolution 359 was introduced as extending five years. Council Vice President Pete Lesher proposed an amendment Tuesday to tack on the two additional years.
His reasoning for the amendment was to ensure any future extensions can be voted on by the public during presidential elections, when the ballot is more "uncrowded" than other elections. County council and gubernatorial elections are set to be in 2026 and 2030, meaning that if extended to only 2031, the 1-cent question may have appeared on a crowded 2030 ballot.
"By adding another two years, rather than having this expire in a council election year (or) a gubernatorial election year, this will extend it to the next presidential election year so that should this need to be renewed another time, it can be done when there isn't such a crowded ballot," Lesher said.
Council members unanimously approved the amendment 4-0 before passing the resolution by the same vote, with Council Member Dave Stepp absent.
Sparks said she's seen where the additional tax revenue has been spent, which is in "the areas that the public has supported," noting the new positions and increased funding to volunteer fire departments.
"It's very important for the public to know that they're doing good things to help us," Council President Chuck Callahan said.

content:
Black watermen’s monument proposed for Wells Cove

 September 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News

 CENTREVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Commissioners approved Wells Cove as the site for a proposed Black watermen's monument Aug. 26, further representing the history and legacy of the county's iconic industry.Tilghman Hemsley, a Queenstown artist and director of American Patriotic Monuments Inc., who created the original Kent Narrows watermen's monument 20 years ago, said he had been approached about the lack of Black representation in that project.
Seeking commissioner approval to establish the new monument on county property at Wells Cove, Hemsley presented mock-ups of the detailed sculptures.
Symbolizing the rich heritage of Black watermen, the monument will depict life-size bronze sculptures featuring a conversation between a head boat captain and an oyster boat worker, according to Hemsley. The piece will also feature other important aspects of the industry, including a man working with clams, a woman picking crabs, another cleaning fish, as well as a young boy with a fishing pole along for the experience.
"It's a sculpture that leans into the whole industry," Hemsley said.
"The piece is designed for the public to be able to come through and be part of the sculpture," he said.
With the history of the Black watermen engraved into the side of the pieces, "it's all about education," he said.
The monument is slated for a location between Bridges Restaurant and the Jetty restaurant. Hemsley emphasized the interactive nature of the work, allowing visitors the opportunity to pass between the pieces and engage with the sculptures as they visit the local area.
The watermen will be life-size bronze sculptures while the boat pieces will be stainless steel and powder-coated, he said.
Hemsley said the design of the pieces should make the monument low maintenance.
The project has already received approval from the Queen Anne's County Parks and Recreation Department and a letter of recommendation from the Kent Narrows Foundation, he said.
The commissioners unanimously approved Wells Cove as the site for the proposed monument. Commissioner Jim Moran noted he would have preferred a competition among artists to design a tribute to Black watermen but supported the plan.
Hemsley noted time is of the essence if the statue is to be ready by July 4, 2026, in celebration of the country's 250th anniversary.
Serving as director of the project, Hemsley said various other artists will be involved in the sculpture work. The proposed monument has an advisory committee that includes watermen, he said.
With commissioner approval, the next steps include seeking funding grants, according to Hemsley.
Although highly appreciated, just like the original watermen's monument, the project would not be solely dependent on county support, he said.
The total cost for the project is estimated at about $475,000. The previous watermen's monument cost about $300,000, he said.
Statues typically take about three years to complete, but Hemsley was confident as long as funding came through.
"It's aggressive, but we can do it," he said.
A fundraising event with auctions, games and music will be held at the Kent Island American Legion Nov. 8 starting at 7 p.m., he said.
Hemsley is also working with the Centreville Veterans Information Committee to create a life-size statue honoring the more than 400 Black soldiers of Queen Anne's County who fought for the Union during the Civil War.
Working with Chesapeake Charities, the veteran statue committee has been hard at work establishing itself as a nonprofit, according to John Wright, statue committee chair.
Wright credited the enthusiasm of the committee in working to establish a historic monument.
"I'm glad I am in a position to help," he said.
With the sculpture to be completed in stages, the committee foresees about a year and a half before a statue stands in front of the Kennard African American Cultural Heritage Center.
Donations can be sent to United States Colored Troops Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 42, Centreville, MD 21617.
As a Maryland nonprofit, American Patriotic Monuments Inc. seeks to lead public arts projects and monuments that celebrate American legacies.
More information, including sponsorship opportunities, can be found at apmiart.org.
Information about Hemsley's work can be found at tilghmanhemsleyfinearts.com.

title: Local author encourages 'choose love'
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontragerchespub.com
content:
Local author encourages 'choose love'

 February 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontragerchespub.com | Section: News 
 
 725
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "Kitty the Goat and the Puppy" is the third book of what will be a five-part series from local kid's author Abraham Keys, who resides in Rock Hall.All of Key's children's books are based on his real-life farming experiences growing up in South America with eleven siblings, and all his books involve relationships not normally found in nature which teach lessons of acceptance and love.
For example, his first book is about a hen named Donkey...(it's already starting out confusing) and Donkey is a little glum and depressed. In the story, farmer Abe allows Donkey (the chicken) to not only sit on chicken eggs, but also duck eggs.
Well, Donkey ends up with a new lease on life, and when those ducks hatch, she cares for those ducklings like they are her very own.
Farmer Abe learns a valuable lesson from that. If a chicken can learn to love something so different, he can love people different from him too.
And "writer Abe" can instruct people that a chicken and duck cannot interbreed, and the chicken is simply incubating the duck eggs then loving the ducklings as her own.
This kind of love transcends, and is repeated again in Abe's second book: "Moo Moo the Dog Adopts a Baby Pig," published in December 2023.
The theme is, you guessed it, Moo Moo the dog taking care of a baby pig, even more different than a duck and a chicken, and offers another powerful lesson about acceptance to Farmer Abe.
Key's third book, "Kitty the Goat and the Puppy" has been delayed in shipment, but he is hoping for an Easter release. For his other books, you can find them on Amazon and some local book stores or contact him directly.
This time around Farmer Abe will learn from Kitty the goat, taking care of a puppy.
The story goes, Kitty the goat lives on a farm. He's a prize goat, but retires and like many in the limelight, gets depressed. And like many of us, depression gives way to mischief. Kitty is eating up the flower beds and gnawing on the clothesline as goats often do.
What breaks Kitty from those bad habits is raising a little puppy, and through this puppy, Kitty finds purpose again.
The lesson?
Choose love.
It's a lesson that resounds with many readers to the joy of Keys, especially in schools where love and acceptance is a key focus, he said.
Writing with no expectations, his first book did amazingly well. Within weeks of publishing he had schools waiting to buy 300 books and since then has sold 3-4,000 copies of the book.
His foray into writing began with a challenge from friends, and he is glad he went through with it, Keys said. Finding a local artist to complement his stories, he discovered a very special niche combining children's books and agriculture along with a message of love and acceptance.
With plenty of source material too, drawing from his family owning farmland in Canada, South America and Montana, he's creating the fourth book, where the animal theme will continue. The last book of the series will explore Farmer's Abe's past with a very special horse.
Keys success has continued to grow. He has been featured in four newspapers, including a story in Montana the place of his birth, a paper in Canada, and television broadcasts in Salisbury, Maryland in addition to being invited to several local schools.
As many story tellers will say, there are all kinds of ideas running around in his mind, but he is focusing on finishing out the series first.
And he is honing his craft, drawing inspiration from others like Jay Miletsky, author of 14 books including "Ricky the Rock Who Couldn't Roll."
Keys will further challenge himself as he prepares to attend his first writer's summit in Nashville, Tennessee. He will have the chance to connect with fellow authors, pitch his ideas to professionals and learn from longtime experts.
Thrilled with the possibilities ahead, he takes with him lessons from his latest book. "Farmer Abe was reminded that when given the chance, to always choose love. Because you just never know if the love you give to others might also change your life forever," Keys wrote.
Based on his whirlwind author's journey so far, it seems like he's on to something rather special.
For information about his books, Keys encourages you to contact him directly at 410-708-5164, or find him on Facebook under Abraham Keys.

title: Maryland legislators kick off 447th General Assembly
author: Konner Metz
content:
Maryland legislators kick off 447th General Assembly

 January 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 670
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — With snow piled up around the Statehouse, Maryland lawmakers returned to downtown Annapolis for the 447th General Assembly on Wednesday.More than 560 bills were prefiled in either the House of Delegates or Senate prior to the opening session. While both chambers began introducing bills Wednesday, the focus largely remained on the state's looming budget deficit that will be tackled in the coming weeks.
The state is predicted to face a $2.7 billion budget deficit in fiscal year 2026. Gov. Wes Moore (D), who some Republicans have criticized for his fiscal decisions, must submit his balanced budget proposal by next Wednesday.
Leadership in the House and Senate acknowledged the deficit will be center stage but spoke optimistically about what's ahead.
House Speaker Adrienne Jones, a Democrat from Baltimore County, said the House, which reviews the budget first, will "use it to reflect our values."
"As we begin this session, I know there has been a lot of talk about our financial limitations. And there should be," Jones said. "We can't deny our difficult fiscal reality. But instead of talking about what our budget can't do, I'd like to talk about what it can do. Most importantly, our budget has the power to protect the most vulnerable Marylanders."
Jones noted health care and transportation as areas that will continue to be prioritized, as well as the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's expansive education initiative.
"We don't want to talk about cuts and prioritizing programs, but we have to," Jones said. "We don't want to talk about high-energy costs, but we have to. And we have to talk about protecting the investment we made for our students and teachers in The Blueprint."
Senate President Bill Ferguson, a Baltimore Democrat beginning his sixth year in the role, said the General Assembly's efforts to fund and facilitate reconstruction of the Francis Scott Key Bridge last year showed the aptitude of Maryland's lawmakers.
"This institution showed exactly who it is," Ferguson said. "Within days, we had put together legislation working with our House counterparts, with the governor, setting up the PORT Act in a bipartisan way to find ways to put resources immediately to use, to set the state up for success in the midst of crisis."
Ferguson said the budget deficit is the General Assembly's next significant challenge.
"I've been thinking about it a little bit differently recently, in that yes it is a challenge, but really, it's an opportunity for us in this body," Ferguson said. " … What do we want our future to look like? How do we take this challenge and have the hard conversations about what do we prioritize to invest in people and to build communities in a way that everyone has the opportunity to thrive."
The Senate president offered positivity through the fact that the state came in under budget and ahead of schedule on a significant project just outside of the Statehouse — the Maryland Department of Legislative Services building. A ribbon-cutting ceremony will be held tomorrow, he said.
"What emerged was everything that the state of Maryland should look like," Ferguson said of the new building that he called "beautiful."
Leadership in both chambers remained the same Wednesday. Ferguson and Senate President Pro Tem Malcolm Augustine, a Democrat from Prince George's County, were unanimously nominated to their positions.
In the House, Speaker Pro Tem Dana Stein, a Baltimore County Democrat, was nominated and approved for a second consecutive year. Jones begins her sixth full term as speaker.
On Wednesday, the House Speaker reflected on the fact that her first job in public service was made possible by the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, legislation the late President Jimmy Carter extended during his time in office.
"I know that we all love public service," Jones said. "And when I think about public service, I think about the late President Jimmy Carter. As it turns out, I owe a lot to President Carter."
Jones said those are the ways in which "government can do powerful things for regular people."
"Progress isn't linear, it's incremental," Jones said. "It takes time. It takes resilience."

title: Mid-Shore could see highs in upper 90s as heat wave approaches
author: Konner Metz

Mid-Shore could see highs in upper 90s as heat wave approaches

 EASTON — As many regions in the United States prepare for a significant heat wave in the coming days, Maryland's Mid-Shore could see temperatures nearing triple digits next week.According to the National Weather Service, Easton is projected to see highs around 95 to 97 degrees beginning Sunday through Wednesday. Highs are expected to remain in the 90s later in the week across Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties.
The Dorchester County Health Department is encouraging people stay out of the sun when temperatures peak in the late mornings and early afternoons.
A press release from the department noted the following groups should take added precautions: babies, young children, pregnant women, older adults, outside workers and those without air conditioning.
Local health officials recommend regularly hydrating, limiting time outdoors and monitoring for signs of heat exhaustion — heavy sweating, cold skin, cramps, dizziness, nausea or vomiting, etc.
The Maryland Department of Health said in a press release this week that Maryland saw 26 heat-related deaths last year. The state department added that parents and guardians should never leave children in cars.
"Remember to check on those who are particularly vulnerable to heat, including young children, senior citizens, and people with chronic diseases — and confirm that they have the resources they need to stay safe during the hottest months," said Maryland Secretary of Health Dr. Meena Seshamani in the release.
EASTON FIRE PREPARES
As temperatures heat up, volunteer fire departments across the Mid-Shore remain on call. Due to the physically intensive work of firefighting and the heavy gear that must be worn, some departments are asking for water donations from the community.
Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief J.R. Dobson says his department has received enough cases of water from thoughtful community residents and businesses to get through next week's heat wave. Dobson is encouraging residents to contribute to other fire departments in need in Talbot County.
Whether it's lending bottled waters or assisting with manpower on a call, Dobson says local fire departments work together well.
"The other fire chiefs talk a lot, and we're always here to help one another," Dobson said.

title: Kent Samaritan Group nears goal to open emergency shelter in December
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent Samaritan Group nears goal to open emergency shelter in December

 October 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 649

 CHESTERTOWN — On Sunday afternoon, the day of its fundraising rally at Presbyterian Church of Chestertown, the Samaritan Group of Kent County had $1,400 toward its goal of $14,000 needed to open the Emergency Winter Shelter, in operation since 2003.Because of Christ First United Methodist Church's $5,000 donation, along with other donations, at the end of the event that afternoon, the group had $12,000.
Shelter Director the Rev. James Diggs said they need donations and are optimistic to reach the goal, but they also need volunteers for the shelter: some cooks, but more importantly they need hosts and sleepers. The host, Diggs explained, meets and greets the guests, ensures they are comfortable and safe while the sleepers stay the whole night.
Diggs announced this year they are aiming to open the shelter in December, a first.
That is up to the amount of volunteers that sign up. Diggs said that they have to have 85% of December filled to accomplish this, with volunteers especially needed Christmas Eve, Christmas, New Year's Eve and New Year's.
"Let's make this month a recruiting month. Help us do it because I think we certainly can. We're excited to be able to add December and maybe next year, add another month."
As winter approaches, the need increases to care for Kent County's homeless population he stated.
As their mission describes, the Samaritan Group of Kent County work with local agencies, churches, businesses and organizations and individuals to keep them warm and also providing financial assistance.
During the rally with refreshments and ice cream served by Marcia Stoltzfus and family, Diggs listed the shelter's accomplishments and gave out certificates and awards to the hardworking, caring volunteers which make it possible each year, adding a fun family event along the fundraising.
In the early winter months of 2025, they served 21 clients, seven women, two children and 12 men, 661 bed nights total. In 2018 they served 21 people as well, 1,033 bed nights and that next year, 28 people and 921 bed nights.
"The number of people we serve is unpredictable. We just don't know from year to year. The point is to be ready and all of you volunteers make that possible."
He thanked some of the volunteers that helped get the shelter ready.
Receiving the Laverne and Shirley Award was dynamic duo Annie Woodall and Andrea Nieman. Top Chef, and also supplying that tasty soft serve ice cream was Marcia Stoltzfus and family. The Host with the Most was Allison Brieske and Volunteer of the Year, who dedicated time cooking/ inspiring her whole church to cook, and hosting, was Anne-Marie Walters.
Many other certificates given as well, some of whom were not in attendance.
"They may not be here, but they were when it counted," joked Diggs.
Giving her testimony about the rewards of volunteering was Melanie Keller, who was recruited by Woodall and Nieman years back and was the volunteer coordinator for a time.
Keller said that after her third child, part of what kept her volunteering was her two children who also volunteer. They play hide-and-seek with guests and see other people's experiences, their suffering and joys and practice reaching out with compassion.
"We are a community and I hope to see some of you as hosts," she told attendees.
Diggs said hosts have a very important role, stay from 5:30-10 p.m. and are in pairs. Diggs personally greets the hosts each night and briefs them on what they need to know, ensuring they are comfortable.
Sleepers stay into the night and see guests off in the morning.
Diggs encouraged the audience to not only sign up but to become recruits, sharing the joys of volunteering at the shelter where Mid-Shore Community Foundation, United Way of Kent County, the Good Neighbor Fund and Kent County Department of Social Services partner in this important mission.
"We need your help," Diggs said to the community. "With it we can open up in December...one month at a time."
To contact them go to: info@samaritangroupofkentcounty.org.

title: Be careful what you vote for
author: Staff Writer
content:
Be careful what you vote for

 April 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 445
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Be careful what you vote forLast Sunday, Easton resident Larry Pifer's piece on "authoritarian government" was published in the Star Democrat. He spoke to real impacts of authoritarian governments of the past, but also to those currently taking hold, around the world and potentially, right here in America.
Larry's thoughts, observations and quotes, particularly this one, from Trump, himself, "I will be a dictator but only for a short time" should give all Americans reason to carefully consider who steers Good Ship America in the upcoming four years.
We do not have to rely on what other people say about who, or what, Trump is; he, himself, tells everyone that tunes in to national media many opportunities to hear it, directly from his own mouth. Granted, there are many, many other media outlets and pundits that will spin who and what he is, and what he will do for you, if you vote to elect him. However, many of the promises he made during his first presidential run, were never fulfilled, for example:
I'll build a great wall and Mexico will pay for it. NOPE.
I'll repeal Obamacare and give you better, cheaper health care, NOPE.
I'll bring manufacturing back to America, NOPE. Under his watch manufacturing jobs remained relatively flat, until they fell off the cliff as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.
I'll grow the economy by 4% per year, NOPE. Actually, his best year was 2018, when the economy grew by 2.9% over the previous year.
I'll cut taxes for everybody, NOPE. While many, but not all, benefited, marginally, from Trump's tax cuts, the vast majority went to the rich and to corporations, some of them not even American.
I'll terminate Obama's executive orders on immigration, NOPE. While one program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, (DACA), was challenged in our courts, it remains in effect, yet today. A second program, Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA), never was implemented, so Trump could not terminate it.
If you listen to Trump now, he is regurgitating some of the same promises he failed to fulfill during his first term in office, even though he enjoyed Republican majorities in both the U.S. House and the Senate for his first two years in office. Which brings me to a word, or two, of caution to those who choose to vote in the upcoming elections.
Be careful of those who don't keep their promises and be careful of the would-be dictator you vote to elect; you don't always get the kind of dictator you think you will, when you voted, based on what he and his minions tell you, and it is very hard to get rid of dictators.
WILLIAM C. KEPPEN
Easton

title: Was Biden's health cover-up worse than Watergate?
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Was Biden's health cover-up worse than Watergate?

 June 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 646
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In today's 24-7 media coverage of current events in the political world, stories are regularly introduced as "breaking news with more details to follow."That will most certainly be the case after the recent release of the book "Original Sin: President Biden's Decline, Its Cover-Up, and His Disastrous Choice to Run Again," coauthored by CNN's Jake Tapper and Axios reporter Alex Thompson.
Not surprisingly in today's deeply divided society, the reaction to the book has been mixed.
Some have said elected officials, and their staff lie regularly. They say it is and always has been the way of the world in which we live.
It has also been said that the public should not be surprised or upset when details emerge on behavior by elected and appointed government that is illegal or unethical.
Others have said illegal and unethical behavior is never acceptable.
They say the media has an obligation to report it, and those who engage in such behavior must be held accountable and punished to the maximum extent of the law.
Some have said, while such behavior is bipartisan, more often than not, it is overlooked or excused by some of the national media when it involves Democratic presidents.
They cite the levels of reporting by the national media on Bill Clinton's involvement with Monica Lewinsky, compared to Richard Nixon's involvement with Watergate.
Until recently, Nixon has been almost universally viewed as the least ethical and least honest president in U.S. history.
John Kass, a former Chicago Tribune political reporter and columnist has challenged that view by writing "… this one about Biden is much worse than the Watergate break-in. In that one the White House covered up the lawbreaking and the media uncovered it."
Even Jake Tapper has suggested that may be true in saying publicly, the "cover-up of the former president's mental decline may be a worse scandal than Watergate."
With that in mind, Congressional investigations are already underway on Biden's levels of awareness of and involvement on decisions made during his presidency.
More are likely to come.
It will be most interesting to learn answers given under oath to three questions:
Was there at any point during the Biden presidency, when, as a result of Biden's physical and mental health conditions, decisions that are the exclusive responsibility of an elected president were instead made by an individual or individuals other than the elected President?
If so and perhaps without President Biden being aware of it, did these individuals break the law, that is, by using autopen signatures on executive orders and pardons?
Was the media complicit if they ignored or did not follow-up with due diligence on these matters?
Other questions will not be answered until next year's midterm elections.
How many decisions were made by voters based on their support for or opposition to President Trump's agenda?
How many decisions were made on whether or not there was conclusive evidence of a coverup of President Biden's levels of engagement during all four years of his presidency?
Will the latter reflect an increasing loss of voter confidence in national news media outlets?
There are already signs of significant loss in that confidence in some of the national media.
Tapper's own CNN show had its lowest-rated month since August 2015. That should put every member of the news division of the national media on notice.
There are measurable and profound consequences on ignoring and disrespecting what Americans expect from national political news providers.
Going forward, American voters deserve three things from the national media.
Fact-based news with no hidden agendas.
Vigorous pursuit and continuous exposure of verifiable unethical and/or illegal behavior by every elected and appointed government official.
No group think — a psychological phenomenon when conclusions are not the result of a lack of information, but because of a conscious decision to put conformity above critical thinking.
Until that happens, all the excuses and explanations from the national media who failed to do their job during the Biden presidential years will be nothing more than too little, too late.

title: Talbot County diversity training, statement stir dialogue
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County diversity training, statement stir dialogue

 February 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Life 
 
 657
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A resolution to repeal Talbot County's diversity statement elicited strong reactions from the community over the weekend.While the Talbot County Council had its Tuesday meeting canceled due to impending snow, the resolution requested by Council Member Dave Stepp caught the eyes of many residents and organizations when it appeared on the meeting agenda.
Tina Jones, chair of the Demarva Pride Center, said the organization's board discussed it Sunday. Jones said the center opposes a potential repeal of the diversity statement.
"One of the things that our government is supposed to be is representative of all people, and that includes people in marginalized communities," Jones said.
The resolution's title on the agenda states that it would repeal two 2020 resolutions "regarding diversity training and development of a Talbot County diversity statement, respectively."
The first 2020 resolution implemented an annual report of diversity training opportunities offered to staff. The second facilitated the creation of Talbot County's diversity statement, which is now found in its employee handbook.
The statement defines diversity, equity and inclusion, explains its purpose and details the county's approach to ensuring diversity. It also outlines how employees can report discrimination.
Stepp, who joined the council in 2022, confirmed to The Star Democrat that he is bringing forward the new resolution.
"I certainly think there's a lot of folks that are out there that are trying to make this something that it isn't," Stepp said in an interview. "It's all financial in nature."
In a letter written to residents Tuesday, Stepp stated the resolution's purpose is to keep Talbot County "in good standing with the federal agencies providing funds" to the county. He said it's not an attack against the county's diversity and inclusion.
Stepp's letter makes mention of President Donald Trump's Jan. 20 executive order to end all diversity, equity and inclusion policies and programs in the federal government.
"What this proposed resolution will do is protect the Talbot County taxpayer from potentially not receiving the millions of dollars Talbot County already receives annually from the Federal Government," Stepp wrote.
Former Talbot County Council President Corey Pack brought forth the initial resolutions in the summer of 2020. In an interview Tuesday, he said the diversity statement was meant to "memorialize" what the council was already doing regarding diversity, equity and inclusion in the workforce.
Pack hopes any attempt to repeal fails and said he's disappointed the council may be looking to remove the statement.
"Put your money where your mouth is," Pack said. "If this is what you are about as a governmental body, what's wrong with putting that in writing? If you are a governmental body that believes in diversity, that believes in inclusion, that believes in equality, what's the fear?"
County Council Vice President Pete Lesher was on the council when the two resolutions were passed in the summer of 2020. He said he hasn't noticed anything that would lead him to "try to attempt to remove them."
"I've gone back and read over the language of the diversity statement, and I can't imagine what in there anybody would find objectionable," Lesher said in an interview.
Lesher added that he's worried removing the diversity statement could hurt the recruitment and retention of county government staff.
"I don't know that somebody would come here on the basis of whether or not we have these statements," he said, "but the publicity of actually proactively removing such a statement might send a signal that some people aren't welcome here."
Before Tuesday's meeting was canceled, groups such as the Delmarva Pride Center and Talbot County Democratic Forum encouraged members to attend the meeting and speak against the proposal.
"Our community voices matter. Together we can defeat this transparent challenge to the Eastern Shore value of treating others with dignity and respect at all times," wrote Michele Dappert, forum president, in a newsletter Saturday. "The community must speak out to ensure this progress is not erased."
The proposed resolution is expected to be on the agenda for the Talbot County Council's next meeting on Tuesday, Feb. 25.
